reviewText: I saw Battleship in the theaters earlier this year. 6 times. I love this movie. It is my favorite film next only to the Avengers. I thought this was better than Men in Black III. Since many have already reviewed the plot, I am going to share some of my favorite moments and tidbits. Director Peter Berg is a Navy fan and it shows. Battleship has outstanding Transformer style special effects, lots of action, a great cast and support of the Navy, which includes many naval personnel, both active duty, retired WW II & Vietnam vets and wounded warriors. (You must see Army Col. Greg Gadson, a real wounded warrior who lost his legs in Iraq, personally take on an alien warrior-he is one tough soldier!)You don't see many of the latter in save the world films. Taylor Kitsch is wonderful as Alex Hopper, our slacker turned hero and I love Alexander Skarsgard (True Blood) as his responsible Navy Captain brother Stone. They have a nice vibe between them. Rihanna is absolutely bad ass as Navy gunner Raikes. She spent time with weapons training with a real gunner named Jacqueline and she modeled her performance partly on this tough young lady. You will see Jacqueline in the bonus specials. Brooklyn Decker is wonderful as Sam, Alex's girlfriend and physical therapist. The alien weapons are awesome (the first ship destroyers are designed to look like the pegs in the board game), both peg projectiles and the formidable shredders which eat metal and have a mind of their own. We humans are considered much of a threat until we directly provoke them. Time for the Navy to save the day! While we normally see aircraft carrier and fighters, it is great to see what a destroyer does and Director Berg does a great job of putting you in the action and making it easy to follow.Ignore the critics and the bad reviews. This is a great movie, with lots of action and humor. I have friends who didn't see it in theaters, rented it loved and now wished they had seen it during its initial run. Several of them bought it. One friend said it had more action than the Avengers. Sit back, relax and enjoy seeing the Navy save the world. This is a wonderful tribute to our veterans, active, wounded and retired.**************************************************************************************************************THERE IS A BONUS SCENE AT THE END OF THE CREDITS SET IN SCOTLAND. Many people didn't know about it or missed it. The digital copy includes subtitles and languages and the bonus scene.****************************************************************************************************************Some favorite scenes:Alex getting tazed after damaging a convenience store to get Sam a chicken burrito. Great comic skills from Taylor.Alex meeting Captain Nigata (TADANOBU ASANO, a famed Japanese actor-Thor fans, you know him as one of the Asgardian Warriors 3) during the soccer match. Nigata kicks him in the face, causing Alex a concussion and the loss of the game. This sets up the dynamic relationship between the two.During the Rimpac exercises (the Naval games that include 13 nations participate in) some great moments:Alex explaining the difference between a destroyer and a battleship (a destroyer is the Terminator, a battleship is a floating punching bag)The opening ceremony aboard the Might Mo, USS Missouri battleship (the cast and crew shot aboard the real Mighty Mo, including a rare opportunity to film the Mighty Mo out at sea (details in the great making of docs including a tour) with over 600 multinational sailors and WWII vetsA great contrasting scene showing the difference in approaches Stone and Alex use while speaking to their crews. Stone as commander encourages his crew to be safe and learn cooperation from other nations and "Keep Charging." Alex as tactical action officer informs his crew to crush the enemy and outperform every other ship during the exercises. Watch the faces of the crew during Alex's speech when he says "We are not here in this weapons room to learn." Priceless looks from some of the real Navy sailors!When the Navy encounters the aliens and the action begins, note the care shown to include reactions from the sailors, they have some of the greatest reactions during the battles. "Who's running the ship? Hopper. Hopper is, we are all going to die?!" When a helmsman is steering the ship in a dangerous area, "Ordy, we are about to kiss these rocks, man! I can see fish man!"Alex in command of the John Paul Jones after the CO and XO are killed insisting on charging the overwhelming power of the aliens that costs Nigata his ship and the loss of the Sampson and brother Stone, being reminded by Petty Officer "Beast," (a great John Tui) that there are sailors in the water who need to be rescued.Key section in which Alex and Nigata begin to work together (their dynamic, contrasting styles help drive the film) while plotting their next move. When Nigata explains his water displacement strategy "seeing them without seeing them" Alex steps back and offers Nigata his chair, showing how much he has learned. Raikes (Rhianna) and other crew members give him questioning looks and he says "My brother would have done the same." One of my favorite scenes in the whole film. Watch the crew reactions as they first question and then rejoice in Nigata's clever usage of water displacement (like the battleship board game) to take out 2 alien ships.Destroyer John Paul Jones' destruction of the the third alien ship, which in turn sends out shredders to rip up the JPJ. Incredible special effects showing the shredders ripping the ship to pieces!A truly great scene where the survivors of the JPJ board the Might Mo. Beast says the ship is 70 years old with steam engines that he doesn't know how to run. There is a great view of the veteran sailors around the ship who come forward and step up once again when asked to fight. Great patriotic moment. I saw this on Memorial Day and the folks in the audience applauded. The Mighty Mo still packs a punch and it is worth it to see her take on the last alien ship and win. Another great section. Alex references the Art of War (a legendary Chinese guide to war strategy) several times during the film. Near the end he realizes the last confrontation reminds him of a section of Art of War. When the Mighty Mo defeats the alien ship, I love the exchange with Nigata.Nigata, "I can't believe that worked!" Alex, "Art of War, after all these years it finally clicked! Fight the enemy where they aren't." Nigata, "That's not what that means!" Alex, "Really?" Nigata, "Not even close!"Buy the ticket and take the ride. A number of reviewers on iTunes were surprised at the amount of action and enjoyed it as well. I think you will enjoy this fun film. I am sorry we won't get to see further adventures of Alex Hopper.
summary: Intense Action Thrill Ride with Heart

reviewText: When this came out in the movie theaters in early summer of 2012, I wanted to go see it, but a plethora of negative reviews persuaded me otherwise. I've been trying to purchase this DVD on eBay for months at a "reasonable" price. On Cyber Monday, Amazon came to the rescue with a half off deal on the DVD-Blue Ray combo. I watched it last night.The premise for aliens, who can travel light years across the galaxy, but cannot avoid crashing into one of our satellites and losing their only means of communications is a bit ridiculous. They resort to confiscating our telecommunications equipment, which supposedly can work with their super-advanced technology? Hello? Then, the battleships that traveled half-way across the galaxy can only skim across the ocean? There only armaments appear to be these mortar shells, which they lob at our ships and ironically resemble the pegs from the old battleship game. Hello? Where are the advanced projectile weapons and the energy beams and particle weapons? So, if you can ignore all this silliness, then you can sit back and enjoy the explosions and the special effects.If you want good, entertaining sci-fi with lots of action, get Avengers. If you want to watch the best movie of the year, get The Dark Knight Rises (latest Batman movie), which I pre-ordered weeks ago. If you want decent special-effects and can tolerate a slightly muddled story line in the grand tradition of sci-fi spectacle, get Prometheus. Battleship is now part of my ever growing DVD library along with classics such as Predator and Aliens. Happy Holidays:)

reviewText: This film should not have been made. The story is laughable, derivative and falls flat on its face. The two redeeming features were watching Rihanna and the (presumably) CGI Battleship. This film tries to be a summer blockbuster exploiting the proven formula of predecessors such as "Independence Day". However where Independence Day had a witty and at times quite clever script along with over-the-top acting, memorable characters and outrageous CGI, Battleships had none of these attributes. It is plain stupid. Liam Neeson, who is an entirely believable Command figure, is completely wasted in this miserable production. I did like Rihanna but I really can't say she was given an opportunity to prove her acting abilities. I do hope we see her in more films. Message to Hollywood. You need to cast your net wider for engaging stories, and stop poaching the talentless writers from the SyFy cable channel.

reviewText: If you like the "Transformer" movies, you will love "Battleship." Period. Some belly laughs, lots of great military action, buff athletic men and women performing impossible tasks against incompetent alien invaders. Some neat camios by vets and my favorite battleship, the USS Missouri.Sure, we are required to ignore the usual pesky things like physics (uh, anybody heard of the speed of light? Anyone?). Then traveling between the stars, but crashing into an orbiting satellite? Does anyone really believe that a race capable of waging interstellar war would need more than 15 minutes to destroy mankind? And does anyone believe that the undisciplined lead guy would be placed in command of a destroyer--EVER?That said, my wife and I thoroughly enjoyed this fun movie. We watched it on Amazon streaming video as a lark, but rapidly got engrossed and kept saying how much we were enjoying this movie. I put in an order for the Blu-ray version before the final credits. Like I said, it is what it is. Five stars if you like the Transformer movies. Steer clear if you are looking for sparkling dialog and deep meaning of life stuff.

reviewText: I'm usually all over blow 'em up alien sci fi.  But when I start looking for reasons to get up and walk around while the movie's playing, something's wrong. For Battleship, it was the complete lack of realism in how the Navy was portrayed. I'm retired Navy and from an accuracy perspective, this was junk. Here's why:Screw-ups like Alex Hopper would NOT be assigned as Tactical Action Officer (TAO) on an Arleigh Burke-class destroyer. The level of responsibility is too great. (Aegis ships are breeding grounds for type A personalities.)CIWS does not make a 'wee wee' sound when it fires. When CIWS fires, IT SHAKES THE WHOLE SHIP. (And CIWS, as I recall, was being phased-out for the Rolling Airframe Missile system.)You can't light off seven boilers on a steam-propelled battleship and expect to be underway in less than two hours (by the movie's timeline)...not happening.There is NO (ZERO, ZIP, NADA, ZILCH) live 16-inch ammunition on the MO (USS Missouri) in Pearl Harbor. Maybe a couple of de-militarized and highly polished rounds for show purposes on the Quarterdeck, but that's it. (The Navy doesn't leave high-explosives just lying around...sorry...)Zodiac boats (Z boats) are not 'lifeboats'.The TAO and scope operator on watch in the Combat Information Center (CIC, aka 'Combat') would not be pulled away from their watch for a boat detail. Stupid.I know I'm nitpicking. And most of the time, I can overlook stuff like this if the story is engaging and it seems like the movie makers were at least trying. Not this one. The acting was fine and the cinematography was great. But Battleship is not only mindless from an entertainment perspective, it's mindless from a credibility perspective, as well. If you're going to make a movie named Battleship and center it on the Navy in Pearl Harbor (where I served for five years), you need to do your due diligence to understand the culture you're writing about. Disappointing.

reviewText: Stay with me on this one and ask yourself upon reading my review whether you've ever "been there, done that"  --- here's the situation, you have the remote in hand and you go through the movie channels looking for something interesting and some get your attention and you watch it [or part of it anyway if it turns out to be a bomb] or you move on to another channel. So I'm doing this and the moment I click on the satellite channel, there are some guys [in today's USN uniforms] in a small boat and I see the Japanese guy [wearing his Japanese uniform of today] say, "What do you want us to do, Hopper, we have no ships left!" and this Hopper guy responds, "We have .... ONE" and he glances at the venerable "floating battleship museum", the USS Missouri, whereupon the Japanese guy says, "Are you crazy? That's a museum!" and Hopper says, "Not today it's not!" The scene and the lines got my attention so I continued to watch it and, cutting to the chase, once I saw that the "enemy" was out of space aliens, I was ready to move on but I hesitated ... and I'm glad I did! While I can't say that I'm a great fan of sci-fi movies [although there are exceptions], the stunning Blu-Ray quality and clarity of the movie and the special effects were 'so' good that I stayed with it, aliens from space or no aliens from space as the opposing force!Then I looked at the thing psychologically --- is it not true that as adults we make a trade-off, yes? We KNOW that virtually ALL movies are basically cinematic "set-ups" with a script, actors, cameras, cuts, directors, extras, etc. etc. ==but== we get into the thing because we are willing to suspend reality for a set period of time in order to be entertained! Think about that! BTW, this is precisely why 'some' directors INSIST in their contract that if they are in charge of the movie, they do NOT want any "The making of ..... " features as some claim that their efforts in creating the "grand illusion" [especially with an good script and excellent actors] is then ruined! It's somewhat akin to various directors who frowned 'mightily' when the colorization process started some years ago of classic B&W; films but it died out because of the the resulting criticism from those who made the film! Anyway, back to the Battleship movie, first it had the full cooperation of the US Navy and could film scenes on government owned ships and get the reality input of 'real' Navy personnel and, again, I found the special effects so outstanding that this alone was a compelling reason to watch the whole movie. I thought the casting was good too and you would never know that the real-life double amputee LTC in the film had never acted previously but I thought he was excellent in the role he played. The action is non stop and once you get used to the idea that the "enemy" are out of space aliens, well, hey, action is action!You can't go wrong with the price either for which you get a standard DVD disc, a Blu-Ray disc [with excellent Blu-Ray remastering for those high definition pics] and there are film extras including "the making of ..." kind of thing and cast interviews. There are some humorous scenes here and there [the chicken burrito thing, etc.] but overall it's an interesting watch and those special effects rather neat. I also liked and appreciated the film going out of its way to pay tribute to the 'real' military personnel and giving film parts to real military people or that one great scene where former real life crew members of the USS Missouri come by and the leader of the Navy Veterans says, "What do you need,son?" , and Hopper says, "We need to borrow your boat."Doc Tony
summary: I liked it but a confession follows ...

reviewText: I'm amazed at the stupidity of this movie. To explain why, I'm going to describe the first few minutes of the film. At the very beginning they explain how we built an entire radio array in 2006 (which will later turn out to be a radar station, because they're clearly the same thing) to contact the sole extrasolar planet within habitable range of its sun (how many radio arrays do we already have operating?). This is followed by a radio transmission in the form of a burst of energy like a phaser beam being sent out of this array via a satellite. I already knew I would hate this film.Then to impress a girl at a bar the main character breaks into a convenience store in what's supposed to be an amusing scene set to the Pink Panther theme. Against all probability he succeeds in winning the girl with this stupid immaturity. So then his brother signs him up for the navy. Which is funny, 'cause I didn't know brothers could do that. Maybe I'll enlist mine just for kicks. The rest of the film is supposed to be him getting over this immaturity, but after such a stupid display the character has used up every smidgeon of the sympathy we naturally feel for main characters. At one point he's actually trying to get his crew killed in a suicidal attack because his brother died and he wants revenge.Taylor Kitsch demonstrates the acting talent that makeJohn Cartersuch an unbridled commercial success. He's believable neither as the mature sailor nor the immature man-child. About the only thing he can sell right is cocky incompetent. And he still gets the girl. Whoop. The moral here (as in far too many other movies of late) is that spoiled, idiot, immature boys with no self-control offer a vital dose of much needed passion into the impersonal and formal environments of modern society, and worse, that they can actually perform when it comes to crunch-time. Why Hollywood thinks we need this lesson is beyond me.I will admit that over time I found Kitsch's obvious effort and passion charming, but it's the kind of feeling you get for a drugged puppy repeatedly walking into a wall. And it just isn't enough. Liam Neeson is in this film too. He has an atrocious gung ho American accent. There's not that much more to say about him since he spends the entire film on the wrong side of an alien force field. Genghis Khan gives probably the best performance in the film. Rihanna isn't actually that bad as a naval officer with no role. She certainly didn't deserve that Razzie. Everyone else is pretty unmemorable. The girlfriend and her entire plot features the worst acting in the film, except possibly for Peter Nicols who overplays an incompetent Secretary of Defense.The aliens are impossibly inconsistent. When the plot decides they want them dead they're incredibly weak, yet the rest of the time the Navy's full firepower can't touch 'em. Also, they don't shoot at anyone who doesn't attack them, unless they do. And there was a big revelation I kept waiting for that would have explained the alien motivations along with why they didn't kill certain key people. But nope. Just a stereotypical psychic flash of explosions and conquests from when Kitsch looked into an alien's eyes.Cinematically this film is all over the place. It makes a massive overuse of the 'rapidly slow down/speed up zoom in/zoom out' camera movements. The efforts that they go to to match up with the game are amusing. They have the grid laid out and everything (although apparently its weather buoys) and when the ships get hit by the aliens the missile things look like the pins you stick in the ships.Good things: The movie has two good lines at the end, one about dying and the other about the Art of War. And the final battleship fight is pretty cool, albeit totally irrational. I think that if the whole movie had been like the last twenty minutes I'd have forgiven it a lot, but by the time you get there it's already too late.

reviewText: Good special effects and good mindless explosions.  It was a whole lot more fun than watchin' the Dukes of Hazard wreck cars.If you're hung-up on reality, then don't bother.  Does anybody know how long it takes to put an Iowa Class Battleship to sea?  With a full crew compliment?  Well, just don't let those details worry your pretty little heads pilgrim.  Just sit back and watch a bunch of John Wayne types light the ships boilers with their cigars to get underway to defeat an alien that has travelled millions of light years to stomp on our bug-like butts.Oh, and does anybody realize just how much a sixteen inch artillery round weighs? Hint: Think of a mid-seventies model Cadillac.  Now how many sailers does it take to pick one up and carry it through the bulkheads of a battle wagon?Like I said, don't sweat the details.  Just enjoy the carnage and destruction.P.S. Don't shake hands with a four fingered alien.  Especially if each of their fingers opposes all of the others.
summary: Ahoy Maties! Forget Reality! Let's Just Have Fun!

reviewText: The movie Battleship is supposedly based on Hasbro's boardgame. Funny, I don't remember any space aliens being in the game.Anyway . . . .The movie deals with a thought that has been kicked around in the past few years: in our desire to contact alien civilizations . . . is that really such a good idea? The underlying assumption is that if they are technologically advanced enough to receive our transmissions, then they must be benevolent, right? I mean, just look at us, we have the technology to create atomic bombs and human beings are benevolent, right?Riiiiight.The movie more or less begins with a disheveled loser being tasered for breaking and entering and a few months later, he is not only in the navy, but an officer.Riiiiight.Then, at the same time, there is a 15 nation naval war game going on near Pearl Harbor, Hawaii---of which, inexplicably, only Japan and the US are involved (beginning as rivals, then ultimately cooperate. FIRE THE SYMBOLISM CANNON: KABOOM!!).Anyway . . . .Aliens arrive in behemoth transports near Hawaii, land in the ocean and set up shop. They put up a force field that keeps everything out. Three alien dreadnoughts appear. Three destroyers are already inside the dome and two are dispatched quickly (one of them being the Japanese one) when they attack the aliens. As long as one does not attack the aliens they pretty much ignore you, except for the forces in Hawaii, where this rule doesn't seem to apply. The loser officer becomes captain when the ship's former captain gets killed and he shapes up in time for the struggle. The aliens are humanoid, of course, with hands, eyes and even teeth and tongue, which makes you wonder when are we going to ever come across a truly alien alien.The special effects are great and so are the battle scenes and they will keep you interested and excited and oblivious to the obvious blunders (except for the in-your-face blunders, like the black guy with no legs beating up an armored, weaponed, alien. Riiiiight).

reviewText: How this movie didn't do better at the box office is beyond me. Good looking cast, paper thin plot, and awesome special effects. What's not to like?! It is the truest form of summer blockbuster schlock since Pirates of the Caribbean 4. I found it simple and concise; Earthlings send message into space, years later alien recon force arrivals to determine if the Earth is fit to invade. American armed forces in the form of the Navy battle the superior force and it is up to the aged Battleships to stop the aliens from sending the final acknowledgement to launch an all out invasion of Earth.  When it's all done tons of stuff has been blown up, the good guys kill all the aliens, and the hero gets the girl. Had this been made in the 90's it would have been called ID4.

reviewText: Battleship takes a while to warm up.  At first you're inclined to think it's absolutely horrible judging solely the first 30 minutes which is dominated with WAY too much pointless attempts at humor.  They all fall flat on their face time and time again involving a Naval officer.  The bathroom scene is probably the worst... or how about the burrito/taser gun segment?  These two are EXTREMELY awful, seriously.However, almost out of nowhere (much to my personal satisfaction) suddenly 4-5 spacecrafts appear on radar and... guess where they're heading?  Why of course, planet Earth!  Wouldn't be very fun to have them crash on Venus would it?  Anyway, they blow an explosive hole through the atomsphere upon impact, destroying satellites in the process.  From here... well, what's the name of the movie?  Battleship.  This means several Naval officers are on ships in the middle of the ocean and forced to deal with these invading creatures.  Explosion after explosion, it's nonstop excitement.  Both sides constantly trading attacks back and forth... I was worried even MORE of these spaceships would appear!The aliens themselves aren't portrayed the way we've seen in several other films.  In fact they're drastically 100% different!  They almost resemble monkeys in the face, and aren't nearly as threatening without their spaceships.  That is, when the one Naval officer eventually finds one temporarily down and out and takes his helmet off.  This is when we finally see them.  I always love the suspense here.  What WILL they look like?My favorite segments are the one that show this giant destructive spinning ball made of blades storming off the spaceships and tearing up everything in its path.  This is downright *awesome*.  Why not tear up the little league kid playing ball, though?  Because that would be downright mean!  I couldn't help but compare these spinning balls to the legendary one and only Samus Aran (video game fans know what I'm referring to here, hehe, especially Metroid Prime lovers!)  Of course Samus can't rip things apart in her ball form... oh well.  Comparable enough!My only grip (other than the severely lackluster story-less 30 minutes in the beginning) are all the heavy metal/alternative rock songs.  They sort of diminish the action-packed storytelling and make the alien invasion concept seem significantly less serious.  I mean come ON!  Aliens are invading Earth!  Loud music doesn't really make these scenes any better in my opinion- tacky instead.  The AC/DC music near the end is really unnecessary (despite the song being great of course, because AC/DC is a great band!)  Overall, wonderful movie for science fiction lovers.

reviewText: I don't get where reviewers online are saying this movie is too loud, too predictable and generally uninspired. Not only that but they compare it to Michael Bay's Transformers film and they also say that it has absolutely nothing to do with the actual board game. Okay. How else could they have made this movie without treading ground that's already been covered? Personally, I think that Peter Berg did an excellent job with this film. Visually, I think Berg's film is a step above Bay's Transformers.Battleship, itself, is about an international naval battleship that is Earth's last hope against a hostile alien force at sea.Steven James Snyder of Time Magazine described the movie as "an unlikely mix of Independence Day, Pearl Harbor, Jurassic Park and The Hunt for Red October"..which, to me, is the most accurate description of this movie. That mix works for this movie.To me, Battleship was one of the better movies out there this summer, despite what everyone else has to say about it. I'll admit, there may have been better summer movies but, as far as sci-fi goes, Battleship was a great movie. I really enjoyed it! Hopefully, it will have a better life now that it's on DVD & Blu-ray. Give it a look, you won't be disappointed. I assure you!

reviewText: I almost did not go to this movie, but am glad that I did.  Battleship starts off with a great piece of humor as the main character, Hopper, breaks into a convenient store to get a woman a chicken burrito. Fed up with his lack of direction in life, Hopper's brother forces him to join the movie. Skip a year to two later and Hopper is not a Lieutenant in the Navy and stationed on a Destroyer in Hawaii. Then the aliens come.Some of you might think that this is just another alien invasion movie where humans must defend themselves from annihilation. Though the plot line is similar, Battleship is still different. To me this was a story about accepting change and growing up with the alien invasion as a backdrop. Hopper is a very immature character when you meet him at first. When the aliens arrive in Hawaii and destroy most of the Naval fleet stationed there, he is suddenly left in command of a very cr*ppy situation. He has to figure out how to rally what is left of his crew to fight, discover the aliens' weak point, and destroy them before they can call for help. This horrific incident forces Hopper to grow up and learn what it is he's made of. That is something very few people ever get to learn.There is another character in the movie who is a Army Lieutenant that lost both of his legs while fighting overseas. When you meet him he is angry at that and feels incomplete and useless. When the aliens arrive, the man learns that even without his legs, he quite capable of putting up a fight. He hikes up to where the aliens built a communications array with two other people, to destroy it. He learns to accept the loss of his legs, but also discovers that he has more than just physical strength. He has courage and the willingness to do what needs to be done.Another thing I love about this movie, is that it paints the U.S. Military in a positive light. It shows men and women putting their lives on the line to defend everyone else. There is also a scene where Hopper and his crew join with a bunch of retired Navy soldiers, all of whom are in the 60s or older, to navigate the USS Missouri, which currently serves a museum, out into the open water. They then use the decommissioned ship to obliterate the alien warship. I thought it was a nice touch because it pays tribute all who have served in the military.Battleship has a lot of explosive action and won't let you down on that score. There are plenty of scenes with the main characters going toe to toe with these armored aliens. There is also a good amount of humor mixed in to break up the intense action sequences. In short, if you liked Battle L.A., you will like this movie. It is well worth seeing in theaters even with today's prices.
summary: Great Movie-Glad I went to it.

reviewText: Lets be honest here, the movie is -well- dumb but not the way you might think. Because the studio wanted a wider audience, paying for tickets, they made a key mistake in the PG-13 rating gutting what could have been a really gritty and brutal flick. It had all the makings for a hard R rating but no. That's not what we got so the "bad guys" avoided killing people even when they posed a direct threat. It was very bizarre to say the least. The only recourse the director had was to show alien tech destroying human tech and that's the real gem of the movie.Dont get me wrong. The special effects are top notch and the surround sound is equally engaging. I cant wait to get this in my home theater! Just because the movie is dumb, and requires no thought, doesn't mean I didn't like it! I happen to like some "B" movies including "B" movie #1 "Battle: L.A."! It set the standard for "B" movies in my eyes.This is more like one big audio/video demo from start to finish...

reviewText: I really liked Battlefield L.A. and thought that this might be something akin to that only taking place on water. Well I was wrong. The movie has a lot of glaring questions not answered. Why is the US Navy involved with other countries Navy's in military exercises? It tries to lay some well worn subplot about the Older, can do not wrong brother trying encourage his younger brother to take more responsibility and seriousness his role in the Navy with a kinda Rah Rah feel to it.When the Aliens appeared on the Radar I thought, great, now the screaming starts. Well for reasons unknown the Aliens reason for coming to earth is not at all defined. We know that one ship lands on an Island of the Hawaiian kind to set up satellites to call in other ships, or so the characters assume, but they really seem like prospectors. Their ships are big, but they lack for any real apocalyptic armaments other then then outside canons and these rollers with spikes which would seem to indicate that they are in the mining business. And these wheels are like their digging machines. Their ship really seem made for cargo transport then battle.Their technology differentiates between friend, schooner or yacht and possible foe battleship and they never fire on civilians only the obviously armed Battleships.  I think we fired first, but the plot hole is why they did not try any attempt at communication as to their intentions which may have only meant mining, perhaps for some materials that their technology could reach and maybe it was more of a supply gathering splashdown. Maybe they needed alloys for repair. Anything. But all we do is open fire. Back and forth and a bunch of silly dialogue in-between. Was Liam Neeson hard up for a check? Cause he barely had anything close to 20 minutes screen time. The plot if thats what it was, was all over the place and droned on till you really stopped careing by the middle of the film.  A real stinker of a Alien movie. That I stand by.
summary: Battleships makes you feel your adrift on a vast ocean of tediousness./spoilers

reviewText: THE GOOD1. The battle sequences are fun, watching Navy ships strategize and duke it out with superior alien vessels.2. The acting is pretty good.3. The special effects and explosions.THE SILLY1. Some of the dialogue is clunky.2. There are some issues with time, such as how quickly the aliens get to Earth (faster than light?), and how quickly the main character goes from drifter to naval officer.3. Naval procedural issues, like sending key CIC staff out on boat detail, and making a World War 2 museum piece battleworthy in a few hours time.RECOMMENDATIONIf you're looking for a mindless, "war" movie with a good dose of explosions and naval battles pitting the Earth vs. aliens, AND if you can look past some of the silly stuff, then you'll probably have a good time watching this fun, popcorn flick.However, if you get hung up on some of the silly stuff, OR if you're expecting an Academy Award winning movie, then you might want to pass on this one, or at least wait until you can watch it as a rental.Dads with young sons will probably enjoy this movie.  I went and saw this with my 8-year-old son, and we both had a fun time.

reviewText: This is a great heroic, action filled, alien movie. I am a fan of end of the world type movies, and this one did not disappoint me. The hero is a troublemaker, a smart young man who can't seem to get his act together. When his brother dies, he is pushed to the forefront as a leader of a Navy Destroyer. I didn't want that ship destroyed, even in a movie. I would have to reconsider my rating if something happened to that floating museum.Overall, it was great. The actors were believable, even Rihanna. reviewText: I enjoyed this film. Straight off, it was fun. If you liked Transformers, or ID4, you'll like this one. It's fun, and stupid, and full of holes, but that what cheese is all about.It's also a good family film, as there are no real violent deaths, or blood, or nudity, or even swear words.This is not Skyline, or Battlefield LA.That said, here are some spoiler questions:1) How does a guy who just broke into a store, get out the next day and able to enlist in the Navy?2) How does said guy, who has about the intelligence of Homer Simpson, get to lieutenant?3) How can Alien Race who can travel the stars, not have a guided missile, Just mortars?4) Why does a Race that prefers dark, need lights to see in the dark?5) Why can they detect the insides of something, but can not detect that it's the same kind of creature that attacked before. If you killed a roach, then saw a second roach, you would know it was a roach.6) If the guy can break into the satellite station to get a radio, why can he not just turn off the satellites, or redirect them?7) why do the aliens carry no weapons, except a hammer/sword thing?8) In the 1 hour trip to the North side of the Island, The captain on the destroyer could not take the time to lock onto the Radar dishes and destroy them?9) After being fired on twice by the enemy (with major damage), the Navy ships still only fire single shots at them with their main gun. Why not open fire with everything? It is a Destroyer, right? And we see what opening fire, can do to the enemy later. Pretty effective.10) Why are the enemy soldiers bulletproof, but the ships are not?11) How do the aliens fit into their armor? The legs on the unit are thinner then most super models.This list can go on and on.....
summary: 4 stars for fun, not for quality

reviewText: "Battleship" is a enjoyable movie that should be watched for it's entertainment value alone. There are a lot of plot holes and theBattleshipgame tie-in is just cute, but there is plenty of action and special effects to make this a "popcorn" movie night standby.No plot spoilers from me: the movie centers on gifted, but under achieving Navy Lt. Hooper (well acted by Taylor Kitsch), who is facing a less than stellar future. Things definitely change when scheduled War Games get interrupted by alien invaders bent on establishing a foothold in Hawaii.Over analyzing why the aliens didn't use their vastly superior technology in different ways will take the fun out of this feel good movie. I choose to just enjoy the premise, likable characters, good action, and great special effects.Recommended!CFH
summary: Just Fun, A Feel Good Movie - Recommended

reviewText: Spoilers!Battleship is a movie that could have been good. Aliens receive a signal sent by Earth and drop in to say hello. Be sure to skip the first 30 pointless minutes of this movie, when they introduce a bunch of shallow characters that barely do anything, a pointless side plot, and play soccer. Anyway, their trip goes wrong when their communications ship slams into a satellite and burns up in the atmosphere (I guess their steering wheel was broken), and they land in the ocean to be greeted by our esteemed US Navy. Unfortunately Earth is the last place they should have visited. This movie is delivered on the surface as a typical alien invasion movie. Under the surface, there is nothing aggressive or dominating about the aliens at all. They try to land near the source of the signal we sent, try to communicate with our Naval ships, and are promptly shot at.What follows is a series of aggression on the part of an incompetent military that shoots first and asks questions later. The aliens, almost reluctantly, destroy our ships and create a giant shield around Hawaii so they can phone home. No doubt to say, "Help! These people are nuts!!"You spend the entire movie feeling sorry for the poor aliens. Especially when being attacked by a bunch of military misfits. A confused young man who cries at his post because he doesn't know what to do during battle. A slacker who somehow manages to end up in command of his own ship, and then promptly orders them to ram the aliens and kill everyone. They are saved of course by a Japanese commander and a bunch of 80 year old retired naval officers who are the only ones in this movie who seem to know what they are doing. Why the Navy thought this was a good movie to support, I have no idea.Throughout the film, the aliens do everything they can to protect themselves and avoid killing the natives. They go out of their way to rescue one of their own without hurting anyone else. They risk boarding the ship to disable it rather than destroy it, which they could have easily done. Their weapons are primitive and ineffective for a interstellar travelers. The mechanical suits they wear don't have any weapons at all. At the end of the movie, the aliens are destroyed and our protagonists all get medals. I really feel like this was a different movie that was gutted in the editing room and changed with a slap-on new ending. At least at the end of Independence Day, you felt like the aliens deserved it. At the end of this movie, I felt like we just killed a stray puppy and paraded it's dead body down Main Street.Oh, and just to justify the name of the movie, there's a scene where they blindly lob shells at each other on a Battleship grid. Because of course, an advanced interstellar traveling spacecraft would have no way of seeing a giant 500ft steel boat in the dark.
summary: A good movie is missing here...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Finally, a summer without Michael Bay or Roland Emmerich, but in its place we get Peter Berg's "Battleship". By the end of this review, I hope to get across that I think that's a good thing. "Battleship" is big, silly and flawed, but while I say that, it is certainly a worthy addition to the summer blockbuster rollout. It may be facing an uphill battle against "The Avengers", "The Amazing Spiderman", "Dark Knight Returns" and "Prometheus", but it shouldn't be overlooked as a fun trip to the movies.To make matters worse, "Battleship" was wedged right between the billion dollar "Avengers" and another anticipated movie coming out next week, "Men in Black 3". Yet, what Peter Berg understands about making movies is that people really register with personality and humanity, which "Battleship" has in spades.Taylor Kitsch (John Carter) plays Lieutenant Alex Hopper, a loose cannon, unpredictable, Maverick from "Top Gun" kind of character. You get the gist of his personality in the very first scene we meet him as he takes going that extra mile for a girl to a whole new level. Brooklyn Decker plays Samantha Shane, a girl who just wants a chicken burrito and Hopper is out to impress. That scene sets the tone for the rest of the movie."Battleship" knows what it is. It is big and silly. The comedy is frequent and the comedy, for the most part, works. Yet, when the trouble occurs, the creators have done their job and we feel the urgency and peril in their dilemma. As aliens from a similar planet from a distance galaxy explode into our atmosphere, bent on taking over, the trouble grows thick and it grows fast. You feel the overwhelming and seemingly invincible nature of the invaders.Peter Berg knows that people relate to people, not explosions and he puts the comradery and humanity of the navy officers on full display. "Battleship" isn't trying to be serious. It knows it's big and crazy. A perfect example is the one element of the film where the U.S.S. Missouri, docked for museum purposes, is recommissioned along with the elderly veterans that inhabit it. Still, not only is this an entertaining wrinkle, it is also pretty cool seeing the filmmakers refer to the U.S.S. Missouri as the quality vessel that it is. Not to mention, seeing the elderly veterans talking trash about their battleship."Battleship" is a fun movie. It reminded me of "Top Gun", "Hunt for Red October", & "Crimson Tide" with aliens and comedy thrown in. It is a worthy summer movie and I hope that people do go see it, so that Hollywood knows that we like personality, humanity and story with our explosions. I'm bored with Michael Bay and Roland Emmerich type movies. Never once was I bored during "Battleship".

reviewText: My first impression ofBattleship, was one of OK, I'll just wait for it to come out on DVD because I'm not paying movie prices to see this on a big screen. In hind sight, this was a really stupid decision! I carefully watched all of the ads and purchased the brand new Battleship 2012 the day it became available. Even then, I found Amazon.com to have the best price on this product. I received it in less than the two days expected and in excellent condition, of course.My wife and I sat down, with a big bowl of popcorn, and watched this movie without even a bathroom pause. We didn't want to miss a second of this film. Yes, I know we can pause it, but it's just not the same, do you know what I mean? The time went by in a flash and the next thing we knew, we were looking at the credits. For a few seconds we just sat there, then looked at each other and said, "That movie was outrageously crazy fun! Let's watch it again." To say we were very pleasantly surprised at the acting, writing, overall plot with superior special effects, even throwing in a good 5 minutes or more of them actually fighting the aliens by playing the original form of Battleship the game, is a gross understatement.I can't figure out how a movie like this can get panned so badly by the alleged critics, appear to bomb at the box office and yet when we watch it, the film is outstanding. Do these critics not have an imagination or have any fun in life? The premise is somewhat predictable, so big deal. Like stupid humans we send a powerful radio beam message to another planet inviting them here. As stated by one to the science people, if this is successful it will be like the Indians sending a message inviting the Conquistadors and the more advanced societies always win. Meaning, we are the Indians. By this time we're saying, "No .... kidding." Sure enough this very advanced civilization of aliens come to Earth and it's not to play Hazbro board games either. Then the fun really begins.This movie is nothing but visual candy for the sci-fi adventure people, especially if you enjoyed the "Transformers" series. It's appropriate for just about any age as there is a lack of bad language, violence or blood and gore, all while teaching the lessons of thinking out of the box and good wins out over evil. The bottom line to us was, if Liam Neesan was playing a major role, this was going to be a quality movie and we were not disappointed. I highly recommend this movie as a multi-watch quality product appropriate for the entire family. Of course, if you're going to watch it on your own home theater, turn the volume up high cause it's gotta be loud to be good.

reviewText: Do you remember that scene in "Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle" Where Harold (John Cho) and Kumar (Kal Penn) are hiding in the women's restroom as those two women play "battle sh--s" with one another? It was not only expected that that scene would be better than the 131 minute duration of "Battleship", but the way that scene possibly smelled would also be like a bed of roses in comparison. Brought to you by Hasbro, the company that brought us "Transformers" is a movie that looks like it's trying so hard to be exactly what you've already seen in those three blockbuster movies. The actual result is one thousand times worse than you can possibly imagine.For the first 45 minutes, you're left wondering where in the world is this movie the trailers hinted at? You're introduced to Taylor Kitsch as Lieutenant Alex Hopper, who appears to be still drinking off the failure of "John Carter". Alex is the stubborn rebel who never listens to anybody and flies by the seat of his pants except all of his decisions would be idiotic even to a ten year old. On his birthday, he is jobless, drinking with his brother Stone (Alexander Skarsgrd), is shot in the back with a taser gun after breaking into a closed gas station food mart trying to obtain a chicken burrito to impress a buxom blonde named Sam (Brooklyn Decker), and is drafted to the Navy the following morning by Stone.If that wasn't enough, you're subjected to a game of soccer where Alex continues to be terrible at everything as he gets kicked in the face, misses a goal that would've sent the game into overtime, loses the nerve to request permission from Sam's father Admiral Shane (Liam Neeson) about marrying Sam, and gets into a bathroom brawl with Japanese Captain Yugi Nagata ("Thor"'s Tadanobu Asano). Isn't this amazing, you guys? It's exactly like the board game you used to play growing up!Then the aliens arrive. You tried to contact alien life with groundbreaking technology and then you're surprised when you get a devastating response that could affect the world as we know it. Smooth. As they arrive, Peter Berg reveals just how much he looks up to Michael Bay as he tries to mimic every explosion, action sequence, and plot device the Californian director has become successful for. "Battleship" is a combination of "Armageddon", all of the "Transformers" movies, Halo, and James Cameron's "Titanic" as the main references to the board game lie within ammunition from the alien ships looking like game pegs and the entire "water displacement" scene being the actors playing the game itself on a huge screen. The line "You sunk my battleship!" is never uttered. They had to make room for a fist fight between a man with no legs and one of the aliens. Oh, if only that was meant to be a joke.The acting is really, really bad. Taylor Kitsch attempts to be the lovable idiot, but he comes off as more of a lite version of Keanu Reeves. This is also Rihanna's acting and feature film debut, but her character was only designed to state the obvious and verbalize sound effects ("BOOM!"). Hamish Linklater's entire performance seems to be inspired by Tom Green and Liam Neeson could only stomach having six or seven minutes of screen time despite how much money was thrown at him. It's like they cast Hawaiian natives and war veterans with no acting experience in many of the supporting roles."Battleship" wants to be "Transformers" so bad. The lame and juvenile attempts at humor are along the same lines as the humor everybody hated in "Revenge of the Fallen" that was crammed down your throat the majority of the movie. Its formula is even similar; aliens invade earth and destroy everything they can with a plan to overcome the Earth, a (bunch of) secondary character(s) dies that inspire the main cast, the once thought useless character becomes useful, saves the day, and grows into a hero without learning a lesson but teaches the world to succumb to his reckless ways. The only difference is "Battleship" has this old man AC/DC montage that goes on entirely too long and they make a battleship drift out in the ocean that would impress anyone from the "Fast & Furious" franchise."Battleship" is just so awful every way you look at it. If you could somehow take out the entire first hour and the last fifteen minutes, and watch all of the action sequences on mute, it would still only be partially watchable. If the atrocious acting and mind numbingly familiar storyline weren't enough, the regurgitated attempt at recycling Michael Bay's success should be enough to send you running and screaming out of the theater. But the one question this terrible excuse of a movie does leave you with is just what could the number for humility actually be?
summary: "I have a bad feeling about this."

reviewText: Battleship is like a cross between Independence Day and Transformers and is not even close to being as good as either of those films. The film is probably OK for 10 - 12 year old boys, but that's about it. The actors give the impression that they are a.) reading their lines, and b.) cannot wait to be finished with the film. The plot is absurd (taking the USS Missouri out to sea and finding live WWII shells still on board). The Navy does not take boneheads off the street and make them into lieutenants, even if their older brother is a Lt. Cmdr. There are more than three officers on a destroyer, so when the CO and Exec are KIA there would be more than one officer and a handful of enlisted remaining in the crew. When a captain gives a command to a desron (destroyer squadron) he is not ordering the start of air operations. EMI sufficent to take out radar, targeting, etc., would probably also take out most of the command and control systems. There is no such thing as slingshoting radio transmissions (which by the way, are invisible). And the list goes on and on and on. Hollywood could have done much better by not making the film and giving the money to a food shelf network.

reviewText: Not sure I like the "hot-head-kid makes good" type of story as much as I did before Hollywood beat it to death.  Another such movie was J J Abrams Star Trek.  Whether they don't allow enough story arc for the character to change, or maybe they see it as a new archtype and just expect audiences to know that when command is thrust upon them, these bad boys of course grow up (which, of course, they don't in real life).  Either way I wasn't buying the main character in this film .... or too many of the other primary characters for that matter.  Which is too bad cause the story premise and it's progression was fine, the special effects were fine, Rihanna was great for what little she was given ... but Liam Neeson was handed a cardboard cut out of a role and there wasn't much he could do with it, Taylor Kitsch, who did perfectly fine in the under rated John Carter of Mars film, didn't do much for me, and his girlfriend Sam and her double amputee patient could have been played by cardboard cut outs (Brooklyn Decker and Gregory D. Gadson in these roles .... I know Gregory Gadson is a vet and this is his first role, but my criticism falls here mostly on the director, Peter Berg, who should have worked some of the woodenness out of this performance before committing it to the movie).All in all, it didn't suck, but it could have been a lot better.
summary: Maybe three and a half would be better ....

reviewText: This is a fairly predictable fantasy/adventure movie with good special effects and some interesting scenes of naval vessels. You will definitely want to check your mind at the door before starting to watch it if you intend to enjoy all of the action and a lot of the action is well done.The opening section is a little tiresome as the flaws of the main character are defined but later, after several massive leaps of unlikely developments, the movie tightens up a bit and things begin to happen. Again I will caution the reader that your ability to go with the flow and accept the premises of the movie is vital to its enjoyment.The almost constant thumping music background was a bit tiresome but if you have the ability to tune it out or enjoy that kind of music it may not bother you too much.If you enjoyed the most recent movie in the Transformer franchise you'll probably enjoy this one too. I was curious to see it but now that I have I'll probably not watch it again.

reviewText: This is one of those movies that entertains despite itself. The dialogue is awful, filled with bad one liners and cliches that make you think it was written by a couple of teens. The story is a bit contrived and characters are your basic action movie cookie cuter types, nothing new or innovative in this movie.However, that being said, I some how found a way to enjoy it. It did deliver on action scenes, and some nice special effects. The one thing that makes this movie enjoyable is that you have the navy fighting aliens. Using everything from hand guns to big guns on the ship.  Too often in Sci-fi movies the military is nothing but cannon fodder, or they are so stupid they do nothing but get in the way.  This movie lets the Navy battle it out, and I do appreciate that.  So yes, the movie is entertaining and sometimes that is all you want or need.

reviewText: I just watched Battleship. Oh wow, did I ever watch Battleship! Three times in a row to be exact,  and rewound to the most spellbinding authentic appearing and downright heart rending scenes too many times to count.After I invested my entire day with this BRILLIANT movie, I then went to Wikipedia to check on how it had done, etc. Well, folks, I was downright peeved. I still am! This movie did the WORST for a movie that cost what it did to produce. Are they NUTS whoever "they" are? I've had this on my wait list since I first learned of it - on the internet, by the way. Actually, via seeing a "drop" which is basically a 10 second commercial, on HULU likely, but I'm not sure. What I notice is this. I didn't see ANY other advertising for it - and wouldn't have located it had I not done my own searching for when it would be out.Now, with the movie industry making these massively costly boo boos for their box office, don't they get it? Don't they get the fact that most of us want to stay at home now and watch these newly released movies for MUCH less than going out to the theater and dropping a hundred bucks for all the concession nonsense as well as the cost of going? Look, film makers. We are in a real bad place here in the US financially, and yet these movies are still our outlet. Also, we who have a set income, have to limit our entertainment options - and there is much more now available via ROKU and the net. Heck, I haven't had cable for years since I found HULU. It rocks to have the option of watching what I want, when I want to watch it. Also, all the networks have gotten it apparently - because I can also watch CSI or whatever - and when I wish, via their website. Who, in the world, doesn't know this now? I don't know anyone.Back to BATTLESHIP! My point is simple. This movie is exceptional, as is another movie by the star, Taylor Kitsch who appears in this one - John Carter the movie. It didn't do well at all either - and I just happened on it. On Amazon, of course, and you should buy it too! You won't be sorry. So, all you who are making the mistake of paying any attention to other than what folks are sharing in this forum? Get over it and WATCH THIS MOVIE. BUY THIS MOVIE! BUY BATTLESHIP, pop some popcorn, get some Kit-Kats at Walmart and have fun! Be prepared to be proud of the USA. We are the greatest country on this earth...well, the best of the worst anyway! Anyway, Battleship is absolutely worth it. Now, I think I'm going to watch it again!! Be well, all of you.
summary: All I can say is WOW

reviewText: I'm not saying this is the absolute WORST movie ever produced, but it's in the running for sure.Let's start with "kids" that run the entire United States Navy, and on top of that...... NONE of those kids can act!!Just awful attempts at acting, and the story is ridiculous, but not as ridiculous at the solutions.Not one person connected to this film could have EVER, EVER been in the military because not one thing, nor one bit of the language is correct in this piece of junk film. From the space-ships that do the "BREAST-STROKE" in the ocean, to the WWII battle ship in storage for 60 years that starts right up, and still heavily equipped with weapons and fuel, goes into action in an hour of prep to save the world in ways that you simply shake your head and ask yourself, if this was a middle school film project.Words defy communicating how bad the acting really is with almost no exceptions, and the main woman that is a "personnel coach" that is saving the world is almost the worst I've ever seen except for the 19 year old kid that becomes the captain of the ship. (That's right the pentagon, or heads of state, or military can't do us any good, but a "personnel coach" does the trick) OMG!!To be a good film....please...TRY to have something in it that is worth watching, and not this terrible, awful collection of outright foolishness.

reviewText: An alien ship lands in the middle of the ocean and the kind of damage it does while at sea is so ludicrous that it defies logic. The attempt to convert a board game into a movie is so contrived that no matter how hard I try to suspend my disbelief and accept the story for its worth - I can't get over how illogical and how stupid these aliens are. I mean after watching so many good alien invasion movies (War of the World) and some that aren't so good (Independence Day), even the not-so-good ones had a logical premise to it. This one does not. Furthermore watching Rihanna act is like watching an amateur on a high-school stage. Liam Neeson choose poorly in involving himself in this crud of a movie - and giving it 1 star is really being nice - it should be a -1 star.

reviewText: If one were to judge from the previews then one would conclude that "Battleship" was a summer popcorn movie and nothing else and I'm not going to dissuade you of that belief because "Battleship" is indeed a summer popcorn movie and it functions well as one. On the surface level "Battleship" is equally good as "Transformers" and is in fact quite a bit better than "GI Joe: The Rise of Cobra" in the great lexicon of Hasbro movies.However there are a few bright shining moments in this movie that are worth seeing, I don't want to ruin them for you and I'm sure there are plenty of other reviewers that will happily do so, but let's just say that "Chicken Burrito" is a very good catch phrase for those that have seen this movie. In addition I was happy that Director Peter Berg took 10 or 15 minutes from the film to actually try to make the movie seem relevant to the board game. I recommend giving this movie a rent because you might find yourself pleasantly surprised like I was.
summary: It's nice to be surprised by a movie now and then

reviewText: Perhaps my expectations were too high for this movie after seeing the trailer, but I was disappointed by this movie.  The special effects were really good, on par with the Transformers movies.  And the basic premise of an alien race invading Earth was okay.  I found the biggest drag on the movie to be the lead actor, Taylor Kitsch, as Alex Hopper.  His role as the screwup Naval Officer was eye-rolling bad.  Where a more accomplished actor may have been able to take the role and make the audience root for him, he had me disliking the character for the whole movie.  Unfortunately, I had forgotten that this actor was also the lead in the John Carter movie.  There were, however, other actors in the movie that did really well in their roles, which saved this movie for me. I also liked the twist at the end, when they went "old school".  I would say that this movie will be enjoyed by teens and people who like their movies big, loud, and with lots of CGI action.  If that's not your cup of tea, I'd wait for a special deal on this movie.

reviewText: So I went to the Midnight showing last night...and it was OK.  I did not want to race out and see it again, I may never rent it (although Alexander Skaarsgaard sure was pretty).  So why 4 Stars? (Possible Spoilers after this, not that much in this movie is a Surprise)This movie did do a couple things really right from a sentimental point of view.  I am unabashedly a Pearl Harbor Patriot.  I own all the books on it and I cry at all the movies, and when I go an visit I am just a MESS!  I cry big cry, not little tears.  So I LOVED that they referenced the Veterans in this movie.I also loved that they had someone portraying a double amputee injured serviceman, and they did not make him someone you felt sorry for, thought it was great that they showed that he was still able to be a warrior.  That was FANTASTIC, and nice to see.The next thing I loved was and here is the Spoiler - last chance - that they made use of the Veterans that worked on the USS Missouri.  I loved them showing that just because people age, they are still useful, due to the knowledge they had.  Also - I loved that the Missouri opened up a huge can of whoop *ss on the aliens!!! Go Mighty MO!The other thing that I thought was great historically was being at Pearl Harbor and having us work with a Japanese captain to save the world.  It showed how far we have come since 1940's and our perspective and relations.So as you can tell for completely Sappy reasons, I gave this 4 Stars and not 5 because of the rest of the film which I will get into now.See it on the big screen because the cinematography awesome.  No way will your home theater due it justice, especially the panoramic ocean views.  I would go to a Matinee rather than full price.It was such a cliched story line with my exceptions above - super smart hot guy who is a bit of a screw up and enlists to straighten out, but then he is still a screw up that puts himself first, and is very selfish.  Let's his buddies down by being a "Top Gun" in his own mind.  Then (SPOILER) his brother dies (dang it, he is reason I went to see movie)  and conveniently every person with rank above him and he is thrust into being a Captain.  He still is thinking of only himself, but someone snaps him out of it and he starts leading - blah blah blah - pretty trite.They tried, but the dialog was just not as snappy or clever as was intended, and my biggest gripe - the inconceivability that they let his ship continue to exist!  So these super smart aliens have these awesome destructive balls that wipe out freeway overpasses and get rid of all the helicopters, yet they continue to let his ship float.  Just stupid.So with all that said, I enjoyed all the big blow em up stuff and effects - the aliens were morons for not killing off our tragic hero and Rhianna from the get go. Rhianna did ok - it was nice that they did not try to put her in a bikini or anything, and she did alright as a tough girl.  I would watch it at a Matinee if I knew then what I know now, and I would not purchase it on dvd/blu ray - because it just was not that great.  I liked it for totally sappy reasons that might not hold for everyone.On the other hand my Dad LOVED it - but he is secretly a 12 year old boy ;).
summary: Basic Cookie Cutter Blockbuster with a couple nice notes

reviewText: The graphics and premise were fine. Some will say how unbelievable the story line is, but they are wrong. They are always making assumptions. For example, some complain aliens couldn't have received the signal and got here in the time allotted. However, they don't know if our signal was intercepted by their equipment that is long off planet (like how we have tech that is floating to the outskits of our Solar System, or Mars) and then relayed by a much more advanced tech. They might have tech pretty close to us. Furthermore, those 5 ships could have been send from one of their outposts that are much closer to us. Anyways, just a couple ways to explain what the wannabe's can't comprehend.Some will complain that the aliens tech was not advanced enough. Well, we are sending tech to Mars and we are having to cross our fingers during the landing. Any race, any where, is going to have tech that is simply as advanced as they've taken it to date. People are just assuming because they are flying to another planet that their tech must be the ultimate of all tech ever imagined.And some more will complain how "what went down" didn't make sense when seen from the perspective of alien tech. They assume that because the aliens avoided non threatening humans that they must be here for peaceful purposes. However, if you are actually paying attention, you'll see the aliens are the aggressors from (even before) the beginning. Why did they avoid non threatening humans? Well, let's see. If humans were going to a new planet to take as their home, and there was food running around on it, would you kill all the food as soon as you got there?Just not so. These are usually childish little boys who only see or miss what they expected, and don't give a rats hiney about reality.Hi ArthurAll in all this movie was just okay. I can't comprehend how a studio can spend so much money then have such failures in their dialog. Of course - this could all be the editor's fault. The dialog could have been better, but this move was not about the dialog. I think the lead was a miscast. That guy is just not a good fit for a (any) lead role.The redeeming features of the film were seeing the old battleship in action (sure it wouldn't have had live artillery or been able to work, but really, who cares?), seeing a new type of alien and their tech. I'd like to give it 2.5 stars, but I don't regret giving it 3 stars. I'd say for sure RENT not buy. I hadn't seen a new movie in a while and this was not available for rent so I bought it for like $17 (pent of desire to see a new action flick) and I can honestly say I regret that. I wouldn't have regretted it at 9.95, and definitely would not have regretted a rental.

reviewText: Where to start? I don't want to spoil it by revealing too much. Special effects are off the charts! Story line? Loser punk kid becomes the hero, aided by a 21st century crew of young fighting sailors, a retired heroic (real life) Army colonel, a cadre of 20th century fighting "old salts" and the "Mighty Mo"... A precious heirloom of American greatness combine to win the day in the face of impossible odds. You will cheer at the cleverness that won the fight(s). You will form a bond with these characters. I have to abandon the critical thinking that one engages in during his 2nd, 3rd, 4th viewing in order to rate it for the first time viewer. If military action movies against aliens on the high seas are up your tree, you'll blow a gasket once the action starts. If not, you might just become an enthusiast for the military action movie on the high seas against aliens! The morphing process is painless!

reviewText: There are holes here you could fly a giant space alien star cruiser through. Taylor Kitsch as a doofus screwup slacker who within a short span of time becomes a naval officer who is still a screwup who becomes a brilliant hero guy. (I must admit, I do not get Taylor Kitsch, who presided over another huge bomb this year, John Carter.) Transmissions to the stars that apparently travel faster than light. Invading space aliens who won't kill you unless their sensor thingies flash red instead of green. (Why not just kill everyone?) Aliens who can travel across space at faster than light who fight by using what's essentially old-fashioned artillery. A WWII battleship (the great Mighty Mo) brought to battle readiness within a few hours by several current naval personnel and a troop of old geezers, complete with shells and powder. My wife couldn't wait for this movie to be over, and I don't blame her.But having said all this, there are a few chuckles and thrills to be had. Think of it as a very wet Independence Day, out upon the ocean waves. Some good sci fi eye candy here. I thought the aliens were well done (except for their weird red light/green light thing.) And I did enjoy seeing the USS Missouri dish out hell to the alien mother ship.This is a movie for a 12-year-old boy; or the 12-year-old in us grownups.
summary: Lotsa holes and a bit of fun

reviewText: No one can deny that these film makers put their money on the screen. The CGI effects were eye-popping and many of the on-location physical sets were amazing, such as the scene when they first contact the alien vessel at sea. The stunt work was also impressive. As so many others have noted, please leave your brain at the door and simply enjoy it for what it is. That said, I did admire the writers for coming up with a refreshing take on the Aliens. In so may other films they are portrayed as slimy, insect-like monstrosities but these aliens are somewhat human-like and they exhibited qualities that defy the norm, such as their rescue mission to retrieve one of their crew members captured by the humans. Also, they were not mindlessly violent, such as the when the scientist encounters one is the communications shed - it lets him leave unharmed? I didn't see that coming. I also liked the fact that the film makers found a role for some disabled and retired veterans. Very cool. On the special features there a short clip of the woman who trained Rihanna to shoot weapons and move like a professional warrior, no disrespect to Rihanna but I was kind of wondering why they just didn't cast her.
summary: A roiling glorious mess with big guns and cool people

reviewText: After seeing "Battleship," the first thing I did was check IMDB to see if Michael Bay had directed, produced or written this lump of steaming, festering tripe.No, apparently Bay has fanboys who aspire to make the same kind of movies -- monstrous, overblown explosionfests that borderline fetishize the American military. Peter Berg isn't QUITE as bad as Bay, but that's like saying that a punch to the gut is less painful than a kick in the crotch. It may not be the worst, but you might still get serious damage.Our story follows slacker Alex Hopper (Taylor Kitsch), who robs a convenience store and gets tased by the police. Why? Because Sam Shane (Brooklyn Decker), daughter of Navy Admiral Shane (Liam Neeson), wanted a chicken burrito, and he was trying to impress the bimbo. Sadly, it works.His brother Stone (Alexander Skarsgrd) forces him to go into the Navy to get his life together, where Alex continues screwing up. In fact, he screws up so badly after a soccer game against the Japanese navy that Admiral Shane plans to kick him out. But for some reason, they allow him to command a ship in the RIMPAC, presumably so he can continue to embarrass the United States in front of the whole world.But the RIMPAC is interrupted when a group of alien ships arrive on Earth -- and suddenly Hawaii is sealed off by a giant forcefield, with only a few ships on the inside. And after his brother's ship is destroyed, Alex suddenly finds himself in command -- and must find a way to destroy the alien ships before a full-scale invasion can attack Earth.First, some faint praise. "Battleship" is not QUITE a bad as a Michael Bay movie, mainly because it doesn't have the blatant sexism and racism. And while Bay practically fetishizes the American military, director Peter Berg seems to have genuine admiration for our soldiers -- consider a moving subplot about a double-amputee soldier who fights the aliens despite his disability. Or the elderly veterans who appear to help destroy the alien ships.However...Everything else is Michael Bay fanfiction. Unfunny comic relief, idiotic dialogue ("He said we ain't alone. He said one day, either we'd find them, or they'd find us"), and prolonged scenes that are nothing but explosion after explosion after explosion. And in case you're wondering, the titular Battleship does not even appear until almost two hours into the movie.It also has the most pathetic aliens in film history. They look pretty cool when they have their helmets on, but underneath they're grunting goat/ape hybrids, and they invaded a planet that they cannot tolerate. Oh, and their spaceships are so fragile that they fragment when they hit a stationary satellite, and they have easily-shattered GLASS for windows.And for some reason, Berg seems to believe that the Japanese and Americans working together is somehow surprising... even though the countries have been allies for decades. But hey, it briefly allows a COMPETENT commander to take over the American warship.When elderly, real-life Navy veterans are able to out-act a cast of actual actors... you're in trouble.  Taylor Kitsch's Alex is possibly the least likable "hero" I have ever seen in a movie -- he's a hotheaded, selfish child-man who values his own revenge over the life of his crew. The only reason he ever succeeds at ANYTHING is because other people implement his ideas.Pop singer Rihanna has the acting talents of a log, and Liam Neeson's contemptuous (and brief) performance practically screams, "I'm just doing this for the money, so please leave me alone." Actually, there is only one likable character in this whole mess: Tadanobu Asano as a Japanese naval captain who is competent, cool and smart. When he briefly replaces Kitsch as captain, nobody utters a peep of protest."Battleship" should have replaced the last letter with a T. Despite the respect it shows America's veterans, it's a Michael-Bay-style eruption of pure ineptitude -- so ignore this mess unless you have a lot of booze and friends who like to riff bad movies.

reviewText: I had such high hopes for this film based only on its trailer, forgetting that there might be some type of filler to contend with before and after the good stuff.I've since come to appreciate that there's filler and then there's pure dreck.  In the case of this movie, the first half hour is a slow torturous trek involving a silly bar scene, a case of breaking and entering, instant advancement in the Navy (apparently they will take anyone), a soccer game, occasional announcements to remind us that this is indeed a Sci-Fi flick (wait for it..........), plus a little pomp without the circumstances.  There was also an abbreviated romance tossed in for good measure, involving an idiot (Taylor Kitsch) who (as movie clichés would have it) likes to talk to himself in the mirror.  I clocked the amount of wasted time at 36 minutes before there was any sign of the pesky aliens.  At that point I was beginning to despair, was this a Lifetime movie about unrequited love?  I paid good money for aliens and battle scenes!I will admit, once the action finally started, it rarely let up and was almost worth the long wait.  The F/X was snazzy, the battles were frenetic, and the aliens fascinating (once unmasked).  But.  There was that extraordinarily long wait.  And for some strange reason, I thought this was Liam Neeson's film.  He was rarely to be seen and given precious little to do.  Instead, the apparent star of this feature was an unusually bland actor (Taylor Kitsch) who must think a perpetual scowl is the best form of emoting in any and all situations.  His lack of personality is astounding.At this point, I'm still debating whether to keep this for future viewings.  After all, there is the matter of storage.............

reviewText: When I sat down to watch Battleship, I did not have an open mind. A movie based on a board game? Well, it worked for Clue, and it almost works for Battleship. The acting is pretty mild, despite having the powerhouse Liam Neeson (though he makes us smile at the end of the film). The whole time I was sitting there going "where's the gimmick?". And when it revealed itself, I laughed a lot. But it worked.One thing that really impressed me was the cast of Navy veterans that brought their guns to blaze for the climax of the film. It brought a sense of realism to any otherwise FX-happy producers. The bonus features aren't anything to write home about, but the cast and crew seemed to really enjoy their time in the film.All in all, if you enjoy the 'end of the world' flicks like 2012, Armageddon, the Core, or any of that, you'll probably enjoy Battleship. Just don't forget to turn off your brain and grab the popcorn. And if not, I'd still advise viewers to stick around for the climax - once there, the ride makes up for most of the short comings prior.In other words, it rocks to boat. Apologies for the weak pun.
