reviewText: 2012 already racked up a few blockbuster box office disasters. Many times the failure to bring in the audiences and money studios expected is warranted. Other times it's a lack of promotion and unexpected disinterest in the project. One of the films I was hard on before I saw it was "Battleship." I'm glad I got another chance to see it on Blu-ray now that it's coming out through Universal Studios Home Entertainment.It appeared Hasbro and Universal were just trying to cash in on the success of the "Transformers" and G.I. Joe" movies. Could lightning strike three times and another one of their other popular lines garner as much attention? The dismal domestic box office numbers answered that question with a loud, "Not in America!" The negative response to the film gave a whole new meaning to the famous phrase, "You sank my Battleship!"Naval officer Alex Hopper (Taylor Kitsch) is assigned to the USS John Paul Jones after being forced to join the military by his older brother who also serves. When the Earth is attacked by alien forces, a fleet of battleships are sent to engage them. They must also thwart the aliens' plans to send a message to their home planet seeking reinforcements.Writers Jon and Erich Hoeber and director Peter Berg should be commended for at least attempting to give "Battleship" a story the audience could identify with. A couple of the characters are developed enough to where we care what happens to them. Unfortunately, most of the supporting cast is just warm bodies propped up for looks or to fire guns or push buttons.The visual effects and CGI in the movie look good. One of the most impressive scenes is when one of the battleships goes down. It's reminiscent of the sinking of the Titanic in James Cameron's hit; just with way more explosions. The aliens aren't the usual lizard-like type we've been seeing lately. They are humanoid and uniquely creepy.I feel sorry for Taylor Kitsch after seeing this movie. The guy can act and did his best in both "Battleship" and "John Carter." The movies definitely didn't fail at the box office because of his performances. Liam Neeson is completely wasted in the film. He is onscreen a total of 15 minutes. He goes between looking like he cares and appearing indifferent. I'm not sure why Rihanna is in the movie. Why go to all the trouble to get a famous singer in your movie and then waste her character? She has hardly any lines and just blows stuff up while looking tough.The main problem with "Battleship" is it gets tedious. The excitement of ships shooting at each other in the water only lasts so long. A feeling of repetition hit me about an hour into the film.One thing I'll give the writers is credit for coming up with ingenious ways to use the different concepts from the game. The red pegs were utilized in the film as alien missiles. The crew also had to guess where the ships were in the water through eliminating areas on a visual computer graph.The high definition transfer of the movie is excellent. The picture is clear and the colors are vibrant. The 5.1 surround sound throws explosions and sound effects at you from all directions. They're excellently mixed with the dialogue and musical score. There are plenty of special features to get consumers excited.They include featurettes like "Preparing for Battle," "All Hands on Deck: The Cast," "Engage in Battle: Shooting at Sea" "All aboard the Fleet," "The Visual Effects of 'Battleship'," "USS Missouri VIP Tour," and "Commander Pete." An alternate ending previsualization is also included. We get all access with Peter Berg as well.Maybe the release of "Battleship" on Blu-ray and DVD will garner the attention of people who didn't want to fork over the cash to see the movie in theaters. Hopefully, they'll give it a chance in the comfort of their own home. Now that I've seen it, I realize what a spectacle I missed on the big screen and how unfair I was to judge a game by its box (I know, that was cheesy).

reviewText: Battleship is basically "Independence Day" vs. the U.S.  Navy.  A bunch of nerdy and cowardly scientists decide to broadcast a welcome towards a newly discovered planet with an atmosphere like Earth's.  This proves to be a rather poor idea when the aliens accept their welcome and decide to pay us a visit and conquer our planet.The aliens create a forcefield that traps 3 US Navy and one Japanese destroyer.  When the aliens destroy 3 out of the 4 ships, it is the crew of the final destroyer, John  Paul Jones, led by a young Lieutenant, (just about to be kicked out of the Navy for being an absolute jerk,) that figures out how to destroy them.  Since this takes place in Hawaii, the eventual plan involved taking the famous World War II Battleship the USS Missouri out to sea again, the crew consisting of sailors from the John Paul Jones and elderly naval veterans who served on the Missouri in WW II.  (For some reason, they are aboard the ship and are immediately ready for action.) Obviously, none of this makes any sense.  Also not making any sense is the hero of this film who, at the beginning, is an absolute jerk and loser.  He is forced by his naval officer brother to join the Navy and the next thing we know, he is now a young Naval Lieutenant.  (Does it really take such a short period of time to become an officer in the US Navy?)The reason to see this film are the action scenes and special effects, both of which are great.  Don't think about the plot, just have a good time as I did when I saw it in the movies.  (I must have been one of the few since the film was a giant flop.)The blu-ray includes several special features, many focusing on the film's enthusiastic director, Peter Berg.  The best special feature is a tour of the actual USS Missouri, currently dry-docked in Hawaii.  This is excellent and well-worth watching.  There are no deleted scenes although it does have  an "alternate ending previsualization" that wasn't done according to Berg because it was deemed too expensive.  There is also a totally unnecessary final scene at the end of the credits.  It really isn't worth waiting for unless you have nothing better to do.In conclusion, "Battleship" is a loud, explosive and exciting film.  It is a lot of fun if you don't take it too seriously.

reviewText: This was a fast, fun movie for light-hearted sci-fi fans. I thought it was pretty entertaining, and I was able to overlook some of the more questionable aspects of the plot (such as two dozen old timers being able to get an out of service battleship running in about an hour), because, after all... you really shouldn't take this movie too seriously. Think about it- it's based on a classic board game, and it's a tale about alien invaders doing battle with naval ships stationed in Hawaii. It was very clearly influenced by the Transformers formula, the big name in the Hasbro stable. I think kids and teenagers in particular will love this movie, but I'm 33, and I still had a good time watching it.The design and CGI execution of the alien war ships is positively awesome, the best I can remember ever having seen. Though the actual alien creature design is not particularly interesting or original, their machines are the real stars of the show. Major kudos to the CGI team that put this movie together, because the special effects are just incredible. Furthermore, these ships become engaged in a strategic battle with the US Destroyers that tastefully (and cleverly) pays homage to the board game after which this movie is (VERY LOOSELY) based.This movie is fun, and the special effects are super cool. Blu-ray transfer is spectacular, and it really pops off of the screen. The characters are charismatic, the plot moves fast, and the tension is convincingly conveyed throughout. I liked it- who would have ever thought that old board game could trigger this concept in somebody's mind? I applaud the creativity!
summary: Friday night fun, this is a creative take on the classic board game

reviewText: Let's cut to the chase: there is only one thing I liked about this flick: alien battleships. They were awesome! I wish they just spent the whole movie parading them around. They're done in the style of Transformers in a snazzy steely-blue/flaming-orange/red colour scheme. They are HUGE; they fly; they careen; they whoosh heavily into the ocean; they take off and plop back like Exocoetidae, heavily; they shapeshift, and, with heavy clangour and rumble, unfurl multiple batteries of a sort of flaming mitrailleuse-minewerfern, launching lethal barrages of sort of beercans that fly in high-arched trajectory over the battlefield and burrow into the target before blowing up to the ucking skies; wow, these alien ships were awesome -- I couldn't get enough of these wonderful alien ships. If I could run into one in real life, that'd be too exciting for words.Now, the rest: overlong; dragging (first 30 mins nothing happens, annoying); cliched throughout; unbearable expansive, sprawling Hollywood score that never shuts up; plot unoriginal in the extreme. Aliens themselves are far less impressive than their ships: they basically are misshapen fugly big humans with four fingers and two opposing thumbs, with snake eyes; that's all. They're very strong, but not so superiour that you couldn't deal with them; and their weapons are kind of like cannons, so where's the big deal, they're aliens after all, where's super nuclear ray weapons that are making enemy annihilate w/o him noticing it. Why do they throw high explosives just like our boys? Their ships, once again, are awesome and sexy, but the rest of their accoutrements are underwhelming. They walk around in metallic Swiss-army-knife scaphandres sort of thing: come on, Ahnie looked better in Terminator twenty years ago. He also talked funny -- these dudes don't. Or take Predators, they were also better. There's a number of participants whose parts are nominal, like Liam Neeson. What's he doing here? He has a five-minute, ten words role. Probably wanted to expedite payments on his new car or something... he was there but he wasn't there. "Pretty girl" personage, same thing, no role, and to be honest, while she was tall and blond, she wasn't all that pretty. Come on. Diversity: oh yeah, diversified up to wazoo in the new Hollywood fashion. Heroic African-American: check; comic (in intent, not reality) dweeby scientist who's cowardly but when needed finds courage: check, etc. What else? Nothing really... you've seen it all a billion times before. The whole affair is fundamentally boring. You only feel good when there's alien ships on screen, otherwise it's like, where's my remote, let's FF a few minutes while they're doing nothing worthwhile till maybe there's more alien ships heaving in from under the water.Long story short: it's a twaddly and overlong Fourth of July cum Transformers. It's not what you'd call "BAD". It's just very, very mediocre (except for the alien ships! these are awesome, and you'll want them to bear your children). I would recommend that if you decide to watch it, watch it like you watch pr0n: ff to the alien ships, let them do whatever (whoosh, splash, rumble, etc); once it's over, FF to the next alien-ship scene. You'll be done in... um... about 20-30 mins and then you can turn the movie off.
summary: Worthless twaddle. Cool alien battleships though.

reviewText: There are some movies that just want to entertain you. This is one of them. It has no geopolitical pretenses, no higher motives, no highfalutin' ambitions. It's fun, it's got great CGI, and yet there's moments that are genuinely striking, particularly in the relationship between the layabout leading man and the Japanese captain who helps him after the fecal matter hits the circulating air device. As a matter of fact, I found that relationship kind of touching, given the respectful way the Japanese were treated throughout the film, as allies.  I also liked that the crew reflected something of Hawaii's racial mix in its population, and that the sarcastic cameraderie of the military was captured in much of its scatalogical glory. And most wonderful of all was the performance of an actual Army vet in a major, unforgettable role as the amputee who needed something to fight for after a lifetime of service.I have to say the weakest link was a froth-spitting Alexander Skaarsgaard,  whose entire performance in this movie seemed to consist of humorless pill or goggle eyed cannon fodder, but that's the way I've found him in so many other things. I'm biased in favor of his father, and with good reason.The movie starts out with an absolutely hysterical exercise in comic excess, as Hopper, the lead character, tries to impress a pretty girl in a bar. You'll never look at another chicken burrito again, and Taylor Kitsch shamelessly milks the comedy from every last second of it. What's surprising is that she's the daughter of an Admiral, and she's very much the love interest, but not in the family business. It's the one kind of disappointing decision in the movie, especially seeing as how the actress gamely makes as much of the role as she can, given that there's not much there. (Having Rihanna around, nailing her lines with attitude and relish doesn't help her, either.) Speaking of Rihanna, she's both bad ass and funny consistently the way through, whether saying, "Maholo, (word that refers via obscenity to Oedipus' improper relationship with his mother)", or spanking a Japanese rival in soccer on the bootie and saying, "C'mon, princess."The heroism of the lead character isn't black and white or anything, either: it's flawed and stubborn and based on bad decisions, but he listens to wiser voices, whatever their rank, and manages to save lives and eventually redeem himself, in some rather touching scenes. (Even if, as I am, an Army vet and not a Navy one.) The chemistry between the characters enlivens almost all of the dialogue and interaction, and while most of the actors were relative unknowns,(at least to me and with the exception of Neeson and Rihanna) they commanded the screen and gave the movie a richness of personality you just wouldn't expect. The name actors----Skarsgaard and Neeson-----were outplayed by the many small roles filled with actors who made the very most of their short time on the screens. It was a delightful surprise.There's some surprising emotional heft to the movie due to the absolute rightness of some of the way the director "got" the way soldiers, sailors, Marines, Air Force, and Coast Guard will nag and fight among themselves and then practically kill themselves to save a fellow the very next minute if one of their brethren come under fire.Now on to the bad: the plot, and....the plot. Yeah,  this is just a big dumb action movie, but it never pretended to be anything but, and yet its actors gave it their all, and that's why I'd watch a sequel unquestioningly if the same personnel were involved.All in all, great fun.
summary: A good old fashioned fun movie without pretenses

reviewText: Is it worth watching? Yes. It's fun, lot's of action and plenty of eye candy.  However, don't expect a movie with a lot of depth or that makes a lot of sense.  Very loosely based on the board game and I do mean loosely.  It has the underdog character who starts off as a screw-up and rises to the occasion and becomes the hero.  You have the cripple that has given up and then finds new reason to fight etc...  You've seen it all before in films like Independence Day, but that didn't make it any less fun to watch.  One thing that stood out at me was how much the film tried to be another Top Gun movie for the Navy and I'm sure the Navy was hoping for that as well, but I thought they tried too hard and fell a little short.  It's not a film I would necessarily pay to see in the theaters, but as a rental flick definitely.
summary: A Fun Kick Alien Butt/Go Navy Movie

reviewText: This review is for the Blu-Ray only. The other discs will never be watched by me. What a waste. How about 1 Blu-Ray disc only & 3-$5.00 off the cost. Why would you want to watch this on Dvd on a 20" computer screen or a Lap Top. What's the point. The Blu-ray is very nice for this film. I have no desire to watch the Dvd again after seeing this on Blu-Ray. I am glad they have it in the 2:40:1 screen ratio. This is the only way to watch this movie. You see everything the Director saw. The Audio is pretty good I think, although I just listen through my stereo speakers. Probably really nice with a good sound system. This has some really good Special Features too. They are: Alternative ending {which is computerized - they do this to see if they like it & before spending millions of dollars to shoot it}: Commentary: U.S.S. Missouri {VIP Tour} - this is really nice - What a monster the Battleship was: Preparing for Battle: All Hands on Deck {The Cast}: Engage in Battle: Commander Pete {Real life Commander}: The Visual Effects {Really nice stuff}. This is one of the best Special Features I've seen on any Blu-Ray disc. Really good !!!!! Get the Blu-Ray if you have the Dvd or if you haven't seen it yet. I think you will enjoy it. Very entertaining.

reviewText: This movie was panned by the critics, so I figured it might be fun to watch. And unless you're a military-hating type who only loves movies that show soldiers as suicidal, wife-beating druggies, this should be fun for you, too."Terrible script", they said. Well, this isn't Henry V. It's a movie based on a Hasbro game, fer Pete's sake, so lose those snobbish pretensions at the door. The dialogue us mostly appropriate for the characters and the situation. It's not Plato. It's action and heartstrings. And this it does well. It's touching, stirring, and exciting. There are character arcs, albeit predictable.Does everything make sense? Mostly. There are things which are strange, such as the aliens' risk assessment algorithm. You'll just have to buy that, although it can be rationalized. Can a hothead like the hero become a captain, then be kicked out? Hmmm. Hard to believe.But it does feel good to see Americans and Japanese working together to save the world. You get to see the classic game translated to the movies, in a pretty clever way. There's lots of action, and well-shot, not like the crappy shaky-camera work in the Bourne movies. You'll like the characters. And you will tear up when the Missouri goes back into action with a geriatric crew.Go and see it wanting to have a good time at the movies instead of the artsy claptrap the critics love, and you'll be OK.I'd give it 3.5 stars. I have to explain this because I gave Saving Private Ryan four stars, too, for some perceived flaws. Yes, maybe I should have given it five, but I've messed up my own rating system, so ... anyway, it succeeds for what it's supposed to be.

reviewText: "You sank my BATTLESHIP!!" is what each suit at Universal Studios is yelling at the cast and crew. While the film had better success overseas and even though it's on the verge of tallying a global sum of over 300 million, I guess it's all about how it performs domestically. In part you have to factor in that THE AVENGERS ate up much of the box office gross. In part you have to look at the flaws within BATTLESHIP because, to drop some sea slang, not all the hatches were battened down.BATTLESHIP is this generation's INDEPENDENCE DAY, except that Taylor Kitsch doesn't come near to matching Will Smith's palpable cool and charisma. Taylor Kitsch, more accurately, strives to Tom Cruise his way thru the movie, except that he also doesn't generate Cruise's swagger. On the other hand, Kitsch does make for a perfectly serviceable lead hero.***PLOT SPOILERS from now on***He plays 26-year-old slacker Alex Hopper, and Alex is an epic screw-up. His latest scrape - breaking into a convenience store to present a fine chick (Brooklyn Decker) with a chicken burrito she'd been craving - results in his arrest and his fed-up naval officer bro (Alexander Skarsgard) issuing an ultimatum: enlist in the U.S. Navy or dot dot dot...But before all that, BATTLESHIP actually opens up with yet one more exploration into hubris, as we're made privy to the Beacon Project, a deep space endeavor which hinges on our scientists' transmitting a constant signal to a newly discovered and possibly habitable planet somewhere in the far reaches of the universe.In the Navy, some years later, Alex Hopper has found a home, has found a girl (in fact, the same girl, hot burrito babe). He's ascended to the rank of Lieutenant and is the Tactical Action Officer on the destroyer, the John Paul Jones. Only, the screw-up is never too far from the surface, and Hopper finds the most inopportune time to bollocks it all up. He is madly in love with the burrito girl - okay, her name is Samantha - and he intends to ask her father's permission to marry her, never mind that Sam is the daughter of the very intimidating fleet admiral (Liam Neeson). Except that Hopper falls back to bad habits. It starts when Hopper and Sam wake up late for a naval ceremony on board the 70-year-old museum relic, the U.S.S. Missouri. From there, for Hopper, it downspirals.The U.S. fleet is currently undergoing naval exercises several miles off Oahu, a joint venture which includes the Japanese Navy, and I think this very convenient happenstance pops up just so Hopper can spark a heated rivalry against a brash Japanese officer (Tadanobu Asano) and bring about Hopper's career-ending snafu. Hopper's most recent conduct unbecoming is the final straw; he's informed that when his ship pulls into port, he'll be drummed out of the service.So, thank goodness for the alien attack.If you're that one person who'd been clamoring for a film adaptation of Hasbro's great game of strategy, my friend, this is your moment. You, more than most, will likely appreciate the film's nods to the classic board game, from giant exploding pegs to the mimicry of the board game itself, thanks to a sneaky strategy that calls for a plot chart superimposed on a grid of weather buoys. I was surprised at how much I got into it during that combat sequence.3.5 out of 5 stars for BATTLESHIP, and I didn't think I'd be that generous. You know what you're walking into: a summer blockbuster that is mindless but fun, garish but visually flawless. It's commercially calculated. The dialogue is by the numbers. There's perfunctory attention given to character development. I mean, check out Hopper's sweeping trajectory: our lead guy goes from a B & E at a convenience store to suddenly commanding his own vessel.Hopper doesn't have time to contemplate his recent knucklehead blunders. Four alien spacecrafts have just plummeted into the Pacific waters. An impenetrable bubble barrier 300,000 feet in altitude and 2 nautical miles deep has just surrounded and isolated three destroyers from the naval exercises. I think that was Tokyo that was crapp'd on just now. Hopper, Petty Officer Cora 'Weps' Raikes (Rihanna), and some expendable red shirt approach one alien ship. And is it just me or were the alien ships pretty passive until the humans started messing about? Anyway, Hopper's little scouting party causes the alien craft to launch hellacious ordinance on the destroyers. And before you can say "bonehead boo-boo," massive casualties and the time-honored chain of command have left Hopper as senior officer onboard the John Paul Jones. This doesn't instill much confidence in what's left of his crew.The acting won't bowl you over. Liam Neeson sleepwalks thru his role. But I thought Rihanna's stunt casting actually worked out okay. And real-life war veteran and double amputee Gregory D. Gadson, as the recovering, tough-as-nails Lt. Colonel Mick Canales, exudes a solid presence. That doesn't imply that I savored his scenes with Brooklyn Decker and Hamish Linklater (who takes on the requisite nerd scientist Jeff Goldblum role). It feels to me like the film wanted to retain the eye candy factor and was looking for a plot thread to feature Decker. She, Gadson, and Linklater get tapped with having to take out the Oahu-based satellite substation before the alien ships can signal for reinforcements.I liked BATTLESHIP, despite its plot holes wide enough for a naval fleet to steer thru. It met my expectations (which weren't very high), and even exceeded them in certain areas (for one thing, it's funnier than I thought it would be). In my opinion, director Peter Berg makes his film more charming and likable than Michael Bay's 'bots in disguise franchise. Half an hour into it, I found myself onboard with the ridiculous shenanigans. I thought the aliens came off meaner than the Chitauri (this is a good thing). And, it turns out, one cheesy moment doubles as a neat moment when, late in the game, Hopper gets unexpected support in the shape of a crew of old timers. Cue the Mighty Mo, and cue the ACDC track. I think Peter Berg should take on Scrabble next. Or Boggle. Or Hungry Hungry Hippos.If you care about that sort of stuff, stick around for the post-credits scene.

reviewText: Yes, they made a full length movie based off a children's board game that had no plot whatsoever.  Yes, it sounds crazy, and leads to endless jokes about how desperate for ideas Hollywood must be if they resort to board games for film ideas (can a "Hungry Hungry Hippos" movie be heading our way in the near future?).  Yet, despite all the odds, we have a genuine Battleship movie that is decisively not bad, but actually pretty good.The movie follows Alex Hopper, a brilliant but lazy guy who spends his days drinking, and slacking out on his brother's couch.  After a fiasco involving a gal and a chicken burrito, Alex finds himself in the navy, and facing the fight of his life, as several alien ships land during a war games exercise.  Thus, both sides engage in a deadly game of deceit and combat, with the fate of the world at stake.Considering how plot less the original board game was, the filmmakers deserve a lot of credit for creating a story that doesn't get bogged down with exposition or in-depth attempts to explain things, instead going for the Michael Bay approach:  Lots and lots and lots of explosions, firearms getting shot off, big visual effects, aliens, and more explosions.  And amazingly, it works.  The movie knows it's entire existence is silly in the first place, and runs with it (at one point, the aliens and humans literally play battleship with each other, in the manner of the game itself).  The story, while simple, does move along briskly, and never lags, ensuring that the viewer is never bored, and while the characters are a bit stereotyped, they're entertaining enough to watch, and Alex, though burdened with the traditional, "smart but lazy guy who has to grow and reach his true potential" plot, serves well as the film's protagonist.  Equal recognition must be given to Mick, a double-amputee soldier who helps contribute to the fight against the aliens, and is a delight to watch, as we rarely see amputees getting their own action sequences.Surprisingly, there are some unexpected moments of greatness here:  The aliens themselves, while clearly not friendly, don't go around killing everyone in sight, which gives them a fascinating moral side.  I also loved how the battleship of the movie's title comes into play, and it's role in the fight against the aliens, and is easily the most entertaining part of the film.Still, for action and nice touches, "Battleship" is essentially the standard blockbuster entertainment: it deals in broad strokes with story and characters, and relies heavily on action scenes to keep the audience's interest.  I do wish there were scenes where the entire naval fleet engaged in combat, rather then just a few ships, and Liam Neeson is criminally underused, but as a whole, "Battleship" is an entertaining surprise that works perfectly as harmless, B-grade movie fun.  Not bad for a film based on a plot less board game.
summary: I can't believe I'm saying this...but it's actually pretty good

reviewText: Get a beer and popcorn and prepare to step into the pure adventure of earth, once again, being invaded by a powerful and dangerous enemy from who knows where and who knows why they are here. But, if you have seen a dozen other sci-fi films over the last forty odd years, you will know the pattern: the creatures are ugly as a dead rooster laying in the Alabama sun, th lovely gals will be thrust into positions of power and influence and do a mighty fine job, the lowly underlings will toss out a few good one-liners and act terrified but come through for the heroic officer who must figure out the gooners weakness and save this planet. Lots of fun, some obvious 'this ain't gonna work', resilient and reluctant combatants, lots of flaming gigantic spaceships, a seemingly doomed earth.We don't know who and what the aliens are about. But who cares? We figure out (with the visual assistance of dozens of other films) that the creatures want to take over Earth and will stop at nothing to do so. Some pretty nice effects which don't dominate the film as much as I thought they would. Some stiff acting but the action takes up the slack and leads our soggy heroes to toe to toe combat with the Russkies, er, make that aliens with the aid of Might Mo, guns a blazin'. This film is mindless and mirthful for a couple of hours as you take the salt water stained decks and full speed ahead, cutlasses sharpened and load and run out the guns. Mix some old WWII battleship vets and AC/DC then blend in aliens and their fiendish weapons of destruction, toss in some missiles, some sarcastic comments and presto, you have this movie.Yahoo, go for it. There are and have been plenty of worse 'let's conquer the earth' films.Five sixteen point one inch shells for this baby and nice AC-DC song near the end that rocks.
summary: Kinda predictable but lots of surprises too - Aliens vs US Navy

reviewText: I was in no rush to see BATTLESHIP knowing it was based on the Hasbro game and it had not been well-received by the critics or public. I did not know the story and imagined battleships fighting each other on the high sea. BATTLESHIP became a must see when I saw that lovely, sexy singer Rihanna was one of the stars. Rihanna? In an action film? Really? It was worth a look.BATTLESHIP is off to a slow start. A troubled loser with no future joins the Navy as a last resort. Despite his bad attitude, he shows potential and moves up in rank. Is any of this a surprise? How about the fact that he is in love with the admiral's daughter. Any surprise there? Our hero butts heads with all of his superiors and is about to be thrown out of the navy when it happens...Scientists have discovered a planet that seems to be in the right position from its own sun to be a twin of earth. Maybe life exists so signals are sent from earth to this distant planet to make contact. Here was the huge twist from what I expected. What happens if the aliens receive the signal and decide to come visit their "brothers" on earth?Suddenly, BATTLESHIP has some potential as the alien spaceships are seen. Here come in the amazing visual effects and possibly an interesting story. Are the aliens here as friends or conquerors? What are their intentions. At first it seems they are interested in destroying machinery and not out to destroy humans. There is a bit of confusion here. The US Navy fires first and maybe our alien friends are just in self-defense mode. The visual effects are amazing and we get to see human-like aliens. How would life develop on a "sister" planet light years away. It is an interesting premise.Unfortunately, amazing visual effects can't always save a film riddled with clichés. BATTLESHIP is a combination of so many films we have seen before. It's part JURASSIC PARK and INDEPENDENCE DAY. Add in Pearl Harbor since the on land part of the story takes place on Oahu with a connection to Pearl Harbor and the Japanese are involved again (as the good guys) attacking Oahu.Apparently, the director thought Rihanna would be good in the role of a sailor and she was eager to do a movie role. It's hard to imagine Rihanna as a sailor helping to save the world but the woman is talented. I guess she could help save the world.BATTLESHIP misses so much of its potential. Why not have the aliens come with a clear message. What do they want? We learn they have one problem with life on earth. There always has to be one simple problem that aliens can't cope with on earth.The movie drags on. The beautiful daughter of the admiral obviously will have some role in helping to save the world while her navy man is at sea. Lian Neeson is the admiral and suprisingly this is a relatively small role for Neeson. Maybe he needed the work.BATTLESHIP is worth seeing because of the phenomenal special effects but if a good story is important you, this is a film that can be missed.
summary: PROMISING IDEA LOST IN A SEA OF CLICHÉS

reviewText: Except for the zazzy special effects, I can see why this was the lowest-grossing Hollywood film of 2012 (followed by Transformers: Dark of the Moon). You see, you got a total slacker who doesn't know how to grow up, living with his Marine brother, and now has to join the Marine, yet it seems like he's been in it for some time as it is (and with no indication of any length of time passing by for him to get promoted, and it's impossible for it to have happened so quickly), and during the Marine's own battle game on the sea, some transmission sent out to a distant planet back in '06 has a few spaceships coming to Earth. They use their superior technology to create a lifelike board game, destroying everything that threatens violence at it (and then some on land).There really seemed to be nothing for me in this film worth enjoying beyond the special effects (as I said before), its script, for the most part, was cookie-cutter and unrealistic. Some of the characters seem to come up with some random bit of helpful info just out of nowhere without prelude. Not to mention the aliens their selves, look entirely laughable (like parts of the script, too laughable for me to enjoy thoroughly), and I guess they had budget cuts on their own currency if their own technology can't come up with better sound effects when they detect some threat.Then are certain soldiers that don't act like the real deal- like they don't have a mind to think with in the most common sensical ways. And a death scene presented just did not have the emotional substance for me to shed a tear, it simply felt like they tried too hard to yank the tears out, and failed.Really, Hasbro, did you learn nothing from Michal Bay's abysmal interpretation of Transformers? The special effects may be cool, but they don't replace substantial story and characterization (especially when a character breaks in to a convenience store, keeps looking into the camera, and does not seem to care he keeps breaking law after law), and not all scientists talk like the cardboard thin scientist who apparently represents those who think people with artificial replacements are "cyborgs" (that did bother me, and I have no replacements, I thought it unscientific and not humorous). Remember that for the next toy/board game/overall game you decide to popularize into a mainstream movie, because this is getting old.

reviewText: It's a harmless summer action film that wasn't as horrible as the critics and dilettante cineastes would lead you to believe.  Some variation on the SETI Project has been trying to communicate with the Gliese 581 star system, and the response to those calls is a small invasion force that cordons off Hawaii in a force field to test our potential response to a full-scale invasion.  The aliens just happened to pick the time when the annual RIMPAC naval war games are being conducted, and although the vast majority of the US Pacific Fleet and several other nations are on the outside, it's ultimately up to the Aegis destroyer USS John Paul Jones and its screwup tactical action officer Alex Hopper to save the world after all the other ships trapped inside the force field and all of Hawaii's bases are summarily massacred in the first encounter.Its affiliation withthe board gameis fleeting and 98% ancillary, and could've been left out altogether without anybody noticing: the only connections to it are that the invading aliens occasionally fire peg-shaped munitions, and the only time they call out the letter-number sequences when shooting is after cobbling together a fire control method by overlaying NOAA map grids onto the tsunami warning buoy network because the aliens' ships don't appear on radar and the aliens themselves are so light-sensitive that they have to wear welder's masks in normal sunlight.  It's noMidwaybut it was nice to have a sea-based war movie pop up for once.
summary: You can relax; nobody says "you sank my [whatever]" in it

reviewText: It's aliens vs. the U.S. Navy in this fast-paced action movie.Stone Hopper (Alexander Skarsgard) is the captain of an Arleigh Burke-class destroyer.  His brother Alex (Taylor Kitsch) has no job and sleeps on Stone's couch.  One night after Alex embarasses himself trying to impress Samantha Shane (Brooklyn Decker), Stone informs his brother that he must join the Navy to learn some discipline.Fast-forward: Alex is now an officer aboard his own destroyer, the USS John Paul Jones.  He's still in love with Samantha, but she is the daughter of Vice-Admiral Shane (Liam Neeson), and the admiral has no use for Alex.  But things are about to change.With no warning, a massive alien force of unimaginable strength has landed in the Pacific Ocean.  An international coalition of ships on manuvers is the only shield.  But, the alien's firepower is superior to anything the ships have.  Soon, ships are left sinking.  A seemingly unbreakable force field is surrounding the aliens, making destruction nearly impossible.  But Alex, after witnessing the destruction of his brother's ship, must spring into action before it's too late.Overall, I thought "Battleship" was a pretty good movie.  The special effects are the highlight of this film.  The battle sequences are exciting, and the sinking of the John Paul Jones is one of the most exciting and realistic in the movie.  Kitsch, Decker, Skarsgard, and Neeson give good performances in their roles.  Rhianna makes her movie debut as Petty Officer Cora Raikes, and she gives a strong performance."Battleship" packs fast-paced action with thrilling special effects.  Recommended.
summary: Can The Aliens Sink The Battleship?

reviewText: I love movies, if they are at all well done, that are about the Navy. That is true whether the ships and fleets in question are Canadian, U.S., British, Australian, German, Japanese, or whatever, whether of the two World Wars or afterwards. Although I have spent more of my life in the Dominion of Canada, where I was naturalised a citizen, and I identify more readily as a Quebecker and Canadian than as an American, especially as the U. S. of A. has been sinking ever further into bankster/crony neo-mercantilism, other economic and political corruption, oppressive surveillance, and national insolvency. However, I had spent childhood, youth, and early adulthood in the U.S., including military service (during the Kennedy years) in the U.S. Navy, and it always is impressive in some detached, objective way (however perversely) to see a naval war machine act so efficiently and effectively as it does in this film, even that only amounts to mere fiction convincingly enacted on the screen.Just as I was beginning to think of this motion picture as merely another pleasant Navy movie, and one that can be just a bit annoyingly hokey in spots, ON CAME THE U.S.S. MISSOURI, that actual ship herself, which had been trotted out to make this film on her, along with those old veteran sailors who come out to help the youngster Navy men to handle the superb old ship as marshalled together to do battle with aliens to save Planet Earth. Suddenly my emotional sense of involvement with this film surged mightily and I admit that I really got choked up about the setting and the doings. Some of the old sailors of W.W. II and more of them from the Korean War, still would have been on active duty when I was a Navy lad myself so many years ago. I had some of the same feeling that I experienced on seeing "Under Siege", of which I also have the DVD, and that also partly had been filmed on the U.S.S. Missouri. My naval service was on a destroyer built during World War II, so it was a wonderful feeling to see the older warship after seeing so many modern smaller ships of like displacement tonnage to the one on which I served. Destroyers now, in the early 21st century, look very different than they did back in the early 1960s, especially than the ships which continued in use after W.W. II was over, such as the Gearing Class destroyer escorts (some acting as destroyers, as "my" ship did thus intermittently), the type with which I was so familiar.The U.S. Missouri continued in service for many years longer than most W.W. II vintage ships and therefore continued to undergo overhauls and refitting at the naval yards to keep it up to date with modern technology. For all of that, however, the Missouri still has the basic look of a ship of the earlier era, so the shock of recognition, although not complete, was pleasant to experience on seeing U.S.S. Missouri in this film. In the Navy, it always was awesome to go from a destroyer to a larger ship in the course of work, e.g., to a cruiser (beautiful ships equal in their own ways to the grandeur of a battleship, though not so large as one of them) or to a repair ship, supply ship, or oiler, since the sheer scale on which such large ships were designed and constructed dwarfs something like a destroyer.Fans of naval ships get both worlds in this movie, the ultra-modern destroyers of today and the vintage wonder that is (and remains) the U.S.S. Missouri. What a delight! It's worth it, believe me, to see the film if only for that! "Battleship" is full of action and the special effects are exciting. Those who like sci-fi and/or action films will find much to savour in this movie. I wish that the script's dialogue had been better at points than it is, to avoid some corniness and gauche chauvinism (referring to the nationalist, not to the gender-related kind, since women have an important part in the movie). Just avoid being nit-picky about that kind of thing, pull out the snacks, and enjoy one really entertaining motion picture, as this one surely is, reasonably well acted, and more authentic than a lot of Navy and other seafaring films that I have seen over the years! Even viewers not so "invested" in Naval lore, as guys like myself unsurprisingly are, should find much to savour in this thrilling cinematic work.
summary: A Lot of Fun to Watch, and a Lot More Than Only That for Anyone Who's Done Naval Service!

reviewText: Scientists discover an earth like planet in another solar system that is in the Goldilocks Zone, not to hot and not to cold. It is an ideal planet for the possibility of extraterrestrial life. Big enough to hold an atmosphere and all the indications that life could evolve there. They build a massive transmission system to broadcast a message to the planet from Hawaii via a high power satellite in the hopes of finding intelligent life. They get more than they bargained for. Be careful who you invite to your home, you just might not like them....I won't go into detail as I don't want to ruin this movie for you but I thoroughly enjoyed it. It is nonstop continuous action that was entertaining. I love Sci-Fi and I watch it for enjoyment. This movie was exciting and fun to watch and I liked the story line and the special effects were just out of this world, literally.Of course it is hokey in some places, of course they take liberties with technical aspects and military details that are incorrect but it is a movie for entertainments sake. It is fast paced, high action with the US Navy and the alien forces head to head for the survival of the planet earth. The aliens are aggressive and dangerous with advanced technology and weapons. The special effects were well thought out and done to perfection. The aliens are actually in the light and you get to see them and it is not filmed in the dark like most alien movies are done. The camera work was great and the soundtrack is awesome.If you like Sci-Fi movies then you will like this one! Don't believe all the professional movie critics, this movie has already made $280 million worldwide and it has only been released 11 days ago in the USA and sold $48 million in USA ticket sales.My wife, grandsons and I all liked this and so will you! We will buy the DVD when it is released.
summary: Be careful who you invite to your home, you just might not like them!

reviewText: Warning - Spoilers will followThe movie starts off with a decent enough premise - a bunch of common sense lacking eggheads sending out a message to a planet with the potential for intelligent life, without stopping to consider the consequences.We then switch to a completely useless scene where we meet our hero, a loser attempting to steal a chicken burrito from a convenience store. Said loser is then forced to enlist in the Navy by his older brother (who would have made for a better lead) and, miraculously, is an officer in the chain of command next we see him. (To be an officer, he would have had to go through the Naval Academy, or, having enlisted, gone through Officer Training School.) He then goes through the rest of the movie trying to channel is inner Kirk.The aliens are little better. They manage to fly light years to Earth, and then have their communications ship get destroyed when hitting a satellite on their final approach. So their goal is to re-establish communications with their home world, but we do not learn this right away. First, we are left guessing at what motivates the invaders. After all, they only fire upon ships that first fired upon them. (But then they we learn that they somehow cannot "see" the ships that are not actually firing upon them - which of course is all lead up to the scene in which they are actually "playing" Battleship with the aliens by anticipating blind shots and calling out "hit" or "miss".) We find out that the conflict is not a simple misunderstanding when the main character has some sort of mind meld with an alien they just happen to find floating in the sea. He sees a vision of them conducting an all out invasion, when he looks into the aliens lizard like eyes (which is how we learn they don't like bright light, but still gives no insight as to why they cannot "see" anything not presenting an immediate threat).Back to their goal of getting communications established with their home world. Why is this such a concern for either side? Obviously, the aliens already know where the Earth is.  Are they not able to send more ships without the advance scouts (if that's what they are) reporting back first? And why do the main characters think that the threat is ended if the aliens cannot transfer their message? It's not like this was a random encounter. They followed the instructions given them in the beginning of the movie. Given such a situation, you cannot assume that following waves are not forthcoming.In the end, though it has some interesting action sequences, this movie requires a much greater suspension of disbelief than virtually all big budget alien invasion movies that have come before it. Any alien invasion movie that doesn't have the enemy simply bombard the planet from space requires suspension of disbelief, but this one simply has too many elements that are just not well thought out.

reviewText: What a heap of fun this movie was! Admitidly, given the lack of buzz about it when it came out, I saw it with low expectations but I was genuinely entertained by it. There are a couple of big laughs at the start and then when the action kicks in some tense passages and some surprises. Sure it's predictable but the significant adjustments needed to boost the board game origins into a full scale film were in my opinion quite well done. Obviously you need to suspend belief about various things, but if you can accept an alien invasion you can live with the other major credibility leaps too. Indeed, if you insist on your viewing following completely logical paths you should probably stick to documentaries.I thought the actors did a sound job, they kept things moving and looked the part. The aliens looked fine, and were quite inscrutable at times. The special effects were quite good indeed and some of the big scenes were quite spectacular. I liked the pumping sound-track too! There were some clever historical references and some pleasing character interactions. There are a few cheesy moments but it's in keeping with the film not taking itself too seriously. It really worked for me and I happily recommend it as a good `B' movie. All up, the makers can be well pleased with themselves here!

reviewText: So a few years back there was a planet discovered that was remarkably similar to Earth, to contact and gather more information on this planet there was something created called The Beacon Project which decided to send a transmission to this planet called Planet G. Now we cut to a man named Alex (Taylor Kitsch, "John Carter") at a bar with his brother Stone (Alexander Skarsgard, "Melancholia"), after Alex's failed attempt at impressing a girl at the bar named Sam (Brooklyn Decker, "Just Go With It") ends up getting an ultimatum from Stone, either join the Navy or else.So some time later we cut to both brothers in the Navy, Alex is together with Sam (some guys have all the luck) and along with the Shane (Liam Neeson, "Taken") the Admiral of the entire fleet. After some more exposition while out at sea some aliens decide to attack various locations around the world. These attackers are obviously from this planet G and Shane along with his sailors must do their best to turn back this attack and drive the aliens out of our world.There's some good humor in this one, of course a lot of it is unintentional thanks to the complete and utter ridiculous nature of the film. Its based on the popular family game in name only as I don't recall ever saying "Aliens sunk my battleship", the budget is enormous just over $200 million, the cast is decent even including singer Rihanna, the story is so bad but honestly its also an entertaining mess.I do credit the filmmakers for working with actual Naval officers to lend some more realism to this flick, even having a good amount of actual Navy members as part of the cast. This did show that they actually cared about making sure the Naval aspects were accurate and not just made up. Of course that doesn't stop the director and writers from taking liberties with how silly and ludicrious the story and plot is, along with the goofy and stilted dialogue.The cast at least seems to be having fun, though how Neeson was cast in this goofy flick is beyond me, however I must commend them for casting Brooklyn Decker who is just stunningly beautiful. The special effectts are very good as are the action sequences, it does breeze by a lot of the time and while I expected to hate this movie I found myself enjoying a good amount of it. Its not nearly as good or as fun as another Hasboro inspired movie "G.I. Joe" but "Battleship" is much better than I ever thought it would be. **1/2 out of 4 stars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The characters are cookie cutter, the plot is well worn and the special effects are pedestrian. But "Battleship" is nevertheless quite entertaining. Just put your mind on hold and enjoy the ride. Well worth having in your library. I've already watched it several times, much like watching a fireworks show. They're all the same but that doesn't deminish the thrill.SPOILER:If, however, you're looking for something to engage the mind, forget it. A glaring example: the entire plot centers on aliens, having arrived on Earth but having lost their long distance communications ship (so they can signal back to their home planet to send the entire invasion force), gets wrecked before landing. Instead they take over a ground station for the orbiting satellite that sent an initial message from Earth out into deep space that first attracted the alien's attention. They plan to call home using it to start the full invasion. Yet not once in the entire film does anyone say "look, if they need that satellite of ours to get the signal home, why don't we just retask it to a different orbit where it won't connect to the ground station and they won't be able to send their message? Or why not just shoot it down? Either way, problem solved." When they miss a solution that simple, you just know it's time to put your brain on hold and just enjoy the fireworks.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Battleship(2012) is an action packed science fiction film loosely based on the board game Battleship. American and Japanese naval officers have to fight off an alien invasion. Battleship is a big, expensive, ponderous spectacle. It feels like a big budget Asylum movie or a Michael Bay film. The alien beings that the Battleship crew fights are very one dimensional. This feels like a 1950's style alien invader film made in 2012. Still, this movie is fun if you turn your brain off. The visual effects are solid. The chicken burrito theft scene was funny. It was a shot for shot spoof of a real life liquor store robbery recorded on CCTV. Battleship is packed with product placement. I saw the Subway logo three times. The aliens in the film use giant orbs with razors. The orbs slice through cars, helicopters, bridges and ships. The behind the scenes featurettes on the DVD show us how much money and elbow grease went into making this film. Battleship is worth a rental or watching on late night TV with beer!

reviewText: I know, I know, it's a "check your brain at the door" kind of movie. I don't even mind those kinds of movies, as long as the acting and dialogue aren't painful. This movie? Yeah, the acting and dialogue are painful.The main character is played by a man who I have witnessed acting in other things. I know he can act, he just needs a better director and script. The girlfriend? A swimsuit model who is now an "actress." I guess jiggling the goods onscreen is acting now? My acting professors would disagree. I disagree. The disabled vet and the old-time war heroes? Come on. I know you want to lend some authenticity, but putting non-actors on the screen and having them woodenly utter memorized dialogue is just awful to watch. As background actors? Fine. As actual characters who utter lines? HELL NO.Peter Berg: Please, for the love of all that is good in movies, STOP COPYING MICHAEL BAY. Bay had an excellent popcorn movie style a decade ago before he started overusing all of his signature shots. If you want to emulate Bay at his best, watch The Rock and go from there. Transformers? No. Just, no.The highlights of the film consist of Liam Neeson as an Admiral and the cool looking alien ships. And...., yeah, no, that was it.

reviewText: Update: 7/19/2013 - Battleship is now playing on the HBO channels, so I watched it again to see where I left the track on this review. This movie has been maligned by professional critics and everyday people who review, and I watched carefully for that AHA, they were right, moment. I LOVED it all over again! Two hours of rollicking good sci fi fun that I unashamedly enjoyed as much this time as the first time. I guess I will never understand when people stopped laughing and enjoying a simple, old fashioned good guys vs. bad guys movie (I reference The Last Stand with Arnold Schwarzenegger) and simply enjoyed it for what it was - fun with no apparent relevance. I stand by this review and ask anyone who reads this to let go and stop looking for trouble where there is none!ORIGINAL REVIEW: I live in Maine. I have watched dozens of movies supposedly taking place in New England. I've had to suspend my better judgement as I recognize over and over, Vancouver, CA, Oregon or Washington being passed off as New England. If you ARE from New England, you know darn well the movie or show you are watching does NOT take place in New England. This is a bit of information for those of you who are either in the military (and, mind you, we are retired military and strongly support you), or are die-hard sci-fi geeks who have whined on and on about how "unreal" this movie is. For crying out loud. Can you NOT suspend your beliefs for 90 minutes and just enjoy a good old fashioned shoot 'em up, yay for us as we take on and win against all odds a bunch of obviously better equipped aliens?I LOVED this movie. It was fun. It gave you time to get to know and like the characters. I'm not stupid - I certainly saw many of the errors and problems pointed out by those of you who are so depressed by today's miserable issues or whatever that you cannot just sit back, buy some popcorn and a soda and enjoy this movie for what it is? Just a fun movie for families and people of all ages, full of excitement, good guys vs. bad guys, very funny moments, and some hot guys for us ladies to drool over in the process. OF COURSE, I had to suspend belief that Alex Harper would have even made it into the military with his background (not!), that a bunch of ships out for an international exercise would be armed to the teeth (not!), that there was no way in heck the few ships caught in the dome with some really vicious aliens had a snowball's chance in heck of winning (not!).But you know what? I wasn't WATCHING this movie for realism. I wasn't watching this movie for some deep political statement. I wasn't watching this movie for a message that war is bad and peace is good. I watched it to escape reality and have a lot of fun. Something I haven't done at the movies for a very long time. The language wasn't terrible, the acting (yummy Taylor Kitsch!!) was great, the movie was well cast, a little romance thrown in. I laughed, I found myself at the end of the movie after what seemed like 5 minutes (what we call a 5-minute show - it's so good you lose all track of time and it seems like it's over in 5 minutes as opposed to most shows and movies today that have me looking at the clock and thinking "oh my gosh, only 15 minutes has gone by???") wishing I could watch it for the first time all over again.Seriously, people need to lighten up and just have some fun. Especially today. The world isn't such a great place right now and I am smart enough to know too much about just how bad things are.I almost passed this movie up because it only had three stars! If I were deciding whether or not to watch this movie based on most reviews, I definitely would have passed it up. I AM HERE TO ENCOURAGE YOU NOT TO READ ALL THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS AND TO SUSPEND YOUR LIFE AND REALITY FOR THIS MOVIE AND WATCH IT! DO NOT let the negative reviews stop you from watching what is almost an old fashioned shoot 'em up movie with really great characters and actors, heart-stopping action scenes and almost too true CGI scenes. Three of us watched it together and we all said the same thing at the end - we LOVED it and we're REALLY glad we didn't let the reviews stop us from watching it. Like I said, I'm used to having to suspend belief - you have NO IDEA how many times they've shown our local airport, our little town, our coast - and those of us who live here (on the East Coast) know darn well it's been filmed out on the West Coast - they look NOTHING alike. Suspension of belief comes easy for us. Lighten up and let this movie take you away for an hour and a half or so for some really great action filled fun!
summary: GOOD OLD FASHIONED ALIEN INVASION - WELL DONE

reviewText: This movie was the best invasion flick in years. It is hands down better than Battle Los Angeles. The movie has the same feel as Independence Day in that the characters and events are not 100% serious and it does not try to be a technically accurate sci-fi. It's about excitement and fun - not blood and gore. It's about people and not big strategy; the strategy has its flaws just like Independence Day. The special effects are excellent, not cheesy. The movie is not as epic like Independence Day and remains tightly focused on a few characters. I highly recommend this flick for a less cerebral night at the movies.

reviewText: This film is about a young man that is about to get kicked out of the Navy. One day an alien race attacks planet Earth and it is up to him and his crew to stop them. Through a crazy turn of events, they commandeer the USS Missouri and defeat the aliens.Battleship had a couple good actors. Liam Neeson, and Alexander Skarsgard (the guy that played Eric Northman in True Blood).It had great special effects, tons of action, and a little comedy. The cinematography was kinda bad though. Most of the filming was really shaky. The story wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either. I think that just about everybody can find something to like and dislike about this movie. It's probably worth watching once, but I wouldn't want it taking up space on my shelf. So I recommend just renting it.
summary: Good and Bad at the same time.

reviewText: Started watching Battleship, drawn to it by its reputation as the biggest box office flop of the past five years, but I wound up admiring something about the movie and kept it up through the end, eventually luring my wife into watching the last two thirds with me.  We clapped at the end like two total geeks.  But I must say that in the light of day the movie has problems which prevent me from giving it the coveted Killian five stars.  I hate to say it, but Taylor Kitsch, so watchable in Friday Night Lights, has no personality with the short Naval Academy haircut they give him here.  Did his long twin swoops of side hair as Tim Riggins give him the shadow he needs to act?  Here, he's playing the same exact part--the handsome screwup who's throwing his life away, plagued by a difficult relationship with a distant older brother--and he's letting himself be a parody of Tim Riggins.  Even Riggins wouldn't have cut through the roof of that 7-11 to get the girl a chicken burrito.  And as others have said, how on earth did he get a berth in the Officers' training school or whatever it's called, with that track record, and how did he manage to turn himself around in what looks like six months of movie time, to become the greatest warrior the Navy's ever known?  OK, so that part is ludicrous, but I'm blaming it on the stylist who made Taylor Kitsch's face so glowy and blushy he doesn't even have any expressions.  Apparently Peter Berg, Kitsch's director in both this movie and on FNL, thinks he has it in him to be the new Channing Tatum, but I don't think so.  He needs new material--no, he needs the same old material, long hair, return to the Dillon Panthers, driving that truck, maybe taking over the coach's role at the high school when Coach moves to Nashville with Connie Britton on her new show.Another one dragged along into Battleship from Friday Night Lights is Jesse Plemons, and HE'S playing the same part he had too---the sleepy-eyed towhead sidekick who inexplicably wins the attentions of the hottest chick within miles--in this case, Rihanna of all people!  Plemons' stuttering and nervous tics bring to mind a degraded and country version of oldtime comic standby Jack Lemmon from those Billy Wilder films, but without the timing or the glibness.  He just stands around looking dumb and Rihanna gives her heart to him like he's Chris Brown.  Well, I didn't buy it!  However, Rihanna is terribly good in this show and in fact may be the best actor in it--outside of the Japanese guy and the man who has just little rods for legs, whom we figured was CGI at first but then we thought, OMG, that may be his actual body!  Either way he's pretty stoic.  Hamish Linklater, who plays the ambitious news producer on Newsroom who fabricates the Genoa scandal, here takes the old Jeff Goldblum role from Jurassic Park, except nerdier.  He's not bad either, though we couldn't figure out how he came up with the big reveal about the aliens' weakness.  Truth is, on the home screen perhaps Battleship loses a few points.  You couldn't see the aliens' awesome superweapon all that well--it looked like the whirling gizmo of gears that Pinhead employed in all the old 80s and 90s Clive Barker films--hovering ominously, then skeetering over surfaces and carving them up then briskly looking for a new target.I thought the good guys were going to harness the energy or instruction manual for those ball machines, and use them to carve up the protective fortress of plastic that the aliens had whipped up to isolate them in.  What happened to that plot development, eh?  Maybe they were saving that for Battleship 2: Balls in Our Court....  but due to the failure of Part One, it will never come to pass.

reviewText: Each time I watch this movie, I love it even more than the time before. I believe it only suffers from a "poor to fair" opening act. One the war games begin, this is a truly great movie. Remember, it's not trying to be the next great social commentary- it's a fun summer popcorn movie- and more. The acting is very good- including the razzie malligned Riahna- I know nothing of her music, but I thought she was great in this. I especially enjoyed the storyline of the  of the American and Japanese commanders.The "Art of War" references were hilarious. The script was well done, save the opening sequences. Finally, the special efects were absolutely spectacular. ILM made great strides in presenting photo quality realistic war ships. The ships are patterned after water bug- brilliantly done! The aliens appearance was well done- not great, but very good. The uniforms (space suits) are spectacular. GREAT MOVIE!

reviewText: As I recall this movie came out in the spring/summer but I missed it upon an avalanche of other tasty confections of the season but this would've been a comfort for those who like this sort of fare but simply overlooked it. If you like sci-fi, love to explore, not a snob about movie vs. book versions of things Battleship is a good home-cooked meal. A bit short on the creature feature I wanted but strong visually with enough pop-fizzle-bang for the kids alongside a very "thoughtful" script allowing for credible adult attention spans. The breakout star is Taylor Kitsch of (Wolverine) but everyone is bringing "full-on" performances that leave you satisfied. Brooklyn Decker, the female lead, is aaight, lol, if you like that sort of bottle-blonde, Hollywood formula, leading lady thang, she's a proficient actress and none too hard on the eyes but that is to be expected. Rihanna would've been an unconventional "beauty-babe" choice, although her scant lines are delivered with punch and memorable panache.
summary: Surprisingly Good Script From Hasbro Productions

reviewerName: Leiah "So, I Read This Book Today . . ."
reviewText: I totally enjoyed this movie. it was absolute fun. Definitely not "War and Peace", but come on, people, did you REALLY expect it to be? If so, the problem is yours, not the movie's. No story? Well, we do what some people are terrified of and some are totally excited about - sending out a signal to a possibly inhabited planet. Said signal, as some say will happen, some don't, brings those 'other worlders' to our world. The Navy gets to strut it stuff, the world wins out, the boy gets the girl, and there is your story.Again, no storyline by Dostoyevsky, but hey, what did you expect? It's a summer blockbuster. Get over it. Relax and enjoy, or don't, but come on people. Is it actually necessary to be a total JERK in your review? I am amazed at the number of people these days who rant and rave and scream in reviews, being as nasty as possible, just to hear their own heads rattle. I can understand making considered complaints about a movie, making points about problems with movies or books. I am certainly capable of ranting and raving about something that is important - glorifying child abuse, sexual abuse, etc. But ranting and raving about such ridiculous issues? Come on people, get a life. . .There are a lot of things to like about this movie, if you take it in the vein in which it is intended. It is a shoot-em-up alien blockbuster. And, it includes a POSITIVE look at the Navy, which is really cool. Our soldiers put themselves in horrible positions, give up their lives, and we treat them horribly and pay them less than minimum wage for doing it. They deserve to show their stuff. And using those venerable old sailors on the Missouri? Priceless! My dad, a major in the Marines, would have gotten a HUGE kick out of that! I am going to be digging around, seeing if those are Really U.S.S. Missouri veterans. How cool would THAT be?I found the movie well worth watching, especially for this "end of the world/asteroid/alien attacks" movie buff. Great CGI, lots of big guns, the sailors showing their stuff, what's not to like? A total blast! Besides, Rhianna struts her kick-ass stuff . . . I really didn't care for Hopper, and was a little confused that he was apparently in his late 30's, then went into the military and climbed the ladder even though he was a complete sc**w-up . . . but, well, it was still a LOT of fun, and that is what matters!Take a pill if you are too uptight. Otherwise, pop it in, sit back with popcorn and soda, and enjoy.

reviewText: "Battleship" is a crappy film, coated with pretty frosting and sprinkles of special effects.  The ONLY good thing about the film is the special effects/action scenes.The first 40 mins have NO aliens...just lame/boring character development. Battleship looks/feels exactly like a Michael Bay film.When the aliens do attack, the rest of the film is practically, non-stop action, with dumb plot-points and cliched characters. And there is a stupid plot-point where veterans are asked to help command the Missouri.The aliens themselves...well, their suits are kind of neat (kinda like a cross between, Master Chief and a scuba-diver), but the creatures look like rednecks from space.Liam Neeson is in the film, but does nothing. Rhianna is pretty, but her character is bland.I still dont understand why the aliens throw people around, when they should just try killing them with weapons.Another thing im confused about is why an alien doesnt kill one of the humans, because the human is wearing glasses...And yes, there is a grid sequence, similiar to the boardgame.While Battleship is nice to look at, the story/characters are just stupid.Watch it, if youre bored, but thats all i can recommend.Battleship sinks with 2 stars

reviewText: Yeah, this movie bombed at the box office. But if you enjoy an old-fashioned military flick (despite the insertion of aliens as The Great Enemy instead of Nazis or terrorists), this one is better than you'd expect. And the ending? It's a whopper, complete with grizzled old vets saving the day instead of those pretty-boy whippersnappers, LOL. If you have ever visited Pearl Harbor and stepped aboard the USS Missouri....well, in that case you MUST see this film!

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: MOVIE REVIEW #33 : " Battleship "Hasbro and director Peter Berg (Hancock, Friday Night Lights) are on their way to bring another commercial product to life - this one loosely tries to give you the feel of two enemies battling for their survival. There are Aliens from another galaxy battling and a Navel `maneuvers' event (with several nations competing) that turns into a literally "battle for the survival planet Earth". There really is no reason given, motivation presented or even a hint at why the aliens are doing what their doing - but I guess you are supposed to `go with it'. Okeydokey!With really no true story running through this film, writers Eric Hoeber and Jon Hoeber (Red, Whiteout) tried to develop a relationship with two brothers and an apparently disapproving father-in-law-to-be and make that the emotional core of the film. It just doesn't work for me. A wedding where the groom can't even ask the father permission to marry his daughter - because his is the Admiral of the fleet! More than a little shallow and superficial - the story really becomes interesting in one way - the Battles.The saving grace of the film is the fast action of the aliens, their technology and how the earth sea vessels and aircraft fight this extremely powerful and strong Earth invasion. The special effects and tactical planning of the attacks on both sides is engaging and candy for the eye. Really the movie becomes quite interesting - if completely illogical - when the humans and aliens make their attempts to achieve military control of a communications satellite array in Hawaii.There are some good performances by the two brothers played by Taylor Kitsch (John Carter, X-Men: Origins) and Alexander Skarsgard (True Blood, Straw Dogs) who lead the pack in the adventure that seems forever foreboding. Pop singer Rihanna makes her screen debut in this film and she does quite a good job as a tough, go-getting navel navigator. Liam Neeson (Schindler's List, Taken) does what I call a "cameo" appearance as the father (and Fleet Admiral) of the love interest and motivating factor for the youngest brother (Kitsch) - Brooklyn Decker (Just Go With It) artfully plays her role with clever wit.Overall...the "Grid" they use to simulate the original Hasbro BATTLESHIP board game is actually cleverly designed as a plotting coordinates made by ocean buoy's in the see. Of course The end sequence is kind of clever - yet completely non-realistic - but involved the decommissioned USS Missouri in Hawaii. I won't tell you what happens...but it was both patriotic and slightly heartwarming.This is defiantly a film with good action and special effects. There is no meat in the story and really nothing to do but just enjoy the special effects ride. I think kids will enjoy it - past the first half hour...and those that are fans of Navel Military vessels will love this film. Otherwise, it really candy for the eyes and a good thrill ride - did I mention the first 30 minutes? Zzzzzzzz. It tries to be more than what it is....but it is nothing more than a series of good special effects action sequences strung together with a small - but big - objective - save Earth!
summary: They Sunk Their Battleship! Really, They Did!
