reviewText: "We're going in... full attack....  That's an order."I was lured into watching this film by the fairly high rating on amazon.com.  It should be noted that as of right now you can't actually rent this movie, which might be an indication as to the "enjoyability" of the film.  That's just a wild guess born out of suspicion, by the way.  So, buy it I did, and boy what a waste of money it turned out to be.  I didn't not like it, per se, but I didn't like it either; hence the 2 1/2 stars.The move starts off telling us that when scientists discovered an earth like planet in the Gliese system, NASA built the most advanced communication satellite ever so that they could send a message there.  Why NASA would do this, seeing how an earth like planet does not automatically mean life let alone intelligent life, is beyond me.  But, hey, it's just entertainment, right?  Unfortunately, the film is just not entertaining enough to ignore the many flaws.There's a whole comical scene in the beginning, involving a slacker named Alex Hopper who's rooming with Alexander Skarsgard (who's performance is shockingly terrible here).  I use comical in a bad sense here because it is not at all funny.  Alex meets physiotherapist Samantha Shane at a bar/restaurant and tries to talk to her.  To make a long story short, he makes a deal to get 5 minutes of her time, if he gets her a chicken sandwich (the bartender/chef refuses to make one).  Alex breaks into a gas station store and hilarity ensues to the tune of the Pink Panther theme.  Horrible.  Why isn't Alex in jail after breaking into the store or even let into the Navy after that stunt is never explained.  There are other parts of the movie like this where the jokes just fall flat.  Like the incredibly nerdy scientist (what's with Hollywood and nerdy scientists?) who thought the 1-emotion (deadpan) double-amputee black guy, Mick Canales, was a cyborg.  A cyborg, I kid you not.Rihanna was pointless.  It must have been some attempt to create another Vasquez from Aliens, but fails horribly.  They actually gave her the hero's final line.  You know, the yippeekayay moment and it was horrible.  Why is she the only woman on the ship, anyway?  Speaking of ships, the alien ship jumps in and out of water like a grasshopper.  Why?  It's not stated.  I guess just to give us something "visually stunning" to look at, but it just looked stupid to me.Anyway, the aliens look like ogres with spiky beards.  Real original there, Hollywood (sarcasm).  There's no indication what the aliens want, by the way, except for some psychic bond one has with Alex for no reason whatsoever.  I guess they wanted an Independence Day moment, but fails because instead of Alex telling us what the aliens want based on the flashes, he just says he has a feeling about them.  Well, I guess, since I don't know what they want either based on that jumbled mess.  It looked like the aliens were at war with each other, then came here to destroy our technology and infrastructure for no reason at all.  None of the weapons or aliens ever targeted people, unless threatened.  Get it, like the Borg?  From this psychic link, Alex deduces that they want our planet or themselves.  Why Alex?  Can you elaborate?  No?  Are you at least empathetic enough to save the sailors in the water, without having to be told to?  No?  Okay, moving along.It's possible to deduce that the aliens destroyed their planet, or were destroying it, and sent out a scout party to look for another planet to live on.  Putting aside the logic that an alien race wouldn't send a military unit to do this (you need scientist for this job, Hollywood.  do'h), it still doesn't make any sense.  War destroyed your planet and your solution to this is to start another war with another species on another planet?  Riiight.This brings me to the point of not caring about a single person in this film.  Liam Neeson?  Wasted.  Louis Lombardi  (Edgar from 24) and Peter C. MacNicol (Janosz from Ghostbusters and Tom Lennox from 24)?  Wasted.And then there's Cal(sp?) the scientist.  This is like the pinnacle of nerdy scientist ever.  But this is nerdy to the point of mind-numbingly annoying.  This is the guy who makes the cyborg comment I mentioned earlier.  This is a winy little annoying uber dork who runs away from the fight, because he thinks its safe, and takes his suitcase with him.  Do you see what's coming?  I won't spoil it.  It's just too laughably ridiculous.Nice to see a shot of a Buddha statue instead of Jesus in a film, though.  It didn't get destroyed, though.  I guess it's not shocking enough to Hollywood for us to see the symbol of other people's beliefs being annihilated before our very eyes.  But maybe that's over-analyzing.  I'm not Buddhist, by the way.So, to help you decide whether you want to watch or not:1) Characters are pointless and their deaths don't matter to me2) Aliens have no real motive and aren't interesting.  They also never talk.3) Bad comedy4) Boring first half5) Moronic hero6) The "S" word is used a couple of times, while the "M" word is half said at least twice)7) Acceptable musical scoreIf you like empty movies like Underworld, Resident Evil and Transformers II & III (the Transformers movies are better than this), then you'll probably enjoy this.  Everyone else stay away.  (Yes, I gave Transformers I a pass.  It's a guilty pleasure.)

reviewText: Battleship is a well done light Sci Fi action romp that actually had good people and acting in it.  The special effects were very well done.  The big thing that is still staying in mind after watching the film is how respectfully our Veterans (past and present) were treated.  I don't want to give away any spoilers, but I will say that several Vets in particular end up being crucial in saving the day.Take a few minutes to watch the special features, the man just learning to use his artificial legs is the real deal.  I thought this inparticular was a brave move on the part of the filmmakers, as I am sure using a professional actor and CGI would have been the easier choice.  He is one character that ends up being pretty important and he is hardly helpless!  Sorry if I am being vague, I am trying not to give out spoilers.  I have a lot of respect for the filmmakers using and depicting Veterans (especially in such a positive light).  My hearty thanks and salute to our U.S. Veterans one and all!
summary: Light Sci Fi Action Romp With A Great Treatment Of U.S. Veterans
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film has for only purpose to entertain us and in this aspect it is highly succesful. The main hero is very likeable, the leading girl charming, the display of military hardware impressive, the aliens naughty (and ugly and stupid!), the scenario doesn't make much sense, the CGI effects are EXCELLENT, US Navy is the best, US government is incompetent - in one word, everything is as it should be in a movie made to go nicely with your popcorn on a Friday evening. WARNING! Some SPOILERS incoming at six o'clock!The main hero, Lt. Alex Hopper (Taylor Kitsch) is a troubled young man who after messing up a lot in his early life finally joined the US Navy and by some extraordinary miracle managed to become an officer in charge of weapons on board of USS "John Paul Jones", a very powerful destroyer of "Arleigh Burke" class. He is however poorly noted by his superiors and is generally considered as a disappointment and a failure. The unexpected alien invasion during a naval exercice will suddenly force him to take command ("Who is in charge now?" "Hopper!" "We are so dead!") and lead his men into a particularly deadly fight against a vicious and resourceful enemy.Other than his messy life style Alex Hooper has also another "problem" - his gorgeous, sculpturally beautiful girlfriend Samantha (Brooklyn Decker). She loves him, he loves her and they are engaged to be married - but her father hates his guts and for reasons which you will have to discover yourself his agreement to their marriage actually matters...Other characters are also important: Alex's brother, Stone Hopper (Alexander Skarsgard) who is the older, responsible and organised version of Alex; Vice-Admiral Shane (Liam Neeson), tough, impressive commander in chief of US Pacific Fleet; Japanese Navy Captain Nagata (Tadanobu Asano), commanding the Japanese destroyer "Myoko" and Lt. Colonel (Retired) Mick Canales (Gregory D. Gadson), a bitter US Army veteran who lost his both legs in one of recent American wars.Rihanna makes her movie debut in this film, as Petty Officer Cora Raikes, a weapon specialist and crew member on board of USS "John Paul Jones", serving under Alex Hopper orders. She has a lot of screen time and she is VERY good! I was very pleasantly surprised by her acting and I am looking forward to see her in more films.The display of modern weaponry is very impressive. 5-inch guns and 20mm Phalanx CIWS (Close-in Weapon System), "Harpoon" missiles and 324 mm torpedoes of American and Japanese destroyers are used generously and they give a great show. And once the old battleship USS "Missouri" enters in action with her 16-inch big guns, things get even better!The aliens are very very agressive and naughty - although to be fair, they seem to avoid the colateral damage as much as possible, by sparing the obviously harmless oponents. They also try to rescue their own soldiers taken prisoner, which is something not so frequent in SF films. Other than that they are the "standard issue" aliens: ugly, hostile, technologically advanced in some fields but limited in others (they do not seem to grasp fully the concept of guided weapons) and last but not least abysmally, galactically, terminally stupid! BUT, in this film it actually is an asset, because it allows USS "Missouri" to engage the alien flagship in a way which reminds of the bloody and dramatic fight between HMS "Victory" and "Redoutable" at Trafalgar...The scenario doesn't make much sense as for the reasons for this invasion which seems ultimately to be just a reconnaissance. The reason for the attack on Oahu island and the whole battle around it are even more ludicrous - as for the whole "saving the world" thing, let's just throw a veil of silence on it... A civilization able to send a scouting military expedition of five ships through interstellar space, can always send a second one, stronger and better prepared. So, there is a possibility of a sequel.The CGI effects are really EXCELLENT! Alien ships and weapons are very well done, fights are very "realistic" and visually the film is a big success.All fighting men and women of US forces (and the one lonely Japanese guy) are shown as heroes fighting to the end at the best of their capacities, engaging enemy with missiles first, handguns second and iron bars and bare fists after that, if necessary. In contrast, the US government is (of course!) completely incompetent, which is only normal, considering that it is chaired by a Secretary of Defense played by Peter MacNicol (yes, you read well!).So, all in all, it is a rather succesful, quite entertaining film, with lots of good special effects, lots of good fights, two well playing hot chicks (Brooklyn Decker and Rihanna), some handsome men, a very stupid scenario, quite a lot of humour, at least one very touching moment and one very VERY dearly paid chicken burito...))) I had lots of fun watching it, although I am aware of its weaknesses - and I think that if all you need is some harmless entertainment, you will like it too. Enjoy!
summary: Join the Navy, save the world, get the girl and have a chicken burito!

reviewText: Essentially a kid's comic book with the accompanying level of depth, expectation or creativity. I suspect if I were 12 and under - this might be the perfect summer movie.However, that said, it had very brief moments of fun, primarily as the 'teams' begin to play Battleship with real ships.Was quite fascinated with the aliens, appreciated that they were humanoid. Mildly bored with screening ETs represented by various Geiger-inspired slippery insectile and tentacled slimy cephalopods. They had a good ride the past ten-fifteen years, time to move onto something new I think.Again, massive plotholes notwithstanding, if you're looking for a kid's movie - this is for you.Movie Notes:- Not sure how many caught Director Peter Berg in a cameo role as a CIC operator. The free-spirited actor/director has shown he can do so much more with the right material. And I hope he's not forced to again draw from the Michael Bay palette.- I'm of the mindset that this is the worst Liam Neeson performance ever. And given his recent string of pay-for-play walkthrough performances, I wonder if he's serious about the craft any longer? Not sure what his effort represents beyond collecting a paycheck. Hate to delve into the man's personal life, but there is a measurable correlation in his career decision-making and the sad untimely passing of his wife; taking on projects that I suspect fill his time and wallet, but not his résumé of previous quality roles.- Interestingly and conversely, I found Tadanobu Asano as the Japanese naval officer, surprisingly genuine. A lone actor stranded amongst a litter-filled field of mediocrity. About the only interesting aspect to this production for cinephiles.
summary: If You're 12 And Under - Perfection Attained
Title: N/A

reviewText: Based loosely on the Hasbro game and concept, this movie takes a little while to get going, but once it does, it's a pretty exciting ride.The movie starts with scientists attempting to send out a deep space signal to another nearby star system to try to communicate. Unfortunately, the aliens turn out to be hostile and decide to home in on earth and conquer it since our two planets are similar and can support the same type of life, perhaps because their planet is dying and they need to find a new home.Most of the psychological tension in the movie is about the relationship between between Liam Neeson, the admiral, and Alex Skarsgard, a bright but ne'er-do-well young officer who wants to marry the admiral's daughter, but the admiral is singularly unimpressed with Skarsgard as a new graduate officer assigned to his battle group. Of course, he saves the day, redeeming himself in the admiral's eyes and gets the hand of the admiral's daughter in marriage after all.That's just the romantic backdrop to the movie, and the rest of the story line in some ways doesn't make much sense, but the action and special effects are what it's all about. For example, the aliens, for all their more advanced technology, are slow to capitalize on their opportunities and often just seem to waste time doing nothing much of the time. Of course, this just gives the humans the needed time to regroup and figure out how to defeat them. They also have the ability to create a large enough force field to cover a considerable area of the ocean, trapping some of the human ships and excluding others, but they don't seem to have the ability to generate a forcefield to protect their individual ships as they are still vulnerable to the humans' guns and missiles. Why the aliens can create such a large force field and not be able to create smaller ones to protect individual ships doesn't make much sense and isn't explained in the movie. But then if that were true the humans wouldn't have had much of a chance at all.The special effects are cool though and the alien technology is superior to ours in many ways, and also different. As one reviewer here mentioned perceptively, they don't seem to understand the concept of a guided missile. Instead, their ships shoot out these giant buzz saw weapons the size of small cars, and only two or three of these can shred a whole ship in a matter of minutes. Military history buffs may remember the British developed something similar during WWII which had a funny name, the Jabberwocky or Hurdy-Gurdy, I don't exactly remember.  But it was a giant rocket propelled wheel designed for use on a beachhead and this was reminiscent of that. The other main weapon the aliens have resembles a ship-to-ship mine which is fired from a launcher and embeds itself in the side of a ship and then explodes. The alien troops also have powered armor--the sort that the mobile infantry should have had in the Starship Troopers movie of some years back (and which was present in the Robert Heinlein novel that the movie was based on).The movie pays homage to the old Missouri battleship which saves the day at the very end of the movie, and is being manned by elderly members of her crew who were there to give the tours and answer questions for the public, a very cool idea. Overall, a fun movie with spectacular CGI special effects and with enough action to be worth your time on a lazy weekend evening.
summary: Fun with great special effects ideas

reviewText: 5 stars? "One of the best"? Unbelievable. Seriously... there are more than a few better action and sci-fi movies available to us recently. This really trumps The Dark Night trilogy, Iron Man, Inception, The Matrix trio, Star Trek, Transformers, Avatar, etc.? This movie is clearly b-list by comparison. Come on people this is based on a VERY simple children's game... and it's a very simple movie.That having been said, it's still an entertaining effort. Not the watch it hundreds of times type of entertaining, but it's a lot less stupid and disappointing than Battle Los Angeles. I'm amazed at the high production values and solid casting given the unimpressive plot. Apart from the first half hour this is a visually stunning movie with a seemingly solid sound track(amazon only plays in stereo). It's worth it to see a Battleship unloading a full broadside at point blank range. I'd recommend you rent it though. This flick'll be collecting dust in no time.
summary: The masses really aren't that much smarter than sheep.

reviewText: Pretty much like Battle Los Angeles was an advertisement for the US Marines. Lots of cheesy gimmicky hoorah American Hero moments that made the movie feel cheap. I like my military movies when they're actually done like military styled movies and not a recruitment advertisement of things that don't even happen in the Armed forces. I think Battle Los Angeles was the worst of these type of films. This was watchable because it had more alien interaction. I didn't realize that this was a movie about the board game battleship until someone pointed that out to me. The entire time I kept wondering how the aliens came all the way from such a distant planet but had such primitive weapons technology. It didn't seem to fit with what you'd expect from advanced life forms. Aside from the movie feeling like a cheap military commercial I didn't dislike the characters. There were some good ones like the Marine that lost his legs and... uh well I can't remember anyone else but him, I think he should have been the star of the movie.

reviewText: First, let's address "suspension of belief." Every movie or TV show requires it. What, there REALLY IS a private-eye like Magnum living in crime ridden Hawaii working for a never seen Robin Masters who lets our Magnum zoom around the island in his Ferrari? You mean crime scene investigators from New York to South Beach to Las Vegas really do work in glass tabled, state of the art, heavily stylized labs? There really is an unbiased media (ahhh! Just kidding. No politics in this review!).I went to see "Battleship", based on the Hasbro game, not knowing what to expect. Maybe it would be good. After all, there was already a very good "Rock'em Sock'em Robots" movie (not based on the classic kids game) last year called "Real Steel." So...I was really surprised with "Battleship." And (semi-spolier alert): thankfully...THANKFULLY...no one says "Hey, you sank my battleship.""Battleship" might be the most fun summer movie since "Die Hard." It's a combination of "Top Gun", spritzed with "War of the Worlds." It's funny at times, serious at times and a schmaltzy at times. What more could you ask for in a summer movie?! AC/DC on the soundtrack? Yeah, it's got that too.Let's not confuse the issue here: this isn't "Ghandi" or "Fried Green Tomatoes" or "The Artist." It's a hang on to your suspension of belief, big Hollywood, blockbusting, metal crushing, Alien butt kicking summer movie that isn't way over the top or goofy under-done. And, they found creative ways to work in the classic concepts of the Hasbro game that won't make you groan. It's a fun summer movie that fits every expectation of what that means.I give "Battleship" my highest recommendation.

reviewText: Okay, okay... now -I've reviewed Stanley Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey" and the lastest version of "The Tempest" -both of which are excellent, extremely well done movies.  But just like with metal (the music genre): there's "thinking man's metal" and "down and dirty, beat you up metal"... This movie is more akin to the latter -just don't think about it.I heard and read about all the angst this movie received from reviewers and even moviegoers.  Now, I'm not saying it's the best thing since "Citizen Kane" or something retarded, but this movie is actually pretty good -for a "turn your brain off, aliens attack, sci-fi flick" -that involves the U.S. Navy.First off, the movie has some (genuinely) funny moments that don't come across scripted (per se).  Second, the story/plot -while not over emphasizing using all your gray matter to figure out, is simple. Aliens come here, want to take over -we kick their a**! (Well, the U.S. Navy does but still, you get the picture)... Third, Taylor Kitsch isn't Tom Hanks but he did a pretty good job in leading the movie... He may not be a "name" star yet, but who cares!?This movie shows the U.S. Navy in a very positive light (similar to "Top Gun") and honestly, maybe I'm biased because I'm pro military, but I really believe the negative hype against this movie is undeserved. This isn't a "perfect" movie, nor is it a thinking man's movie... It's sci-fi action flick -period.Look, if you believe the hype then don't even watch this movie.  You have to want to give it a chance.  Again, it isn't THE MOST AWE INSPIRING MOVIE EVER MADE, but it is a fun popcorn flick with great special effects and the U.S. Navy kicking some alien butt. This movie is similar to "Independence Day" in that respect -don't take it so seriously and look for flaws and plot holes -cause you'll find'em. Enjoy it for what it is. Give it a watch -it's fun!!!  Just don't forget the popcorn :)
summary: Why all the hate for this movie?
Title: N/A

reviewText: This will be my first and perhaps only movie review and I'll tell you exactly why below. When you're 5 minutes into a flick and you're saying to yourself..this better improve quickly, you know that it's just going to get worse.I was infuriated after wasting my time watching this flick. I thought to myself...Hey, Liam Neeson is in this movie. It can't be too bad, right? WRONG! I honestly think he just showed up for the paycheck here. And considering that he is well off and not hard up for the dough, he should be ashamed of himself. I saw John Carradine in some major stinkers but I can forgive him because he actually needed the money. Now that we've come to the conclusion that this is by far THE worst film Liam Neeson has been in, we shall continue.. This film is everything that is wrong with modern, mainstream American films! They insult our intelligence on so many levels it's ridiculous. Heck, I've had more enjoyment watching bad 80's slashers than this dreck! I can usually turn my brain off with crap like this but not with this particular film. This was like watching one of those "made for the SyFy channel flicks" with a huge budget and better special effects. All the worst labels apply to this film basically. Formulaic, generic, manufactured sappiness, bad rock music(they could have at least had Bon Scott era AC/DC!), Overacting, mindless action with no point, overblown special effects and explosions that try to divert you from the lack of any cohesive story, etc..etc.. I can usually forgive one or two of these aspects being attributed to said film in question but this stinker has practically no redeeming value. Unless you're the primitive type that likes to watch rednecks light fireworks for hours on end.And what was up with the cheesy patriotism where we are always the good guys? I felt like I was watching another Conservative propaganda flick like "Red Dawn". What is this? A recruitment vehicle for the military? Macho indoctrination for the naive and easily led? And this movie so disrespects WW11 veterans by making them robots that won't question any of the orders they are being given. How about a bit more humanity and intelligence from these characters. My grandfathers who DID fight in WW11 would have been offended by how the veterans are portrayed in this flick. As mere canon fodder for all the awful aspects that films like this represent. If movies like this and bad reality shows continue to grow in popularity, there is absolutely no hope for the future of America. We will become a mindless, consumer society where very few have individual thought, perception, and intellect. And that is exactly what the corrupt among us want. "1984". It's an excellent book and a warning to us. Should be required reading in high schools all across this Nation.And now my parting words. Peter Berg should never be allowed to direct again(or at least he should take his name off this flick and apply the Alan Smithee tag) and who ever wrote this script should be prohibited from ever writing ANYTHING! They say a flick like "Plan 9 From Outer Space" is one of the worst movies ever. I so disagree with this assessment. It's movies like "Battleship" which are the worst films. At least "Plan 9" was amusing, funny, and didn't take itself seriously. I at least can get SOME entertainment value out of that. Not with "Battleship" however. This movie was so bad, it was just BAD!!! If you haven't seen this flick, the best advice I can give you is to avoid it at all costs. You can do so much better when it comes to "Alien invasion" films. And no, I'm not talking about "Independence Day" either. Start with one of the best that has a great message and intelligent story. A flick that doesn't glorify the military/industrial complex. That being the original "The Day The Earth Stood Still"(1951). Hollywood today could learn alot from classic films like this. Stop dumbing us down, so you can make more profit! Thanks for reading. If I saved one person from seeing "Battleship", I will consider this review a job well done! Plus, check rottentomatoes.com and imdb.com for more well deserved, negative reviews of this atrocious waste of money.
summary: A formulaic commercial for the Military that dumbs down everyone!!

reviewText: This movie is easy to attack on many levels. Items like the fact that the aliens often just let the warships sit there and don't finish them off for long periods of time. BUT it's still a fun romp in which the navy saves the world! And in this day of endless antimilitary movies it's refreshing to see and promilitary movie!.  This one borrows from all the recent alien invasion flicks in many ways but it differs in that it's the Navy that's that's doing hte fighting. The part that probably drove some people mad was they way they used bouys to simulate radar and you had red strikes similiar to the GAME battleship. Still this movie runs very quickly and is full of action. the aliens are very humanoid in this flick and that may not be to some peoples liking. The blu ray looks great and this movie had a monster budget, which it didn't make back unfortunately for it's studio. Still The huge budget shows here and the film is a good way to spend a few mindless hours of entertainment. There is a made for dvd film called 'american battleship" that is also promilitary and actually features more fighting with a battleship against aliens!. That one is low budget but still worth watching if you enjoyed this film. Sure this is not great cinema , but it's fun cinema , and cinema that is very familiar to fans of modern sci fi.

reviewText: Battleship is a decent action sci-fi movie with a darn good cast, great special effects and a decent story. Now I'm not going to BS you and say that it had a great screenplay. But, when compared with a lot of other action movies I've seen lately, it's practically Shakespear. The dialogue was was crisp and didn't get lost in technical mumbo jumbo as it might have. I don't remember hearing any profanity. If there was any it just didn't register. So it's pretty suitable for youngsters.The story begins with NASA sending messages of friendship and good will to a newly discovered planet outside our solar system. While this is going on we meet Alex Hopper, a long haired deadbeat with $60 to his name and a Navy officer as an older brother. Alex's brother was played by Alexander Skarsgard, my wife's favorite actor on True Blood. Stone Hopper (Skarsgard) reads his little brother the riot act for being a loser and convinces him to join the Navy and do something with his life.One thing about this movie that impressed me was the timeline. Most sci-fi movies don't take the truly vast distances of space into account. Battlship does by virtue of the fact that the aliens don't respond to NASA's message of friendship for many years. Since it would take 3 or more years for a message to reach another star, that makes sense. Also, it gives Alex time to go to OCS and work his way up to LT in the Navy - 6 or more years.So as the Aliens are preparing respong to NASA greeting with overwhelming force, Alex is preparing to ask Admiral (Liam Neeson) Shane for his daughter's hand in marraige. But before he can do so he gets in a fight with a visiting Japanese officer, and learns that the Navy is tired of his antics and plans to kick him to the curb. But before all that can happen the Aliens launch their attack on various Pacific Ocean targets. Alex and his crew must defend humankind from alien stormtroopers. When the senior officers get killed, Alex becomes commanding officer aboard his ship and takes on the aliens. I'm not going to give the rest of the plot away. But the script is tight, and the ending just what it should be.By the way, a special mention should go to Colonel Gregory Gadson, Army veteran who plays a double amputee who's given up on himself, but finds the strenght to defend America one last time. Gadson, who lost both legs above the knees in Iraq, was offered this role by director Peter Berg. Despite being a professional soldier, not an actor, Gadson brought a real deapth to this character.Battleship did have 2 things going against it. (1) It came out after the mediocre Battle: Loas Angeles and the horrific crapfest that was Skyline.(2) It was marketed as a film adaption of the 1970s game Battleship. Aside from about a 6 minute segment, I didn't see much to connect the movie to the game.Now this movie isn't going to win any awards. I'd imagine that just about every film critic in North America hated it. But it was good clean fun with over the top special effects, but not the bone chilling gore of some movies in the genre. Fun for the hole family...except mom.
summary: Fun for the whole family...except mom.

reviewText: The beginning of the movie was impressively promising. I soon expected a travel to the newly discovered planet outside the solar system with exotically parallel life.My waiting did not last before the setting moved into a bar with two men, one impressing a woman and got arrested for breaking into a restaurant for a hamburger. From here on, the rest of the movie was greatly disappointing.The trouble maker joined the Navy, ran into strange objects in the oceans, that extended throughout the movie, with constant explosions and destruction to destroy the aliens, who took all the troubles to visit us.The most disappointing feeling was leaving the theater with the sense that we wasted great opportunities to connect with aliens for the sake of grabbing laughter over stolen hamburger, mediocre love story built on sex and good look, and greed for fast money making by turning the big screen into endless violence.A science fiction movie that could have transcended universes by enriching the imagination of viewers ended by preying on the viewers desires to get rocked and wasted in battles of fire and explosions.Mohamed F. El-Hewie

reviewText: I can remember as a younger father playing the Hasbro game with my kids.  I also have a vague recollection of playing a version as a kid myself using a pencil and paper but that could be just dead brain cells floating around.  Speaking of dead brain cells...with a movie like "Battleship" it is usually a good idea to set the bar low (pick a Michael Bay movie) and just relax.  For me, I use the second "Transformers" movie "Revenge of the Fallen" as my standard.Here we have some early scenes that actually aren't bad and begin to flesh out the characters.  The focus is on bad boy, Alex Hopper (Taylor Kitsch) who somehow becomes a U. S. Navy officer at the insistence of his big brother, Stone (Alexander Skarsgard) who already is a Commander.  Unless memory again fades, having been in the Navy myself it is unlikely that they would accept a drunken felon into their officer corps (i.e. Alex) but maybe things have changed.While this is a minor nit not worth picking, there are so many other flawed aspects of the film, it can't be taken seriously.  The good news is that the movie is wildly, if absurdly, entertaining.  It is decently constructed with a beginning, middle and an end.  The movie is extremely loud at times, especially when the alien visitors take offense at being threatened and launch their razor sharp ball bearing thingies.  I mean, the Earthlings did invite them, right?  All is well that ends well, especially when you have the mothballed (yet battle ready!) U.S.S. Missouri easily launched with a skeleton crew (pun intended).
summary: An entertaining film that follows the alien invader formula

reviewText: Battleship is a movie about huge boats with tons of guns blasting the absolute stuffing out of each other. Some of the boats are from space and as a result look all cool and science-fiction-ey, albeit in a somewhat generic way. The alien invaders' ships have a technological edge on Earth's navy, but both fleets are able to deal fairly significant damage to one another. The result is a lot of epic, loud naval combat which is more than a little reminiscent of Japanese nautical adventure comics. Is it then a coincidence that this movie has a prominent Japanese principal (Tadanobu Asano) and premiered in Japan? Surely not. But that's by no means a bad thing- strong foreign cast members and badass naval combat are far too lacking in modern American cinema.The effects for the sea battles are extremely good, and the alien enemies themselves, though rather as generic as their boats, stand out as a high point- they are neither as wantonly evil and bestial as science fiction invaders tend to be, nor as grossly overpowered. When one of their number is captured, they rescue him(?) in a commando raid, and they depend on stealth, sabotage, and cunning to a degree that is usually reserved for the wily human underdogs in such films. Compared to the forgettable Wing Commander movie, in which the noble and cunning Kilrathi were reduced to snarling beast-men with Wolverine claws, the aliens in Battleship are interesting and exciting. They also serve as a warning against dependance on technology over judgment in wartime: most of their blunders result from an over-reliance on friend-or-foe systems in their helmets that allow human combatants to escape certain doom by standing down. This message about brains over science is also played out among the humans themselves- the navy doesn't really clean house until they abandon their modern but technologically vulnerable ships in favor of a thousand tons of antique, cannon-toting battleship (the name has to come in somewhere, right?).So the battleship part of Battleship is a 4 or 5 star film. But it gets dragged down by its opening 30 minutes. These are not exciting, alien battling, swashbuckling, exploding minutes- they are framing in which we learn how our protagonist Taylor Kitsche is a super irresponsible guy who will rob a convenience store to impress a girl (it works). Kitche's character somehow makes second lieutenant in about a year in spite of angering admiral Liam Neeson and constantly disappointing his brother Alexander Skarsgrd, who cannot be bothered to suppress his Swedish accent even when he is playing an all-American military man. This misguided block of exposition is punctuated by irritating editing, poorly selected musical scoring, and an uncanny resemblance to a Red Skelton USO sketch, which I must assume is deliberate, and by extension, a horrible idea. You will have to fight hard to keep watching by the 10 minute mark, and when the aliens finally show up to explode stuff, they sort of feel like the heroes.Pros:-Great effects-Surprisingly plausible interstellar war-Enough sprays of missiles, explosions, and churning engines to please the most jaded anime nerd or dieselpunk aficionadoCons:-Horrible characterization-Awful music choices (the end credits employ CCR's Fortunate Son, which I'm pretty sure is a song about how hard it sucks to be in the military and get ordered around by money men and pencil pushers, and is an odd choice in a film where the heroes fight an unavoidable, self-directed war against a totally clean hostile target)-Odd conclusion (with the alien fleet beaten, EVERYONE JUST ASSUMES EARTH IS SAFE IMMEDIATELY (of course there's a post-credit scene to remind us it totally isn't)Conclusion:Better than any film based on a board game has a right to be, Battleship only hits its mark when the shells are flying, and as a result is an entertaining film but not a very good one.
summary: A great naval action film brought down by cringe-inducing everything else

reviewText: Totally blown away by this movie. There was never a boring moment, even though it is about 2 hours long it never seems like it. You totally get caught up in the movie, due in large part to the great dialog and acting. The CGI is top notch also which is always great because it helps to keep you immersed in the movie.The action in this movie is insane. Once it starts it never stops. There are plenty of great explosions, and fighting scenes. If you are a fan of Battle Los Angeles you are guaranteed to love this movie. My favorite part is when the Veterans step up, you can feel the pride and love for their country, and that is due to them using actual Veterans.This is a must see, must buy movie. That's right don't rent, buy it, cause trust me you are going to want to see it again and again!

reviewText: I don't remember hearing a good thing about this when it first came out - and so my expectations having been set correspondingly low, I came away rather pleasantly surprised.  In tone, scale and aspiration this is aTransformers Trilogy (Transformers / Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen / Transformers: Dark of the Moon) [Blu-ray] clone - it's even generated by the same toy company, Hasbro.  How you feel about a movie whose success hinges on how good its special effects are and how gorgeous the cast are, above such other criteria such as, say, acting or script, will largely determine how much you enjoy this movie.Plot-wise, slacker Taylor Kitsch has been encouraged to join the Navy by his high performing brother, under the gruff command of Admiral Liam Neeson.  He does this to win the hand of the Admiral's unfeasibly gorgeous daughter who seems to serve no purpose other than wearing ultra tight denim shorts and straddling Taylor in provocative poses, and who is inexplicably drawn to him.  Things get complicated when Aliens land in the ocean next to a huge naval exercise and their intentions are clearly more Decepticon than Autobot...  When the action kicks off, it's all wildly over the top, and yet done with such excellent effects and solid editing (hooray, Michael Bay-like frenetic editing has been dialed down so you can actually see what's going on..) that there's quite a lot of fun to be had.  Rihanna is surprisingly underplayed in a supporting role, Liam Neeson is.. well, Liam Neeson and the rest of the cast ably put Tab A into Slot B for their respective prescribed character developments.As a US Navy propaganda it actually works well, in a Top-Gun-at-sea sort of way. The effects are genuinely quite impressive, with stuff blowing up, vaporizing and blasting around in a way that actually seems to look realistic, even if physicists will struggle not to place their head in their hands and shake it at some of the plot points (why DO radio waves beamed into space need to be a striking white beam of light that zings and shimmers..?).  I found the time went fairly quickly and chuckles and thrills outweighed the cringing. Not at all as bad as the nay-sayers would have you believe, and fun if you can suspend disbelief long enough.
summary: Not A1, but not sunk either

reviewText: Well, once again, I let myself be swayed by the critics and I didn't see this movie at the theater.  But I purchased the Blu-Ray.  The critics are STUPID.  This was a great movie.  It's along the lines of Transformers, but better.  The action was great.  Just the perfect balance between character-development and action.  The story made you care about the characters in the movie.  The special effects were awesome.  The special features were also great, especially the full tour of the battleship USS Missouri.  This was a well-done film that is engaging and authentic to the ships it portrays.  Don't be swayed by jaded negative reviews you see here.  This is a great movie that deserved better than the critics gave it.  One more lessen on how jaded critics are.
summary: Much Better That The Critics Rated

reviewText: Made by the same folks that gave us the TRANSFORMER movies, and given that this movie is similar in nature (mankind vs. alien machine) I think the best way to review this movie for you is to make some comparisons...The story is pretty good, the aliens themselves were no big deal to speak of as they were very similar to bald human males with reptile eyes and 4 fingers for hands (like the claws in those arcade machines where you try to grab a stuffed animal).  Their ships were pretty cool (but unlike "transformers" they had no personality and couldn't change into different things) and it was a little disappointing they fired almost ordinary bombs. There were some smaller ships that were fairly unique and deadly.The camera work was the same as in the Transformers movies, where in the heat of action they are in too tight and you mostly just get to see blur instead of the orchestrated/choreographed action (and I always hate when movies do that).I think the main problem with this movie is that you just don't really care about the main character - he's an idiot, lacking charm/personality and often intelligence/maturity. And truthfully, I think the blame for it is more the actor than the script. But it's a big problem for a movie when they can't get you to like the main characters. (The black woman who fires the ships weapons was very good, and so was the big black Army guy with the steel legs -- they were smaller supporting roles, but you like and care about them).Overall it was disappointing but not horrible because some parts of this were pretty cool, but it's not one I'd recommend or care to watch again myself. (And I'll think hard about watching another movie with the guy who had the lead in this as I expect his acting will always be like this)
summary: Disappointing overall, but some cool parts

reviewText: One may think that this is the usual genre of 'earth vs alien,' but this film has more twists and turns than a CIA spy novel.  The story line starts with a young man, who has got to be one of the original misfits of his generation.  He gets thrown into the navy and just happens to be in the middle of an international war games exercise in the Pacific with multiple nations.  Who decides to join the fun but, an invasion of aliens from another planet, intent upon conquering the  earth.  Throw in a romance with the Admiral's daughter, knock-down-drag-out fight with the aliens, and the entrance into the fray by the Battleship USS Missouri commanded by our hero, and you have one h--- of a story line, not to mention enough action to keep even the most jaded of gamers, very occupied.  I was very forturnate, to be assigned to the 25th Infantry Division, when the "Big Mo" arrived in Pearl Harbor.  All active duty and retired personnel were invited to a special tour of this magnificient ship.  You just cannot believe the size, grandeur, and unbelveable  magnificience of this ship.  It is now permanently anchored as a musieum on the other side of USS Arizona Memorial.  If you visit Hawaii, do not miss this!!  This movie deserves a place in your DVD collection.  IT IS AMAZING HOW ONE CAN RISE TO THE OCCASION WHEN LEADERSHIP IS REQUIRED!!  NJMJr.

reviewText: I did not like  'Battle: Los Angeles'. It had corny dialogue, irritating shakey cam, and a plot line you didn't want to spend any brain power to decipher.  'Battleship' thought makes Battle:LA look like 'Battleship Potemkin' in comparison. One of the most poorly executed films of the year, 'Battleship' will certainly find a home in some future 'Mystery Science Theater' show or midnight cult classic screening. If only it took itself a little less seriously and ramped up the humor, it could have been a perfect 'park your brains in neutral' hoot.The film will probably find it's audience anyway among the perpetual 8-years olds among us and might even make back the obscenely large amount of cash it cost to produce. The script is awful and the acting is wooden and embarrassing. Watch Liam Neeson stumbled throught this film and feel sorry for him. Count up the bad lines written into the script and feel pity for the actors.  Luckily the use of CGI is very good  Water effects are very difficult to do. We have seen this CGI before but love for cinema visual trickery will still has us thrilled with the scenes of battles on the ocean between the US Navy and invading aliens.The non-actors, or perhaps they are actual Navy vets that were recruited to play battleship on the USS Missouri were also fun to watch.  They outshined the regular cast by their mere presence and physical reality.We also should celebrate the presence of another of the film's standout performance, so to speak, that of Brooklyn Decker's chest. It should have gotten an ending credit in itself.This film 'Battleship' is what happens when you attempt to base a movie on a board game. No story, no character, and enough plot holes to drive a battleship through. Suprisingly enough  the producers manage to insert the actual board game into the plot near the end of the film about some sort of grid-like tsunami warning system which will have most of the more knowledgeable audience members scratching their heads in disbelief at its sheer stupidity. But hey, after the opening scenes comical missteps, we could believe anything. 'Battleship' is filled with military errrors. It is the type of film that would have actual Navy personnel rolling in the aisles watching all the mistakes make about military life. Incredulity begins almost immediately after the start of the film when we are offered a lengthy barroom brawl, car chase, break-in sequence with Taylor Kitsch in search of a chicken taco which would then have us believe that Taylor Kitsch could then joins the Navy as an officer and in the next scene (with little of no time transition) appears to us as a Navy lieutenant. If we could believe that,  we could believe anything.Watch this film, for free if you can, if you need an evening of emptiness or if you like CGI work. Otherwise save your time and read a book instead.

reviewText: Given this movie is somehow related to the 'Battleship' board game, I entered it with very low expectations.  Sadly, my expectations were not nearly low enough.  Looking back, nothing could have prepared me for the movie...nay...abomination that is 'Battleship.'  I am not the type of person who watches movies for some deep message or an armchair Oscar elitist wannabe.  I enjoy movies like Transformers and other pointless Michael Bay films chock full of explosions.  Still, the movie should have at least SOME sign that the writers gave a damn.  I suspect Hasbro got some 5 year old to write this movie.  It is just so bad and doesn't make any sense.  I have not had many regrets in life, but watching this was definitely one of them.  I would pass on this movie without hesitation.Pros:- CGI for the big ships was good.Cons:- Storyline/plot is so bad that if all the characters were annihilated in the first 5 minutes I would not have given a damn- characters were pointless, they could have been replaced by anyone really and it wouldn't have mattered- acting, I can't bash the acting too much because when you're given zero quality material what can you really do right?- alien design/costumes was lame- camera movement was like some bad martial arts movie compensating for the bad fighting
summary: Quite Possibly the Worst Movie Ever

reviewText: I give this movie 5 stars strictly on fun factor alone. The plot is simple enough to not lose itself anywhere. Not that there is much in the way of things that could be said and be considered spoilers, but I'll keep my description brief anyway. Basically, the misfit brother of a Naval officer gets arrested trying to steal a chicken burrito for the uber hot chica in the flick and is basically forced to enlist in the NAvy himself where he is made an officer. Of course, things happen (namely an alien invasion) and said misfit ends up as the ranking officer in the arena, where he, his crew, and a few other people are forced to squash said alien invasion by themselves. Now, you basically know the entire plotline, lol.So, why did I enjoy this movie? Many reason actually. It was a big, visually pleasing movie. The battles between the human and alien ships were super cool, and the alien technology in particular was really neat and very devastating. The aliens themselves were pretty well thought out in a slightly more advanced than, but not completely dissimilar to humanity sort of way. Their armor in particular was quite reminiscent of the Mjolnir armor from the Halo game series. The interaction between the characters was also pretty funny, and there were plenty of enjoyable moments in that regard. The cast was spot on, and was tailored to a younger crowd. From o-boy of John Carter fame to Rihanna, there was plenty to relate to, and for us older folks, well...there was Liam Neeson and a whole host of crotchety old navy shipmen. The audio for the movie was also quite big, and completely complimentary to the visuals. Last, the way in which they tied the battle structure in the movie to that of the game itself was very cool.So, while not a writers opus, this movie was certainly enjoyable, and I think you will have found your time to be well spent.Enjoy!

reviewText: Street guy (though stylized), underacheiver, with successful older Brother, is convinced to join the Navy...grow up...do the right thing.His final statement as disheveled barfly is to break into a convenience store to steal a barrito (?) for the shockingly beautiful daughter of a Navy Commander..who decides to enter a neighborhood dive for said treat...too late...bar tender can't open the freezer door and look for the microwave. (typical government worker - jk). Then the tribute to Cable TV's "World's Dumbest CRiminals"...a mock-video surveillance tape where the dude falls violently from the rafters but accomplishes his mission. Actually a well-crafted and hilarious scene.His next screw up is to approach a UFO sitting out there off the coast of Hawaii..he bangs on the outside of the thing...then the fireworks. Is it..the end of the world?Thus, he gains confidence and knowledge (too bad he gets his Brother blown up in the fallout from his  "curiosity"). But this endears him to his "love interest"...who, by the way, not just a shocking blonde beauty but a physical therapist who works miracles for everyone she meets.Will our hero save the planet *and* get engaged to her?Just short of three stars. Special effects: phenomenal. Acting: pretty good.[Review based upon Theatre viewing].
summary: Combo of Independence Day, Dear John, and Blue Hawaii

reviewText: I would just like to say 'thank you' to all the haters. I had very low expectations because of all the negative reviews, but this movie was a non-stop action extravaganza. It has very little to do with the classic board game, but that doesn't take away from the fun. This is truly a summer blockbuster. Alex Hopper is the lazy slacker brother of  Commander Stone Hopper. When Alex gets arrested, trying to impress the daughter of Admiral Shane, Stone makes him join the United States Navy. Seven years later, Alex is still a slacker but he must step up his game during the  RIMPAC naval exercises. During the same time, five alien spaceships crash land in the sea. They begin to attacks the ships. Alex is forced to become the leader and fight back against the aliens. Like I said, this film is extremely action-packed and worthy of a viewing. I highly recommend BATTLESHIP!!!

reviewText: BattleshipCreative with a touch of Nostalgia. I especially liked the way they employed the short comings of computer operated weapons systems verses old style manual methods. The failure of computers in a wartime scenario is a real and probable scenario. The old timers going back into action 70 years later gave me real goose bumps and a true feeling of American National Pride. The aliens and their technology were believable. Their vulnerability reminded me that this is not the first time American ingenuity has triumphed over seemingly invincible enemy forces. My father is one of the few WWII Veterans still alive who played a part in it all. Unfortunately, the only unwinnable battle our proud warriors have ever had to face is the Veterans Administration! Buy this movie and you will be entertained for sure.

Title: N/A

reviewText: Ok. Honest review. I'll give credit where it's due. The movie looks great. Special effects wise. The acting is plausible at best. However, the movie has no focus, no real story and felt incomplete. I got bored halfway through. I've seen thousands of movies and many action, alien, alien invader movies. Not all of them are good, not all bad. Great special effects are a dime a dozen nowadays. I expect an at least plausible story. This movie doesn't explain anything about the aliens' purpose. They came to destroy the earth?  Not evident here. They just 'crash' on earth. Then an irritating lead Navy character does something stupid, as they have him do from film's beginning, and then fighting begins. And I notice the battles are instigated mostly by humans. Ok. Give me a reason to root for the good guys. I mean, the aliens even scan humans and refuse to kill them. What exactly is going on? Once again not explained. It almost seemed like the aliens here are accidental bad guys. There's a point in the movie that a guy says that we're facing an extinction level event. What event exactly? They still don't explain it. Did the writers say to themselves that, to the audience, aliens automatically equal bad guys we have to destroy? No explanation needed? Ah no. Independence Day,  Predator, War of the Worlds, Alien, Close Encounters, E.T., Transformers. All alien stories. All with a clear purpose and determination of good or bad and motive. No such thing in this. I wasn't even invested in the human characters. The only one wad the main lead who was an irresponsible idiot that was made into a paper hero. I never got a sense that he became a better man. This was just a loud special effect advertisement for the Navy. Glad I did not pay to see this at the theater.

reviewText: It's a better movie that you might think.  It's a very successful "summer blockbuster" three-star movie that gets four stars for execution.  As others have said the effects are spot on.  The main character is pretty flat, even with the attempt at making him three-dimensional - but it didn't really matter because it was plenty enough for us to root for him.*** mini-spoilers ahead:  ***As to the complaints about the aliens being "dumb", one character notes more than once that it's as if they are Chris Columbus coming to America and we're the "Indians".  So... think about it.  When the Europeans came to the Americas, they didn't try to kill everyone.  They came and if the native people were nice, other than disease, they left it alone more or less.  But if the natives were aggressive then they were attacked.  If you pay attention you'll notice the aliens don't shoot first.  I thought of it as the aliens were making some attempt at peaceful approach but fought to stay alive, and were individuals in that some were trigger happy and others were possibly pacifist and maybe don't agree with the alien invasion plans... maybe that's why... well you'll see.*** end spoilers ***Last note:  Don't miss the end of the credits.  ;-)

reviewText: Frankly this is not a bad movie. It had a good idea and was pretty cool. Lets not kid ourselves here i would say roughly every 10 years someone makes a movie about the Navy. Usually in reference to submarines or SEALs. This is the first modern naval war film i know of that doesn't focus on submarines. I'm not too sure why people don't like it. It has a hero, a villan, big guns, and cool effects. It should be well liked. I think the problem is people walk in expecting something that will be off the charts like Inception or something that makes you think a lot during the movie. While this movie will make you think (mainly on how they could possibly win). You wont be mentally thinking to the extent of Inception or some other generally thought provoking film. This film doesn't ask much of its viewers except to sit and watch. It will lay the ground work and walk you through every step.This is a Naval Warfare film so you cant really expect too many twists and turns and curve balls. I will certainly admit that it is not a film for everyone, if your someone who absolutely demands films to leave you awestruck and blown away then this is not a film that i would recommend to you. Because odds are you wouldn't appreciate the subtle awesome things of this film that a Veteran or a military buff would get. Such as when the USS Missouri power slides then fires off those massive 16.5 cannons.This film does show a rebel Naval Officer turning into the officer he is needed to be. This film shows you Naval Firepower at its finest and is the only film i know of that gives the ships this much screen time. You see ships in plenty of films (such as all 3 Transformers but never do they get this much screen time). Then again you would expect this from a film named Battleship. It will certainly appeal to veterans and anyone interested in the mean grey machines that rule the seas. Would certainly be best understood by any military personnel who understand the sacrifice portrayed when the ships go down. Its my opinion that unless you have written that blank check to your country that is payable up to your life then you'll never really understand that sacrifice portrayed.I'm telling you now if you expect a film that provokes deep thought within yourself then this isn't a film for you and I'd advise you continue your search. Because you won't find it here. This film is really good at making you think 1.HOLY CRAP THAT IS AWESOME! 2. I wonder what would really happen in that situation of aliens showing up. and maybe 3. would i be willing to take that risk if i were in their shoes?I found this film to be outstanding and was certainly glad that for once my friends in the Navy who serve on the ships got their due credit. I found this film to be so good i watched it and 30min later i watched it again.I cannot stress enough that people who demand films of the highest quality wont be impressed. However people who like to see heros overcome adversity and overwhelming odds to win the day will enjoy this film.In my opinion its a good film.
summary: Finally a modern film that shows that saliors are heros too.

reviewText: You could say that I am actually quite childish as far as my taste for movies goes.. so an action/sci-fi/special effect movie must be bad, really bad for me to dislike it.. but trust me, this one is!I understand that this kind of movie is "just entertainment" and should not be "analyzed" too seriously.. but to try to enjoy this flick you actually have to completely sink your mind..You 're supposed to swallow the fact that one of the spaceships of a race advanced enough to deal with interstellar travelling can't do anything better than smash into a satellite while approaching the earth and getting destroyed by it. Then we are told that the spaceships are going toward some sort of astronomical radio station in the Hawaii.. and that should be because they lost their communication spaceship.. never mind the fact that they started targeting the station *before* that ship crashed...Then for some mysterious reason the alien ships after creating a huge energy shield to isolate the Hawaii do not attack and destroy the us and Japanese destroyers trapped in the energy field unless those ships fire on them first and happily ignore all the others...and these should be aliens keen on destroying the humans?? Actually if you follow the action with a minimum of attention you realize that it's actually the US navy who fires the first lethal weapon and starts the conflict.. I don't think the authors themselves realized this, probably used to the fact that after WW 2 if a war starts it's usually the US who started it..Anyhow , as if this wasn't demential enough, we are supposed to believe that an emitter "five time more powerful than any before it"(wow!) who started communication in 2006 has made contact with aliens living on an earthlike planet just discovered by NASA..and caused them to show up on earth in just six years time... too bad that there are only 4 stars in a 6 light years radius..and the closest is more than 4 light years away..which leaves less the 2 years for the aliens to rush towards Earth faster than light to crash one of their ships (the most important one , of course..) on a puny satellite.. and of course these superadvanced aliens who can defy the most advanced physics we know have to wait for us to discover their planet..Come on! Who writes this stuff???  I suppose who wrote this stuff assumed that the average public watching this flick would not have the faintest culture about modern physics and astronomy.. but still! (or maybe the authors themselves did not have the faintest idea about physics..)Or is it actually forbidden for some reasone to make a sci-fi movie that has a little respect for the "sci part" in its genre?And even forgetting about science and limiting ourselves at common sense I know military and government are usually not the brightest people on the planet, but if they want to stop this communication link, instead of trying to destroy the observatory, *why don't they blow the damn satellite up???*  And it goes on, and on , and on with nonsense after nonsense..Even a kid could have written something better than this with 5 minutes of thinking.. like the aliens wanting to fight a "human champion vs alien champion" battle to respect some form of cultural code before invading the planet.. or if you want the classic "tension builder" of having to avoid some terrible impending disaster, how about the alien created a shielded base to settle , build more weapons and machinery and maybe some sort of "final weapon" that they could not bring along in the interstellar travel?And do we want to talk about the abysmal acting quality? Or the stereotypical, "plastic", monodimensional characters? You're really left with the impression that someone had some self over CGI effect from the transformer series and hastily put together this demential story to squeeze some more cash out of them...
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Richard C. Drew "Anaal Nathra/Uthe vas Bethod...
reviewText: You know it's going to be bad when you know the reply to almost every line or situation. The script was totally predictable formula and sounds like it was written by a 18 year old video store clerk. "Dude, I've watched like every SciFi video in this store, like, you know, 5 million times! I can write a way-cool script!" This is the result.The rendering of the aliens and alien armor was the best part of the movie. Apart from that, why did they make this POS? The plot holes, story idiocracies - way too many to list.  Hmm. A ship's window can withstand re-entry, submersion to hundreds of feet, mini-meteorite strikes - you name it, but a 50 cal goes right through? Er, no.  A mothballed battleship gets underway in an hour or so, with tons (literally) of explosives and rounds? Really? REALLY?! A ship that REQUIRES a crew of hundreds to operate, magically works with a couple of dozen people, most of whom can hardly walk.If you watch this, you'll find yourself hitting the FF button through the first 25 minutes (total waste of time, terrible and pointless back-story), plus on and off throughout the movie.  I'll guess you'll skip over 50% of the movie. That's the great part of BlueRay - 4x and you can still see the picture."Acting" - this is what passes for acting? Wow. Remember the lawsuits and outcry over the SciFi channel airing a movie called "American Battleship" - a total rip-off of this movie, by a company that makes it's living ripping off other movies. Guess what? "American Battleship" - the no-name, lousy movie with no-name actors is better than this abomination.Two stars for the aliens. They should have cut all the game-related battleship B.S., trashed the stupid and pointless "hunt" and made it about the aliens and their armor.  But then again, the one time there was an opportunity to have a great scene, the alien got his butt kicked by a guy with two fake legs. Riiiight. A suit that bounces .223's like a windshield deflects mosquitoes, shrugs of .45 rounds like so much rain off a boulder can get taken out by a bare knuckled buy with no legs.
summary: Unoriginal Drek, Armor is a Halo Rip-off, idiotic plot

reviewText: Battleship(released April/12)is another enterprise/film similar to Transformers(their property also)in look and feel.We have the great CGI effects and the grandiose musical score.The movie traveled along pretty well until about the 70 minute mark,then it seemed to lose its steam,failed to capture its initial excitement and coasted the rest of the way out.The film stars Taylor Kitsch as Lieutenant Alex Hopper,Liam Neeson as Admiral Terrance Shane,among others.The plot involves Kitsch as a smart but out of control 26 years old,with no solid direction in life and who lives with his brother,a commander in the Navy.After getting arrested his brother has had enough of his antics and enlists him in the Navy also.Fast forward and Kitsch is a lieutenant on board a destroyer.The back story to all this is that a group of scientists have found a planet outside our solar system that is much like earth and are sending signals to it via a sophisticated satellite array.Admiral Terrance puts his ship fleet on maneuvers along with several other countries,in the Pacific.While his ships are engaged in this,five alien objects enter earth's atmosphere with most flying into the ocean,while one crashes through the city of Hong Kong,creating much damage.While authorities are examining the wreckage of the Hong Kong crash and determining that it's metal is of unknown origin,things are happening in the waters near the fleet exercises.Kitsch has been put in charge of a destroyer and his crew examine some unusual objects sticking out of the water.While on top of one of the protrusions,Kitsch is zapped by an electrical current and thrown back.Suddenly the piece he was standing on raises out of the water and we see that it was a small part of a larger space craft,and they are not happy campers.Before you can say John Paul Jones the fight is on.The aliens have two very destructive weapons:first are hamburger shaped and wizzing dynamos which when they land destroy anything inanimate,and the second thing are smaller projectiles which impact a ships surface and almost immediately explode with usually fatal and horrific results(similar in shape to the pegs in the game Battleship).Both of these weapons are used to great success throughout the film,but at this point they almost completely disable and/or sink the fleet of ships in the area.They also throw up a round and enveloping bubble of energy,that is virtually impenetrable.This energy field essentially isolates a few of the fleet's ships while excluding the rest.It is a good way of protecting the alien's main contingent while also testing their battle skills against Earth's.Back in Hawaii where the space arrays were set up to contact the alien world,the aliens themselves have come to roost there.They need the array itself to send a message back to their home world,as it is believed the one that crashed into Hong Kong was its main communication device.Kitsch's girlfriend manages to contact Kitsch and tell him that the satellite that the dishes line up with,will be in sync in a short time and that he must destroy the arrays before they do.Out in the Pacific,what is left of the fleet is just one ship.Through the use of Tsunami buoys in the ocean(the idea of a Japanese commander),they calculate the positions of the alien ships.They eventually manage to destroy all three of the alien battle space ships but their last remaining battleship is destroyed;and they need to destroy the mother ship creating the large force field.They return to Pearl Harbour where Kitsch gets an idea to take out the old USS Missouri battleship,decommissioned since /92 and now a floating museum,and the only vessel within the energy bubble.With the help of some old vets,Kitsch gets his wish.They re-enter the fight and take down the remaining alien ship and the force field.Before the USS Missouri can be taken out by the aliens the fleet,previously on the outside looking in,now enters the fray and destroys the final ship along with the arrays.The film ends as everyone who survived is being awarded medals.The film is good until about the 70 minute mark.We had been intro'd to the main plot(attack of aliens and our reaction),and the side plot of the transmitting arrays;even the sub plot involving Kitsch and the admirals daughter.Up until that mark the film does a good job at integrating all plots and keeping the pace up.The film's pace slows considerably after the main battle is through and the filmmakers seem to want to concentrate too much on Kitschs's girlfriend and her involvement with the arrays,an amputee serviceman and one of the array techies.Of course it is germane to the story but after the wild battle ride we had just experienced,the rather slow pace and less exciting events on the ground seem a world away from what is happening out in the water;where the action really is.The film tries to get the dynamic up again,as events in the water start to build inexorably,but they never do reach the intensity of what had come initially.And besides this,whatever events do happen on the ground,they all originate from the battle out at sea.As an aside,I was wondering what Hasbro is doing these days with their properties,such as Transformers and this one,besides trying to make more money from them? Those games and toys were first discovered by kids way back when,and it is kids generally who still play with them.But these movies are not geared for kids,as they're way too intense.More like they're geared for the kids that have grown up and first discovered them when they first came out.Although I can see parents these days either still getting their kids into seeing these films and/or letting them watch the movie either when they rent or buy it on DVD;NOT recommended by me at any time.Finally this film is a tribute to armed forces veterans everywhere.They are present(real vets)in both official ceremonies in the beginning and at the end of the film.Also appearing is Gregory D. Gadson as Lieutenant Colonel Mick Canales.He is seen here as the double amputee and the man Kitsch's girlfriend is assigned to.Gadson is a well known and decorated war hero in real life and it was a really nice touch adding such a person to the acting roster.Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 1:85:1 and is clear and crisp.Extras include three featurettes.All in all a movie with a good potential,which they fulfill until about the 70 minute mark,then it all starts to unravel.This is an effects driven picture,in sound and look and should have been better than it was.Hasbro's Transformers got it the first time and fizzled out the second time.Maybe since they fizzled out the first time here,they will get it the second time around.3 1/2 stars.
summary: Comes on great guns,goes out with a fizzle

reviewText: A group of Navy ships encounter an alien spacecraft intent on doing bad things to the human race. It is up to surviving crew members to save the world. Loosely based on the classic board game, this action film contains the requisite noise, explosions, and fight scenes one would expect from a summer blockbuster. Don't take this one too seriously, as there are flaws in the storyline. There is certainly nothing new in this one, as it is another mindless action movie that will appeal to its target audience of young men, who will revel in the excitement and the visuals. This is a movie tailored to fans of the action-adventure genre who don't want to be challenged intellectually.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If your goal is to be entertained by science fiction special effects, you will love this movie.  It has some of the best CGI in any movie I have seen.  Every bit as good as Terminator Salvation and the recent Transformers movies.  I loved them.  But unlike these movies, there was no serious plot.  Or more accurately, the plot was so immature and the characters so one-dimensional and superficial that I was often rooting for the aliens to wipe them out.  This is a movie aimed at 12 year olds, not adults.  Even most teenagers will quickly turn this off in favor of a vampire love story.  Be warned.  The plot is very hard to take.That said, the special effects are worth getting the blu-ray.  You will find this movie much more enjoyable if you root for the aliens.
summary: Outstanding special effects severely damaged by a lack of story and superficial characters.

reviewText: A lot of this movie is just more metallic menace from outer space. However, there's a larger dose of humanity here than you usually find in movies heavy on explosive special effects. People have solid, individual presences, holding their own amid all the mechanical sound and fury. There are actually some humorous and heartfelt moments along the way - and even a lovably bumptious love story. How far would YOU go to get the girl of your dreams a chicken burrito?And then there's the last phase of the battle. That's bound to bring a tear to the eye of even those movie-goers most averse to the genre of Star Wars extravaganzas. The ending is something special.I do wish they would have provided a somewhat more valid justification for the necessity of that ending. I also wish they would have played up more of its details - showing more of the process that would have been involved in launching the final attack. Also, the people who play the biggest part in the touching resolution are oddly not mentioned when the military brass hands out kudos. That's a galling omission that detracts from the film's making a point of honor.Nevertheless, the ending, flawed as it is, is still bound to thrill viewers, especially members of "the greatest generation" or anyone closer to the time of those veterans who fought the previous "Great War." So while a wide range of people can find something to enjoy in this film, whether it be the metallic blasts or the love story - this DVD might especially thrill dads and granddads - and would make an evocative present for them.
summary: A Very Good Gift for Dad

reviewText: I was ready to hate this movie. Or, at least, find it stupid. But the way it is presented is the best I have seen in a while. Acting was pretty good, couple of tear jerking scenes, but special effects were great without being overwhelming.Overall, a very good, very entertaining movie. Definitely worth at least a rental even if you don't buy it.

reviewText: I like intelligent science fiction films, but every now and then I get a craving for a mindless action flick.  Battleship delivers the sci-fi and action components (emphasis on the action) but leaves out much of the intelligence.  That's OK because that's what I expected, and I enjoyed it for what it is.The story (such as it is) is simple:  An alien flotilla arrives on Earth and hides in the Pacific Ocean near Hawaii.  A U.S. naval fleet is conducting exercises in the neighborhood.  Mayhem ensues.The CGI effects are fantastic, and they bring to life some intense combat scenes.  If you liked Transformers, you'll like Battleship.  There's a fair amount of humor as well, especially toward the beginning.  The scene where Taylor Kitsch's character goes to extreme lengths to get a burrito for a girl is actually based almost frame for frame on actual surveillance footage of a comical burglary of a convenience store which occurred several years ago.  This movie could be a 2 hour long recruiting video for the Navy.  Fighting ships and all forms of naval hardware are showcased left and right.Before the movie was released, a lot of people made quips about how elements of the original board game would be incorporated into the film.  Well... that's exactly what they did!  The main defensive weapon on the alien ships hurls explosive shells that are shaped like the plastic pegs used in the game.  There's a scene during a night battle where naval officers are breathlessly staring at a computer-generated grid while a captain gives out targeting coordinates for missle strikes.There is a long list of things in this film that just made no sense.  For example, the aliens in the film are a paradox.  They have ships that can travel across light years in no time and can generate impenetrable energy shields.  On the other hand, their ships' main defensive weapons are no more effective than conventional artillery.  And for a space-faring race, they don't seem to be very smart.Despite its many flaws, I still enjoyed Battleship enough to give it 4 stars.  It doesn't deserve 4 stars, but it's just a fun movie.  It just requires a big dose of suspension of disbelief.
