reviewText: There's nothing wrong with a popcorn movie, one that doesn't require deep thought or have a profound message. But it still needs to be entertaining, engaging, and that means creating emotion. To make that kind of movie requires both the desire to do it, and an understanding of the fundamentals of storytelling and casting. This cynical piece of trash is nothing but empty gimmicks (a moving camera for virtually every shot...it's like watching a drive in movie out the window of a moving car), too-obvious and overused slow motion meant to create drama where really there is none, and an attempt to make it seem like more is happening than really with overblown orchestral music.  With the exception of one minor role, the acting is all bad, noticeably bad, which means either the producers can't cast their way out a paper bag, or more likely, they just don't give a damn. But they couldn't leave it as just their greedy grab for money by shilling an empty shell of a movie...if you know what to look for, you see elements of the agenda pushed on our country by a small minority to bring it down and keep it controlled by their outsider brethren.
summary: More Mindless Transformers Crap from Hollywood

reviewText: How in the world does UFOs ships able to fly light years away to get to this planet, but their ships are so easily damage by human weaponry?Aliens weapons can wipe out whole cities with ease, but they don't know how to make shields or defense weapons???Somehow, the aliens ship weapons are so powerful that they can take out human ships and cities with few shots, but their defenses are just like human battleships. *Yes, the pig can fly, but it can't land!* Ridiculous!Also, they had to dumb down the aliens a truckload to make the story keep going. Otherwise, the Aliens would had won and conquered within the first few hours after landing.Somehow, the aliens wanted to fight the humans in the old fashion battleship game situation.-Why in the world would they do that?-I don't know, but they thought it was a good idea...-That's stupid!But, we need to move on or the movie would just stop, period. The aliens won't fire on the humans unless, they fired first. Stupid again, but we need to move on or the movie would just stop. Somehow the main male lead and his crew mates can't get killed. Of course, everyone else is getting blown up with the ship, but these guys managed to find 3 boats to keep on living and trying. This thing should had been a comedy. lolAlso, the aliens must had been really, really stupid at the end of the movie. They were able to take out previous so many new, high-tech, bigger destroyer ships, but this old relic, battleship, "the dinosaur," is able to live on and fight the aliens! What???Then, instead of just firing at the battleship at the start, the aliens actually waited to see what the old dinosaur would do??? Bull crap!!!Why doesn't the aliens just fire at it when it started moving? Who in the right mind would just let an enemy advantage towards them in a full frontal attack position? A super intelligent being would had just shot at it and blow it up and be done it with it already. Heck, even the humans would had done that. Full on advances, and zero gun fire what so ever. Come on!!! This really is a comedy!Hell, that battleship could had been destroy back at the dock!Don't tell me their guns can't reach that far to shot at the enemy! The Aliens' guns can shot all the way to Hawaii and beyond!!! That's thousands of feet away. So, don't tell me they can't shoot some hundreds feet away, because that's just BS!This movie doesn't make any sense. And should be burn to ashes! Don't waste your time with this one. reviewText: It seems that as soon as critics, and in this case I use that term loosely, heard that someone was making a movie based on the board game "Battleship", the ridicule began and it didn't end.This is a far better movie than any of the Transformers ones, and even does bring into it, in a completely believable way, the game mechanic of Battleship.IN this film, some very nicely rendered alien spaceships invade Earth, and only the various ships which happened to be doing battle exercises in the Pacific can defend the Earth against invasion by a clearly superior force.I liked the acting. In a film that could have been extensively cheesy, performances by several members of the cast including Rhianna, were better than I expected, and the whole movie was exciting to watch from start to finish.I even liked the fact that the alien mines were shaped (though not colored) like the pegs from the game.I think people should give this movie a chance. Or perhaps critics are confusing it with "BattleFIELD", a movie that perhaps deserves the trashing it got.This one did not deserve the trashing it got.

reviewText: While perusing Instant Video on my PS3 this weekend I saw two movies that I thought would be cool. So on Friday night we did Battleship and on Saturday we didAct of Valor. And what a difference! With one you get suckered by stupidness and with the other you get captivated by awesomeness.Director Peter Berg recently did an excellent superhero movie with Will Smith calledHancock. So when I saw that Berg would be at the helm of Hasbro's Battleship, based on the trailers, I thought we'd get a cool military movie that focused on the Navy and how it would handle an alien invasion. However, what Berg delivered with Battleship was a hokey, corny, unrealistic dud. I almost walked out of my own home theater.On the other hand, fledgling Directors Mike McCoy & Scott Waugh come up with the unique concept of casting a group of real Navy SEALs in a story about fighting terrorists, and they deliver a powerful, realistic, emotional thrill ride of a military film.So if we break out some of the important elements of both films, let's see how they fare against each other:Battleship Story: 1 star - A cool Sci-fi/military concept turned into silliness by goofball, slow-moving side stories and disastrous attempts at humor.Act of Valor Story: 5 stars - A serious, action packed military film based on true events of the heroism of US soldiers that have to rescue an abducted op and take out a terrorist.Battleship Acting Talent: 2 stars - Taylor Kitsch (John Carter), Alexander Skarsgrd (True Blood) and Rihanna (Really? Rihanna???) corn up the screen with unbelievable portrayals of men and women who fight for our country.Act of Valor Acting Talent: 5 stars - U.S. Navy SEALs and U.S. Navy Special Warfare Combatant Crewmen show audiences their stripes and make you think that your watching real life Black Ops events captured on camera.Battleship Action: 3 stars - When the actors aren't hamming up the screen, the action is not bad, but unfortunately there's way too much hamming up the screen.Act of Valor Action: 5 stars - Even the short amount of time at the beginning of the movie that is spent introducing you to the heroes that will star in the film moves along due to the underlying tone of something big about to happen. Then when the real action starts, it's intense.Battleship FX: 3 stars - Okay, Battleship's FX weren't bad, but even the main alien craft had a hokeyness to it as it looked like some kind of Transformer-bot instead of a lean, mean, alien fighting machine.Act of Valor FX: 4 stars - Act of Valor is not an FX movie, but the use of current battlefield technology is awesome to observe in action.Average stars for Battleship: 2.25Average stars for Act of Valor: 4.75Hands down: If you've not had the opportunity to see either of these movies and you're here looking for something to order on Instant Video (or put into you DVD player), stay away from Battleship and add Act of Valor to your cart/queue.
summary: No Acts of Valor in Battleship

reviewText: Plot: To rehash every other reviewer... Humanity stupidly send out a message to space that essentially says "Here we are. Please invade us."  The aliens say "Sounds fun".  So the aliens leap in their uber-fast, technologically awesome starships that can successfully cross the vast voids of space to find a tiny planet but which, alas, are incapable of avoiding satellites or even landing safely. Go figure. Maybe the alien engineers put all their efforts into the propulsion units and forgot about the brakes and steering. Luckily for Earth only one alien starship had a communications module that could phone home and that was the one that hit the satellite.  So the aliens must use Hawaii's radio telescopes (or whatever) for that purpose. Hawaii is then surrounded by an alien force field and the aliens send in some traffic control bots to manage the crowded local highways. Luckily three navy destroyers are inside the forcefield and one of these has a senior officer who is an arrogant screw-up with the common sense of a deranged chicken burrito thief. Watch out aliens!To be honest, the premise of this film excited me and even the synopsis sounded fun. The graphics were certainly magnificient. Alas this film just felt like someone in the scriptwriting department had said "Hey, why don't we remake both 'Top Gun' and 'War of the Worlds' in one big movie, use ships instead of planes, replace Tom Cruise with his clone, and then include some real ex-military personnel." Actually, I'm glad they did include some ex-military personnel, especially the double amputee, because their acting I actually enjoyed. (NOTE: a big thumbs up to Gregory Gadson whom it is difficult not to admire).I give the film three stars because I did actually enjoy several parts of it, but the screenwriting just really was appalling. Watch it if you have nothing better to do with your day.
summary: I like big ships and I do not lie...

reviewText: It's bad.  But if you liked Skyline and Battle Los Angelos, also lousy movies, then you'll like this one.  So, what will you find in this movie?A pretty good beginning, but after that, it went downhill fast.  It's a cookie cutter alien flick, complete with absolutely ridiculous, leap frogging marine craft.  That's right, they came from zillions of light years away, but have no idea how to build a boat, so they hop like frogs.  And of course, today's audiences don't much care for beam weapons because they don't explode in big fireballs, so these 'advanced aliens' are using armor penetrating, explosive projectiles which tumble in the air and just happen to always land point first.  /sigh/The entire movie basically centers around the 'bad brother' being forced to "grow up" by taking command in the alien invasion, where his boat is cut off from the the rest of the fleet by a force field.All of the cliches and nuances of bad sci-fi/alien films are here, including aliens who are constantly switching weapons for no reason.The actors are cardboard (except Neeson), dialogue reused from the last 50 B movies, special effects are not special at all, ending is predictable, etc, etc.  I think you've got the idea.If you just like 'cool stuff' and lots of shooting, then this is for you.
summary: Flashy B movie, typical of today's forgettable sci-fi/alien flicks

reviewText: Taylor Kitsch was in two huge tentpole movies this summer--John Carter and Battleship. For a number of reasons, John Carter did relatively poorly at the box-office in relation to its cost.  It was, however, a really enjoyable film.  Battleship kinda tanked at the box office also, and so I thought that maybe I'd give it a try also--perhaps two Taylor Kitsch starring blockbusters would be similarly fun.  Well, John Carter started with a killer source--a classic of sci-fi pulp by Edgar Rice Burroughs.  Battleship started with a Hasbro game.  It is a fun game, mind you, but not much of a plot.  The movie makers completely embraced the concept of the game for this film--all the things that make Battleship a really fun game are here.  Two naval powers (one alien in this case) locked in a battle where neither can see the other and both need to bomb the heck out of the other.  That makes a great game, but kind of a thin plot as produced here.  The script tried to inject a little human drama in: the main character and his brother have a nice relationship, but it doesn't grow much.  Alexander Skaarsgard does a great job as the responsible older brother, but it would have been nice to see their relatinoship mature somewhat.  There is a very pleasant romance with an extremely beautiful woman who likes chicken burritos, a fact which fuels the best scene in the entire movie.  Sadly, that scene happens in the first 10 minutes.  Rihanna is another bright spot--true, she wasn't required to do much, but she had lots of screen time and she did a great job.  The special effects are, of course, excellent in quality.  Unfortunately, they are lacking in originality.  There is nothing wrong with the space ships--they look cool, but they look and behave like transformers.  The spinning ball saws are also very cool, but also look like transformers.  The aliens themselves are a little laughable, but get points for their creepy hands.  There are so many plot holes and contrivances that it gets a little wearisome in the middle, but in spite of it all, the movie comes to a satisfactory close as a popcorn movie should.  My pre-teen boys all thought it was great; I enjoyed it inspite of everything but will likely not need to see it again.  I probably should have waited for this to come out on HBO or something instead of buying the blu-ray, but i bet my kids will watch it enough to justify the purchase.  And if you haven't seen John Carter---give it a try.  It's much better popcorn fun.
summary: Pleasant summer shoot-em-up with aliens and burritos.  Enjoyable but forgettable.

reviewText: Possibly, I'm having a favorable reaction to the movie because I expected it to be horrible. But it wasn't. I expected there to be no story at all so was more than a little surprised that it had a bit of one. Cliche, for sure, but, still, there was a story. I'm not sure why these things -always- have to be about the slacker that doesn't live up to his potential until something catastrophic happens, because, generally speaking, when something catastrophic happens to a slacker not living up to his potential, disaster follows. But, then, that's probably why we want movies about the guys that do rise above the situation.Anyway...So the story is flimsy, but flimsy  is better than nothing. The acting was decent. The effects were spectacular. If you're looking for a good popcorn flick that you don't have to pay tons of attention to, this could be your movie.

reviewText: If you couldn't tell from the trailers, this is a simple, fun, goofy, over-the-top military-themed action-fest. It's Transformers with Destroyers and Battleships against space aliens. And as such, it is very, very good."You Sank My Battleship!"Yes indeed, this is a movie based on a board game (can Monopoly and Risk be far behind?) It's directed with plenty of film style that would make Jerry Bruckheimer and Michael Bay squeal with delight. Everything is done to be the perfect typical summer blockbuster with loads of gunfire, explosions, plucky but not-too-bright heroes and plenty of CGI eye-candy.Sun Tzu and the Art of ExplosionsWhat separates this movie from the other films of its type is the QUALITY of the film. Believe it or not, you can have GOOD cheesy dialog, and you can have BAD cheesy dialog. You can have GOOD CGI aliens, and BAD CGI aliens. This movie does it great all around.When my sister told me about how great this film was I didn't want to believe it. A good movie based on a board game? No way! But she's never led me astray before...and as the film progressed, I realized why she liked it so much...and why my dad said he liked it better than Transformers.Fire!For starters, Taylor Kitsch is GREAT in the main role of the plucky, rebellious, goofy, and awesome loser who becomes the Earth's best hope. I loved him in John Carter, and I love him here. He has great comic timing, he's fun to watch, and he's LIKABLE. I tried not to laugh when he went on a quest for a chicken burrito impress a pretty girl...and as the scene progressed, and built and built...by the end I could NOT stop laughing. Brilliant comic timing that, and good direction. I knew then I was going to enjoy this movie.Likewise, his arch-rival turned ally does a fantastic job, again with great timing and likability. I think most people groaned when they heard Rihanna would be in this film, but she's definitely no Ice Cube from Anaconda. Likewise Liam Neeson does a great job with his character, and all of the smaller side characters are pretty good as well. The only real downside in that department is the love interest. She's no Estella Warren, but she's just...a stereotype, and has no depth whatsoever (and in this movie that's saying something).As for the story, there isn't really one (but you knew that). What dialog there is, is mostly summer blockbuster dialog, but it's smarter and better done in general than usual. The same goes for action sequences, special effects, music, and overall style of story-telling. When I was actually enthralled by the climax of the film I knew they had done things right.Is this a movie I'd pay full-price to see? No. Would I buy the Blu Ray or DVD full-price? No. But do I want to buy a cheap copy of this movie on Blu Ray or DVD and watch it a gazillion times for guilty-pleasure entertainment? Absolutely!
summary: I'll have a Battle Royale With Extra Cheese, My Girlfriend Will Have a Chicken Burrito

reviewText: This Film was obviously sponsored by the US Navy. And why not, since they came out of it as a great organization filled with the right "stuff". But I don't care. It was great fun to see an Sf film with great special effects and not to mention a real Battleship (at least in some scenes). It was just 90 minutes of fun and even if you knew that it was all kind of silly it was worth every minute. Great stuff.Of course you could ask yourself why 15 people could man and fight a battleship normally crewed by 1800+ professionals. You could ask yourself why a museum have live 406 mm ammunition. You could ask yourself why aliens traveling through space have no close in defense. But why should you? It was great fun. Enjoy. I hope there is a sequel.The only question was why was this pop star Rihanna in the film? I know of product placement but pop star placement?
summary: Sponsored by the US Navy and I dont care!

reviewText: Perhaps that "p" at the end should be replaced by a rhyming letter.My excuse for watching is that (a) I knew nothing about it, and (b) that my countryman, the usually excellent Mr. Neeson, was in it. One makes these little mistakes in life... I can only conclude that Mr. Neeson is down to his last zillion.The good points; brilliant CGI.The bad points; absolutely everything else. It features a woman singer (Piranha? Something like that) who, thankfully, doesn't sing, although that might well have been an improvement on the stilted, cringeworthy dialogue and complete lack of acting in this gargantuan turkey. The entire enterprise is as far-fetched as the proverbial bucket of sugar from China and I struggle to recollect anything I've ever seen that is so totally implausible and disbelief suspension-defying. And of course it comes loaded with rah-rah sentiment and heart-on-sleeve moments for our gallant boys in uniform. However, if you enjoy cringing in embarrassment at the cinematic equivalent of spherical equine waste product, you will be in seventh heaven.

reviewText: The problem I see with film critics is they actually try to break down a film such as this as if it was going to be submitted to the Academy for Oscar consideration.  I understand why many producers are withholding their films from critics until they are in theaters because they can just massacre a film to the point where no one will go and see it. I critique every film I watch with just one question- "Was it entertaining?"  In the case of Battleship- YES it was entertaining!  It doesn't have an intricate plot, just a beginning, middle and end. It doesn't have award winning dialogue. No huge list of A-list actors. But these factors do not have to be in place to create a fun flick. The CGI was awesome, the actors did their jobs, I didn't have to stay on my toes for the next plot twist, and with Peter Berg directing you will not be let down if all you want is a couple hours to sit back, relax and watch a great popcorn action flick.  Just reading the title alone will tell you what kind of film you will be watching. And I don't get the whole "based on the board game" thing. From what has been said, it was one of the reasons it did not do well at the box office.  I don't even remember a reference to the game, nobody said "You sunk my battleship!" or anything like that! These types of "rotten" rated films will always be a part of my Blu-Ray collection and Battleship is no exception. Every movie is worth at least one look! I am not a film critic hater but please don't take just their opinion to the bank. I read all the reviews just for giggles and I went and seen it anyway. Read reviews from people like the other folks on this page, good or bad because we are the ones who understand the concept of "suspension of disbelief". Read the review from "Darth Maciek", that's who we should be listening to!

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The film starts with a NASA announcement that they are sending signals to a nearby "Goldilocks" planet to see if there is any life. We then switch to a bar scene where Alex (Taylor Kitsch) is "celebrating" his birthday with his naval officer brother Stone (Alexander Skarsgrd). He sees a young lady at the bar attempting to score a chicken burrito...which leads us to some comical events and then the opening credits.After the credits, the film jumps some undisclosed years ahead. Alex is a full lieutenant in the navy on a ship (normally takes 8-10 years to rise that high). The girl, Samantha (Brooklyn Decker) happens to be the daughter of the Fleet Admiral (Liam Neeson). They want to get married. The admiral loathes Alex because he is a gross underachiever. Everything is fun and games until...the subplots come together. At this point we can write the rest of the script. The alien ships were akin to transformers.I must apologize, but I enjoyed the film. The inane plot continuity issues and science was Asylum grade from beginning to end. I could be here all day writing about how absurd things were.  But unlike an Asylum film, they didn't cheat us on a soundtrack which ranged from Henry Mancini to AC/DC. We had quality actors playing likable characters with some decent lines. And no one can beat WWII vets during an AC/DC music montage.Think of the movie as "Independence Day" light with cheese. Good fun, good action, break out the popcorn and park your brain at the door.No sex, no nudity, near F-bombs.

reviewText: Battleship is a film based upon the board game by the same name.  As expected, the story thus is rather weak.  This movie bombed at the box office, repeating Taylor Kitch's lack of success this year (remember John Carter?)The movie does have a couple of other genre actors, including Liam Neeson who I always find does a fine job.  The other featured star is Alexander Skaarsgard, who has had recent success with HBO's "True Blood."To sum up the film, two brothers have joined the Navy.  Aliens invade, cutting off the ships from the outside world, and the few ships must defeat the aliens from destroying the Earth.  Uhh, that's about it.The visual effects are fantastic in this film, with plenty of action and explosions.  The weak story puts the film firmly into the B-movie category however.  If you enjoy movies such as those shown on the SyFy Channel, you will probably get a kick out of this film (worth a rental at least). However this was far from the blockbuster the studio seemed to be hoping for.

reviewText: It was great to see the wonderful old battleship, "Missouri" and some of the fine old Navy personnel that may have been (I think) among the crew on her.  Of course, I'm also assuming that the battleship was really THE battleship and not just a clever computer-graphics creation.Anyway, the rest of the movie is terribly simple-minded twaddle, whose "stars" are more like amateurs in a YouTube video. The plot is a joke, and the character development is even a bigger joke.  The special effects?  Meh, it's 2012, and so everybody's got good special effects.  But without a plausible plot, it's just an exercise in computer software.  Bottom line: this movie is really just another one of those pizza-and-beer movies, best seen after you've already had quite a bit of beer so that your brain won't be expecting very much of anything.
summary: The old battleship "Missouri" and some of the fine old crew are the only reason to see this.

reviewText: This movie was ridiculous yet mildly fun. The premise of the US Navy saving the world from alien invasion is borderline stupid it's so ridiculous.  So it had better be fun.Was it fun seeing Liam Neeson play an admiral? Sure.  There was enough story there to make that fun.  I enjoy watching him act in movies even those with ridiculous premises.  I'll say the same for Alexander Skarsgrd.  I enjoy watching him act, even if he's a goofy SWO instead of a Viking Vampire.  The movie gets one star for casting them and the rest of the actors were competent as well.  The girl was cute, the Japanese guy was amusing. Etc...I give it another star for the spectacle. Cool special effects applied to the pleasurable task of dramatizing an old battleship blasting the crap out of an alien spacecraft.  Ridiculous, preposterous, yet cool.Beyond that the story was pretty weak, the scripted dialogue contrived.  Worst, I found there was an ambient political correctness that annoyed, this one-world-nations-of-the-world-unite kind of thing.  Not super obnoxious but enough to annoy.Saw it at the dollar theatre and well enough worth it.  It would be fine for a dollar rental of the DVD too.

reviewText: I usually don't like movies based on video games because they focus mostly on special effects and have little plot. Battleship surprised me because it showed more of the relationship between the brothers and the naval officers and their men than merely having things being blown up with wholesale destruction involved.  There's plenty of battle scenes with destruction for the explosion buff however, and the brief glimpses of the aliens is intriguing to say the least. The idea of a Japanese ship and an American ship off the coast of the Hawaii Islands cut off from the rest of the fleet because of a force-field dome and having to duke it out using a decommissioned battleship and a crew of WWII veterans was a neat twist. (The ship is analog-run and none of the youngsters know how to handle a non-computerized ship so the oldtimers have to help the young whippersnappers.) The characters are cliches, of course, but all so perfectly portrayed one can forgive that, from the young scientist at the very beginning who compares the sending out of a spacecraft to communicate with whatever's out there as "Columbus and the Indians with us as the Indians," to the stern naval officer who's father of the titular heroine.  A few surprises along the way: the hero is a smart-ass loser who doesn't know what to do when he's suddenly placed in authority and gives command to the Japanese captain instead of forging ahead in his rebellious way to save the day himself. My only complaint: If only they'd left "THE END" before the credits instead of tacking on that opening ending afterward.  Just once give me a movie that says the aliens have been repelled and aren't coming back and leave it at that!  That notwithstanding, watch Battleship.You'll enjoy it.
summary: A Couple of Twists Make for a Better Movie

reviewText: Battleship, the movie?  Sounds terrible right?  A movie based on a board game where the objective was basically to guess coordinates.  Well, Peter Berg didn't see it that way.  From the minute he signed on as director, he was begging audiences to give his film a chance.  When the studio saw that American's were already 'knockin' it before tryin' it', they decided to release the movie overseas a month before the United States.  The outcome?  Well, let's go.What I liked about the film:The StoryThe STORY, not the script.  The story is quite simple really.  Aliens have crash landed on earth to take over satellite communication with their home planet.  By creating a force field around a small fleet of Navy ships, the aliens have forced the fight on water.  The script is being shredded by critics, and for good reason.  But the story was simple enough to justify the existence of the aliens on our planet, and in turn "justifying" the action.Taylor KitschTaylor Kitsch's character is a hot headed young man who's joined the Navy after his older brother (played by Alexander Skarsgard), refuses to financially support him any longer.  Skarsgard's character is a captain in the Navy and is the man in charge once the navy begins their war on the aliens.  What's important to note is, Kitsch's character actually does experience a growth, a nice arc.  He may not be the best actor doing these genre films, but he is getting better with every performance.The Action/Special EffectsIt's not an easy feat to create a war over water.  As an audience, we've come to expect the best of the best.  The movie creates action set pieces that have never been seen before.  Another complaint I'm reading online is, the movie completely disregards physics... really?!  What did you expect?  This is a movie about aliens invading Earth for satellite communication!  Come on people.  Writers Eric and Jon Hoeber wrote a simple, action packed script with some bad cliches.  But Berg choreographed some great action that made even the most mundane objectives exciting.  I especially liked the way the filmmaker incorporated the simple strategy of the board game into the film, without throwing it right in our faces.  Those hating on this aspect of the film need to get over it.What I didn't like about the film:The CharactersBeyond Kitsch's character, there is not much more to be proud of for the writers.  The great Liam Neeson is restricted to a few scenes from a chair.  Brooklyn Decker plays his daughter, and Kitsch's love interest... for no reason.  She literally serves no purpose to the film, other than eye candy.  Then there is singer/actress Rihanna.  She is a pleasure to look at, but again, has nothing to do in the film that a nameless character couldn't have done for her.  The trailer sold her as the daughter of a Navy veteran who predicted the alien attacks.  But the script does nothing to further explore that one line of dialogue.The ClichesSpeaking of the dialogue.  The writers must have tried their best to put in every action film cliche into the script.  There is the "Mahalo Mother F-----", BOOM, SHOT TO THE FACE.  There is the slow motion walk used in countless action films.  Only in this film, it's a set of 1940's Navy veterans asked to be a part of the final action sequence.  No seriously, I didn't make that up.  I wonder if the studio asks writers to put these things in their scripts?  Does anyone know?  I'd be curious to find out.  Nonetheless, a silly script with silly dialogue of course.The Verdict:Berg > BayThe above equation says it all for me.  I'll take a Peter Berg movie over a Michael Bay film any day of the week.  The similarities between Battleship and Transformers can not be ignored.  Berg however has a way of making the action more meaningful, placing more importance on the heroics of our main characters.  The movie is not great, by any means.  But by no means is it as bad as I thought it would be.  In fact, I rather enjoyed the mind numbing action.  There are a ton of 'money shots' to get hypnotized by.  I believe it is going to flop in theaters, and maybe this is the film to finally get through Hollywood's thick skull.  More original material (Inception), less tie-ins (Transformers).  Either way, take a date to this movie and enjoy the eye candy for two hours.
summary: Battleship review; not nearly as bad as some are saying

reviewText: You're in command of a vessel with no radar, cut off from all reinforcements, and seriously outmatched by your opponent. Your opponent being aliens. Do you panic? Do you surrender? Do you pay more than ten dollars to see it?In 2005, NASA has discovered a planet outside our solar system with conditions similar to those on Earth. Hoping that it contains intelligent life, they construct a powerful array of satellite dishes in Hawaii to transmit a signal to that planet. Simultaneously, unambitious Hawaiian native Alex Hopper (played by John Carter from John Carter Taylor Kitsch) meets a beautiful woman in a bar he wants to impress. The woman (played by Brooklyn Decker) wants a burrito but the bartender won't accommodate her. Hopper (Kitsch) hears this, introduces himself, and goes so far out of his way to impress her that he breaks into a minimart and is tasered by the police just as he's approaching the beautiful woman, burrito in hand. Alex's older brother Stone (played by Alexander Skarsgard) has had it with his brother's antics and makes him join the Navy. Seven years later, Alex is a lieutenant and tactical officer on a destroyer and the beautiful woman, Samantha, (Decker) has accepted his marriage proposal, pending her father's approval. Her father (played by Liam Neeson), an admiral whose character isn't given a first name, is Alex's superior who has disciplined him on several occasions and has grown just as frustrated with him as Hopper's brother has. Then, during an international exercise with the Japanese Navy, the world and the island come under attack by the very same aliens they hoped to contact.Now, this isn't the first movie ever to be based on a board game. Clue came out in 1985 and had a much better cast. Also, Clue is a game with characters in it. Battleship, on the other hand has none. It also doesn't have aliens. While there is an actual battleship late in the film, the alien munitions resemble pegs, and the crew is forced to fire blind once they've lost radar, this movie has nothing to do with the game. Other detractors seem determined to lay the movies failures at Rihanna's feet, this being her first acting role, but she really doesn't have that many lines and the failures in Battleship are so much bigger than this one minor character. Whether Transformers turned out the way Michael Bay and Spielberg wanted it to, it was a box office smash. Battleship is an inferior imitation, and I say that as someone who doesn't even like Transformers. Given how it's performing at the box office, I probably don't have to say this, but skip it.

reviewText: I must say in advance I should have paid more attention to the reviews. I also did not finish the movie, I couldn't, even tried to get hammered to finish it. Even buzzed this movie sucks, the male lead is an idiot, who in the begining breaks into a store to get a girl at the bar a chicken burrito. Gets her the burrito while running from the cops and hands it to her as he is getting tasered by the cops. Love at first sight, I thought that he was just going to be the comical relief but no he is the main character. The brother forces him at this point to join the navy, which I can tell you coming from a military service that he would never be accepted, mainly because of just being arrested. Then next we see him as a officer still making stupid mistakes and dating the admirals daughter, who he gave that chicken burrito too. Also now the retarded toilet paper that they are passing of as the storyline would have us believe that this moron is some kind of flawed military genius. At this point even knowing that the special effects were going to be awesome I could not watch anymore. I knew what I was in for the flawed hero goes on a journey saving the world while trying to be more like his brother who is the responsible type who was most likely going to die in the first alien attack. Then he realizes his own potential and becomes the great hero that leads the humans to victory over the aliens. DO NOT RENT AND PLEASE FOR THE LOVE OF ALL THAT IS HOLY DO NOT BUY THIS MOVIE.

reviewText: Imagine "Independence Day" with naval combat, and you will get a rough idea of what you will see in "Battleship." Very loosely based on a Hasbro's game, Universal Picture's "Battleship" is exactly what you expect from Hollywood's action-packed sci-fi blockbuster film: impressive special effects and incredible storyline.Four mysterious objects from outer space crash land off the coast of Hawaii during a RIMPAC, a multinational maritime exercise. Completely isolated from the rest of the RIMPAC fleet, Lieutenant Alex Hopper (Taylor Kitsch, "John Carter"), still inexperienced, finds himself in charge of the ship, which may determine the fate of the entire human race.The film opens rather slowly, with a silly episode about our hero Alex, who in his attempt to impress a woman named Samantha (Brooklyn Decker), breaks into a convenience store to get chicken burrito (shot in YouTube fashion). Alexander Skarsgrd plays his elder brother Stone Hopper, who forces Alex (arrested, but successful in impressing her) to join the US Navy.Directed by Peter Berg ("Friday Night Lights" "The Kingdom" "Hancock"), the film takes some time to introduce the main characters including Captain Nagata (Tadanobu Asano), Admiral Shane (Liam Neeson) and a weapon expert Cora Raikes (Rihanna). It takes some time for the film to pick up its pace, and once it does, it delivers the goods with fast-paced action set-pieces created with visual effects, even though the underwritten story never convinces.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie smacks of a brilliant "high concept" idea that was sold to a studio in a moment of perverse brilliance.  The stars aligned, the omens were good, and... we get a movie based on a 50 year old board game.  What could go wrong?The action doesn't even start until the 30 minute mark - before that we're getting backstory and character setup.  The hero is a screwup, but the incredibly beautiful girl loves him anyway, but her father hates him, but - yadda yadda yadda.  Get to stuff blowing up already.The aliens, when they do show up, are impressive, and the movie becomes a reasonably effective us-vs-them shootout.  Halfway through, however, we have to stop again so the girlfriend (Brooklyn Decker) can have some more character development and pick up a sidekick who will defend her when she's attacked by the aliens.  (Did they write this as they were shooting it?  Seems that way.)To avoid spoiling the ending (which anyone this side of Forrest Gump could see a mile away) I'll stop there.  But seriously - don't rent this until you're really desperate.
summary: It's based on a board game - what did I expect?

reviewText: We loved this movie - and after watching some of the info on how it was made - we noticed some fun things they worked into the movie from the game that we hadn't caught at first.  It isn't juvenile by any means - there are some scenes that may be a little mature for younger children - but nothing horribly steamy (which is often what I think movies get carried away with).  The girlfriend is shown with some pretty short shorts on one occasion - and is pretty close to the guy - so that stuff is not stuff I just love my teens seeing - but it also wasn't nearly as bad as some other movies that are interesting to older kids, but put too much bad stuff in them.  The language was not horrible either - considering this is a movie about sailers especially!!  The story was interesting - and definitely held our attention - we all watched it a few times.Rihanna is in this movie - and actually plays a character that I really liked quite a bit - though it was not what I might have expected.  This won't be one of the best movies you ever watched, but it's a good one - it was enjoyed by all - our 12 year old loves it, we enjoyed it, and my adult kids enjoyed it.
summary: Very enjoyable movie with some fun elements of the game that you'll want to watch for - more adults & teens than younger kids

reviewText: This movie is righteously a butt-kicking action movie involving the latest technology on the latest Navy ships, and even the old-fashioned, once alien ships splash down in the Pacific right in the middle of a war games exercise involving Japanese and American Navy ships. The aliens target 3 of the destroyers behind a major force field and manage to sink two of them, one of them a Japanese navy vessel. The surviving destroyer, the USS JOHN PAUL JONES manages to pick up the survivors, with only a Navy lieutenant at the helm named Hopper who apparently is on the last legs of his career, but is forced into command when the top-ranking officers of the JONES are dead.While watching this movie, I was thinking, "How is ONE destroyer going to fend off this alien force when the other two ships were destroyed without making much of a dent against the attacking aliens and when their alien scouts can't seem to be brought down by gunfire?" I mean, seriously, one of the crew had to actually kill one alien by blowing it off the deck at point-blank range with one of the guns of the destroyer. When the destroyer is eventually "sunk" off the coast of Hawaii(more like destroyed into bits), the survivors, including Hopper, man the decks of the nearby USS MISSOURI, an old WW2 battleship that hadn't run in over a decade, and only with the help of WW2 vets can they pull this one off for a final showdown against the alien menace.Action-packed in every scene! You'll literally feel your eyes burning when you don't want to blink while watching or you'll be afraid you missed something. And the movie critics need to really lay off. I've read their one and two-star reviews and I don't know what it'll take to impress these people enough to make a 5-star rating out of ANY movie because this flick is one of the best I've ever seen and have the honor to add this movie to my already-large collection! You like action flicks? This is the one for you! 5 stars all around!
summary: You sank my battleship? Not this one!

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Decent movies can be made from board games for exampleClue: The Movie [Blu-rayorJumanji (Two-Disc Blu-ray/DVD Combo)both entertaining flicks that manage to transcend the limitations of their origin. Then there's "Battleship".Coming off as a second-rate rip off ofTransformers Trilogy (Transformers / Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen / Transformers: Dark of the Moon) [Blu-ray], "Battleship" benefits from strong visual effects that borrow so much from the "Transformers" films that Michael Bay and Hasbro should sue. The plot is merely a pretense for the visual effects as are the performances from the actors.Aliens are invading Earth (is there no where else to invade? Haven't they seenWar of the Worlds [Blu-ray],War of The WorldsorIndependence Day [Blu-ray]?)? Stone Hopper (Alexander Skarsgard, True Blood) is a commander of a ship in the Navy, and his screw up brother Alex (Taylor Kitsch, Friday Night Lights) serves as a Lt. after lacking direction in his life and getting in trouble. Alex is in love with Sam (Brooklyn Decker)the daughter of their commanding officer an admiral(Liam Neeson poorly used in the film). When Stone and Alex's ships are trapped inside a force field created by the alien invaders, they are the only thing preventing a Pearl Harbor style attack by the aliens."Battleship" is a stunning looking Blu-ray. Skin tones are a bit off but, otherwise, this is a marvelous, detailed presentation of the film.Audio sounds terrific with a lossless presentation that puts you in the action.The biggest special feature here is director Peter Berg's "All Access" picture-in-picture presentation that features pre-visuals for the aliens, rehearsals and behind-the-scenes bits.Quite honestly I didn't dig into the other special features because I didn't want to waste my time."Battleship" arrives with a sharp, nice looking transfer that could blow most other Blu-rays out of the water. The movie itself, not so much. The film deserves an extra star for the visual effects, stellar transfer and the "All Access" special features.
summary: A weak script sinks this Battleship (Blu-ray review) although visual effects are impressive

reviewText: This film tanked at the box office, and there's a reason. Actually, there are many, many, many reasons. It's loud, obnoxious, stupid, preposterous. Based on the board game (never a good premise) of opposing navies doing battle with each other, the film brings aliens into the mix against an international armada. The film starts out with the only decent moment in it- a bungled break-in at a closed convenience store for the sake of a burrito, committed by a screwup and captured for laughs on surveillance cameras. From there, the film goes downhill fast. Flash forward a few years, and the screwup is an officer in the navy. Alien invaders arrive on earth in an advance force of a handful of ships, one of which comes apart and kills a few thousand people crashing in Hong Kong. The rest set up station around Hawaii during a naval exercise, surrounding the islands with an energy shield, trapping most of the ships outside. Circumstance leads to one of the battleships inside the barrier under command of the senior surviving officer, the previously mentioned wash out screwup about to be court martialed for disciplinary problems. Officer Screwup (also known as Taylor Kitsch) somehow manages to get himself into the right command mindset and takes on the aliens, whose ships spend as much time on the water surface as they occasionally- and clumsily- do flying. The alien tech is awkward, shifting and reshaping as the story calls for it, and the aliens themselves are less than impressive. The cast should know better than to have gotten in on this. Neeson and Skarsgard have the presence to be plausible naval officers, and Kitsch plays the screwup reasonably well, though his sudden reversion to thinking like a commander is implausible. These actors are all capable of better, and they do themselves a disservice by appearing in this disaster. Rihanna, whose music I don't personally like, should stick to music. Her acting is abysmal and painfully wooden. Director Peter Berg is capable of so much better than this- this is the guy who directed The Kingdom, after all. By the last act of the film, featuring veterans of the USS Missouri (I hope these guys are just actors, because if they're the real thing, they have not only disgraced themselves, they've disgraced the ship and their crewmates), the film has become so exceedingly stupid that the end result is that you've gone and wasted two hours of your life. Avoid this garbage like the plague.
summary: There's Two Hours Of My Life I'll Never Get Back

reviewText: I snagged this pile of offal from Redbox, so luckily I'm only out $1.29. It makes Plan 9 From Outer Space look like Citizen Kane! I knew I was in for a beating when I saw the name Hasbro in the production credits and that it was likely nothing but an infomercial for some game, but I also saw the name Universal, and I thought to myself 'it couldn't be that bad' but boy was I wrong! After a nod to the ALIEN MENACE! in the first few minutes, this groaner veered into a seeming parody of character development in which the high (make that low) point is a heroic, albeit criminal acquisition of a chicken burrito to win the heart of his true love! Oh, the sacrifices our male lead won't perform for true love! (By the way, look up the word kitsch in a dictionary) But, his criminality in no way means Kitschy can't go to Annapolis and graduate as a lieutenant, no dear friends, for this is a true hero who will let no obstacle stand in his way, not even a technologically superior race of EVIL ALIENS!, not even the disapproving Admiral/father of his true love! After 28 minutes or so of ridiculous introductions of various cliched characters, and a blatant ripoff of Tora! Tora! Tora! the invasion finally gets underway, and by this point I can't look away the same way I look at horrific wrecks on the freeway; Oh, the carnage! Oh, the humanity! (At least with the Hindenberg, there were survivors..........but no one survives this pile of horse exhaust, from Liam Neeson to the caterer; although it's obvious thay all got paid well, a big budget doth not a good movie make). Oh, and the Missouri? Hasn't been to sea in 10 years? No problem, fire her up, she'll do it! Guns haven't been fired up in at least that long? Quick, roll a few rounds off that pickup on the dock! There's only, what, 10 or 12 of us to run a battleship? No problema ,can do!!! And, just to make sure we've got all the target markets covered, let's throw in everybody, from the kids to the geezer veterans, so that everyone in the audience has someone to identify with! I could go on and on about how bad it is, but too many other negative reviewers have touched on all its blatant absurdities.  Golden Turkey? At least, cooked properly, turkeys taste good; The taste of wasted time in my mouth won't go away soon, and I'm beginning to think I might be a masochist after all, even though I fast forwarded through probably 1/2 of this. It's really a Golden Cockroach. To paraphrase the Bard, it's a tale told by a retard, full of sound and fury, signifying.................absolutely NOTHING!!! Strictly for undiscerning 8 year old boys.

reviewText: You know already when you walk in, just what you want to see. This movie delivers.We start with the ne'er-do-well soldier about to get drummed out. (You can already see where this is going.) Then, the big space thingie happens. It's now down to our plucky band (plus a few surprise guests) to save the world, which they do. And get the girl, despite getting off to a really bad start. The "old guys rule" meme comes in late and works well. For purpose of full disclosure, I must admit that I was recently identified by a waiter to my dinner partner as "the older gentleman," so I own up to lots of old guy sympathy.Great CGI, massive heroics, lots of genuine US Navy support, a really cute female seaman, and a happy ending. It's all you could hope for from a movie co-produced by the Hasbro toy company. Don't think too much, and you'll love it. I didn't, and I did.-- wiredweird

reviewText: This movie was excellent with an intelligent, strong, upbeat storyline!!!! The actors and actresses did a very professional job, bringing believability to a science fiction theme. The critics didn't like it because it wasn't wreathing with banality and gross violence like Prometheus. They liked Prometheus can I say more, lol, they raved about that movie. Talk about stupidity.The reason Battleship was not a success is the terrible trailers. Next time anyone is putting out a quality movie, let some of the story out. The trailers portrayed the women as wimps when they were powerful additions to the story. Let it out that a beautiful woman has a mind. The critics say it had predictable lines, they were soo wrong, but again they liked the stupid utterly no redeeming attributes of Prometheus. Can you tell I felt like I lost my money on Prometheus? I can't say enough about how bad that movie was.I'm really sorry that a movie as GREAT AS BATTLESHIP was smeared. I can't wait for it to be released on DVD.I RECOMMEND THIS MOVIE COMPLETELY, AN EXCELLENT ENTERPRIZE BY ALL, FROM ACTORS TO SPECIAL EFFECTS!!!!
